Recommended for those who like squad-based tactical shooters similar to the mid-2000's Rainbow Six games (think Rainbow Six 3 on Xbox) or those who enjoyed SWAT 3 / 4.  Not recommended if you're looking for more frantic, carefree FPS action since this game will chew you up and spit you out if you're not careful.

Presentation:  Gritty, unsettling, fairly realistic (if not often dreary) atmosphere provides an excellent backdrop to each mission.  Story telling is rather passive and there aren't any central characters or anything which to ground the story, so it ends up being little more than a footnote.

Graphics:  Beautiful lighting and weapon models along with some pretty cool animations for your SWAT squad.  Individual character models are only so-so with some stiff and somewhat buggy animation on suspects (especially civilians and hostages).  The game is intensely immersive, however, and it's easy to look past any imperfections because of the rich environmental detail that really pulls you in.  Prepare to be unnerved.

Sound:  Soundtrack adds to the strangely unsettling atmosphere and evokes a sense of someone's sanity slowly unraveling while also heightening moments of tense action.  Firearms are loud and intimidating, as they would be in real life, and ambient sound effects add to the already incredible atmosphere.  Immersive is an understatement.

Gameplay:  Slow and methodical, with a heavy emphasis on clearing rooms and detaining suspects.  Squad AI, overall, is very competent and can be relied on to carry out commands effectively with minimal loss of life (for your team, that is).  On the negative side, seeking out every last bit of evidence to achieve high mission scores become really laborious and tedious; would be helpful if squad AI did a better of of carrying out the "Search and Secure" command after clearing the map of hostiles in order to cut down on the amount of wandering around the player has to do.  Would also be nice if during pre-mission briefing, the map could be used to set player-defined waypoints that would appear in-game to help the player more efficiently move around the level.  But these are minor complaints; overall the game is great fun and highly satisfying.

Replay Value:  Virtually unlimited if playing multiplayer.  If sticking with single-player, it's much more limited.  You can unlock some items with which to customize your character by replaying missions to achieve high scores.  There's also an ever-growing library of custom-made maps that can be downloaded from various modding resources.  Otherwise, once you've beaten the campaign, there's not much incentive for another play-through outside of the your own interest in squad-based tactical gameplay.

There's a lot of problems in this game, from performance issues to random crashes and disconnects from online lobbies, this game is a lot less stable than most games. I cannot play for more than 1 hour without an issue of some sort with the game client. 
There's no online game lobby manager and the only way to link with players is to use a private lobby. There are also a lot of issues with the online public lobbies, for instance there's this guy that hosts a public lobby and runs a recording of some weird preaching and never actually plays the game. And since the game uses some random behind the scene dice roll to find you a public lobby, you can end up in that lobby multiple times without a way to control anything. 
Add random client crashes and issues and that makes for a very poor online gaming experience. Based on that alone I can't recommend.
Other than that the weapons are realistic and the gameplay is alright, but that's not enough to make up to the other annoying issues.

Ready Or Not: Entry team to TOC.

Patience is a virtue to an extent in the gaming world nowadays, much as I'm not a fan of the constant string of Early Access stuff. Every game that enters that dreaded stage always has a few cards stacked against it, and no game has had the same problem as Ready or Not. Much like Ground Branch, the tactical shooter market is filled with a variety of long haul development games that are still not finished after half a decade of work. And one that's aping more the ever loved SWAT series has more expectations stacked against it. I didn't think VOID had it in them, to be bluntly honest. What made SWAT work was not simply being a funny police shooter, but being a game willing to show casual horror. 

SWAT 4's remembered more for the Fairfax Residence and the Tenements than it was gameplay. You don't remember having to annoyingly shuffle your AI around and deal with bullet spongey enemies as you do the game showing you a graveyard of dead cultist kids and hearing the searing flinch of your team upon reporting it. That took balls in 2005, and I didn't expect VOID to do that. Especially given how generic the old 2020-2021 era RoN builds were.

And then they rolled out Neon Tomb. 

I'm already dealing with heavily armed terrorists and now I get to hear every cell phone in the club going off. 

Ready or Not is a game that knew where to pull its punches, although I still have some relative concerns as to where it's going to go now that we've crossed 1.0. Keeping the gameplay relatively simple was one, improving the movement and AI from SWAT 4 was another. And thankfully dialing the enemy AI back from the earlier 2023~ betas was the best move, so I can complete Relapse without having an aneurysm. It's a game that rewards both some level of careful planning alongside allowing you to go cavalier if you need to. And has rebounded into having some of the slickest level design and pacing I've seen in any game in a few years, let alone a tactical shooter with more AR's than a gun influencer's Instagram reel. It has it's issues for sure, the enemy is still quite good at hearing you and you'll get rewarded for being loud with a sawn off to the skull, and the overall plot is clunky. But I'm not going to forget Voll Health House. And that's more important long term than generic tactical movement mechanics. You'll forget Tarkov, you won't forget all of the tape in the basement.

Where to even begin.

This game had so much potential, but the 1.0 release has been SO bad, which is honestly made worse by the fact that it was in Early Access for, what, 2 or 3 years? And we didn't get any updates for well over 6 months. When 1.0 came around, we were inundated with bugs, poor optimisation, cracked AI, and a bunch of new mechanics that were so poorly implemented, they're still broken now. The game looked, ran and played better when it was in Early Access.

It's been two months since the initial release, and honestly there's been fuck all progress in making this game half-way enjoyable. Oh, and you have to reinstall the entire game every time they release a "hotfix" (Yea, that's what they're calling these 5gb+ updates, they're "hotfixes", not patches. Even though a hotfix implies a level of speed that is not present within Void.)

Stay well away until they A, stop releasing patches that force you to reinstall the entire game, and B, make some actual substantial progress in rectifying the games blatant issues with AI scaling, optimisation, and bug fixing. These issues should have been fixed LONG before 1.0, they were present during Early Access, and now they're [b]worse[/b].

Fuck Void for being part of the problem with EA releases

A little glitchy. When you shoot an enemy, the weapon they were holding can end up anywhere, including in the floor, not on it, in it. Good fun though. The downside is that civilians give you a lot of lip when you order them to put their hands up, one even pulls out a phone and snaps pictures of you (You can bet I've dreamed about shooting that one with a shotgun).

Edit: AI "helpers" AAARRRGH! Nuisance at best! When you try to just arrest suspects, they gun them down like there's no tomorrow. When you just go in to do whatever, they'll happily stand there and let you get shot by the suspect. Also, one of the AI shot me yesterday, I was behind a wall hiding from a suspect shooting and the AI straight up shot me.

Update February 25, 2024: At this point, Do Not Recommend, The suspects shoot THROUGH vehicles, and I don't mean windows, I mean through trucks and trailers. Granted, bullets will go through, but, they're also accurate through items with no line of sight. If this is the game play devs want, give me a 120mm mortar or a M249 so I can just wipe out the entire map.  We're not going for realism at this point. 

The AI have gotten dumber, if possible too. Even if there is a lot of room to walk around you, they have a path and they do NOT deviate from it, ever. Creating tactically incorrect situations. They REALLY want to walk in front of you, even if you're hugging a corner providing cover they want to walk in front of you.

At this point, I'm just clearing levels with no regard for arrests, it's flat out Murder Sim at this point, cause AI will stand and shout at suspects as they full auto kill you, NOT realistic.

Please, please, please repair your game (AI especially)!
It wasn't so during all the developpement (didn't feel that way at least, especially concerning the AI aiming).
- AI aiming is ****, complete garbage for this year. You almost always get shot at first before realizing why. Through bushes (it hits you, you don't know where it comes from, you die and have to restart), through crates (it hits you, you don't know where it comes from, you die, and have to restart), through walls (yes... it doesn't hit you normally but makes all your sight blurry so you can't do anything appart from trying to understand where it comes from while running back)
- Rambos refusing to go down even if they don't have armor and you are at your third jhp center mass on them (oh they keep shooting at you in the meanwhile, no probs)
- John Wicks one hit you as soon as you open the door (even if you saw them with the camera wand, you opened the door with explosives, you flashed them. You can't see anything with the smoke and your friendly AI doesn't react but they still know exactly where to shoot)
- you can't surprise anyone as all AI expects you weapon in hand (even at home yes, no rest for the brave...)
- light is all at your disadvantage as you can't see **** when you go from light to darkness or vice versa (when you have NVs on) but AI do not have any problem seeing you anywhere
- I spent a full mag trying to headshot a "baddie", one shot every 1 sec aiming the center of the head with a scope (40m away approx.). 2 team members were doing the same. We didn't hit him, he hit me several times firing full auto...
- armor doesn't mean anything, you get plastered almost as fast with the heavy armor on, you don't even feel the difference when you try to move with a light armor (supposed to make you more agile)
- your friendly AI is supposed to have a progression skill. You rarely see it happen as you lose all your team KIA or (more often) they leave you on the next missions as they are all demoralized considering you get one mission right every 4 or 5 of your tries (and their morale goes to the abyss).
It just feels random at some point, and most of all, everything, Everything is at your disadvantage.
Finally, you are supposed to be able to finish a mission with less than lethal ways. You never do that... Or you can try days for just one mission (applies for more than half the missions). They just don't care! They see you: they kill you the next 2 seconds (if closer than 10m). The only way is just to shoot at sight: GO SWAT!
pro tip: just alt F4 if you fail a mission, so much faster than waiting through the after action report. literally why is there no quick restart button

its really immersive if you have a team that doesnt run around like its cod, though its not  worth the price imo. there are like 18 missions and after finishing each one for like 2-3 times you've basically seen everything this game has to offer. The enemy placements change a little bit each time but they are more or less always the same, so the elemnt of not knowing if there could be someone with a gun behind the next corner kinda gets ruined.
i also absolutely dont understand why you need a huge chunk of 90GB of space for a game that has like 2 weeks worth of missions. 
Despite all that its fun to work together with people and carefully clear each room, i recommend waiting for sales before buying it.

This review will be brief, but I'll hit some key points that I've experienced in the 30 hours I've played to get me half way thru the game.  It's hard, really hard....I'm not an Ironman apperantly lol, and I love that about the game.   It seems to me that a lot is not really explained...regarding your loadout, your armour and what works or does'nt.  I like that too, cuz you will figure it out.   On a couple missions I changed out my loadout for me and my team and done it RIGHT the second time around......very rewarding.  
What I don't like about this game is the frequency that it crashes, or never even starts correctly.  My PC is way above recommended spec for this with an i9 and a GTX2080 but I keep finding myself looking for another new solution to the crashes every couple days.  I see a LOT of chat about it on the net, here in Steam, Reddit and beyond.  In that regard this game feels very unfinished.  I saw a warning pop-up today saying it may take minutes to compile a modded map while stuck loading................it was an official map!!  I've not tried a mod of any sort and everywhere I'm reading mods must be deleted from your .pak folders.  It took me an hour or more to re-update and verify the game again, just to solve the crashes for another day or so.   I'd really love to find some official support from the game developers on this.

-- Update 2024-02-24 --
EN:
After the last update, game is randomly crashing.


=========================

-- Update 2023-12-24 --

EN:
Oh my god, what have you done with this phenomenal police action simulator? This new version of the game is a total mistake.
1./ Less realistic enemy behavior, who flawlessly know where you are, even if you're sneaking at night and can barely see them through night vision goggles, and they just came around the corner, far from you.

2./ Enemies, dressed in t-shirts, are so bullet-resistant that you need to unload a whole series into them. They are as bulletproof as I am in my full armor with inserts. Even if you shoot them in the upper torso/head. The game is very random here: sometimes the same enemy, on the same map, is down with two bullets, and sometimes I've unloaded a series into them, and they just stagger and start to raise their weapon again.

3./ Infinite ammo of enemies: sometimes one shoots at you like crazy and has an endless magazine as if they had a weapon from '80s action movies (although sometimes they do shoot a few times and you can see they are reloading).

4./ Rating (evaluation system) after the mission. Sometimes I rushed in, did everything haphazardly and got an 'S' rating, and sometimes I did everything right but during the mission, the enemy shot a civilian, and I got a negative rating for violence on a civilian (wtf?). The worst part is that the game is buggy and sometimes allows you to finish the mission (vote up), the tablet shows all points in green, and I receive a 'failed' for not saving all civilians. Developers, something seems to be in need of fixing here.

5./ Bots in the team do not respond correctly to commands. For example, I'm under fire and ask for help 'cover me', and he replies that nothing like that is happening to me that would require his help. Or I say 'search & secure' and just a few days ago, they could spread out across the map and search for things like weapons or suspects to handcuff. At this moment, in response to my command, the bot confirms but does nothing.

More missions? Yes. More complex behavior of bots in single-player? Yes, but I can't say anything more positive about this new version and about the multiplayer game, where other players are weaker in this game than bots, and additionally, they shoot each other.
All weapons are the same (although there are many), and pistols are useless you fire the whole magazine at an enemy, and they still stand, as if I were shooting blanks.

I previously wrote, "Developers, just give us back the earlier version of the game," but now it probably wouldn't do any good.

This new game is not worth any price, except for being given away for free.
Even Fortnite (yuck!) is better now.


PL:
O mój boże, co wyście zrobili z tym rewelacyjnym symulatorem akcji policyjnej?
Ta nowa wersja gry to jakaś totalna pomyłka.
1./ Mniej realistyczne zachowania przeciwników, którzy bezbłędnie wiedzą gdzie jesteś, nawet jeśli skradasz się w nocy i ledwie ich widzisz przez gogle z noktowizorem, a oni akurat dopiero co wyszli zza rogu, daleko od ciebie.

2./ Wrogowie, którzy ubrani są w t-shirt, są na tyle odporni na pociski, że trzeba władować w takiego całą serię. Są tak samo kuloodporni jak ja w swoim pełnym pancerzu z wkładkami. Nawet jeśli strzelisz im w górną część tułowia/ głowę. Gra jest tu bardzo losowa: czasem ten sam przeciwnik, na tej samej planszy jest na dwa pociski, a czasem wpakowałem mu serię, a on tylko zachwiał się i zaczął podnosić na mnie broń ponownie.

3./ Nieskończona amunicja wrogów: czasem taki strzela do ciebie jak opętany i ma nieskończony magazynek jakby miał broń z filmów akcji z lat '80-tych (chociaż czasem faktycznie strzeli parę razy i widać, że przeładowuje).

4./ Rating (system oceniania) po misji. Czasem wpadałem, robiłem wszystko byle jak i miałem ocenę 'S', a czasem zrobiłem wszystko co trzeba ale w trakcie misji wróg zastrzelił cywila, ocenę ujemną za przemoc na cywilu dostałem ja (wtf?). Najgorsze jest to, że gra jest zbugowana i pozwala czasem na zakończenie misji (vote up), tablet pokazuje wszystkie punkty na zielono, a ja otrzymuję 'failed' za nieuratowanie wszystkich cywili. Deweloperzy, coś tu jest chyba do naprawy.

5./ Boty w zespole nie reagują prawidłowo na polecenia. Np. jestem pod ostrzałem i proszę o pomoc 'cover me', a on odpowiada mi, że nic takiego się ze mną nie dzieje, żeby musiał mi pomagać. Albo mówię 'seach & secure' i jeszcze parę dni temu, potrafili rozejść się po planszy i powyszukiwać np. broń czy podejrzanych do założenia kajdanek. W tym momencie na moje polecenie bot odpowiada, że potwierdza ale nic nie robi.


Więcej misji? Tak. Bardziej rozbudowane zachowanie botów na single player? Tak, ale nie mogę powiedzieć nic więcej dobrego o tej nowej wersji jak i o grze multiplayer, gdzie inni gracze są słabsi w tę grę od botów, a na dodatek strzelają do siebie nawzajem.
Wszystkie bronie są takie same (chociaż jest ich dużo), a pistolety bezużyteczne wystrzelasz cały magazynek w przeciwnika, a on nadal stoi, jakbym strzelał ślepakami.

Wcześniej pisałem, że "Deweloperzy, po prostu oddajcie nam wcześniejszą wersję gry" ale teraz to chyba już nic by to nie dało.

Ta nowa gra nie jest warta żadnej ceny, z wyjątkiem bycia rozdawaną za darmo.
Nawet Fortnite (tfu!) jest teraz lepszy.

EN:
For sure, the game is challenging: suspects can be literally everywhere and shoot, for example, from a mansion into the building when they see you through a window.

The only downside is the area with meth-filled junkie houses, where our squad has to find two specific meth packages (they are in random places). It's nonsense, and most people leave the game at that point, not waiting for the end.

Nonsense because it's investigative officers who should be searching for such little packages, not an entry team.
Nonsense because even if we were to secure the drugs, in the area we're storming, houses are full of this substance, so what difference does it make which ones we secure?

WOW. This is a painful one.

I bought this game somewhere around the end of 2021. Mere months before Adam update.
 	I was stunned by this early access version, even when it had huge problems. After the Adam update, I had huge hopes for 1.0. release. Played it both alone and with friends.  Development briefings made the expected 1.0. release look awesome. Thats why the reality is even more painful.
     
[h1] THE GOOD THINGS: [/h1]

Ready or Not is a beautiful game. Both graphically and on audio side. Weapon animations, models and sounds are just top notch.  Main police beautiful and AI companions got a little overhaul, which made them more reliable. Level selection is big, with 18 levels to play through. Weapons and character customization in quite varied. PC exclusive development can be felt with some advanced movement options. Most of the gameplay mechanics are more advanced than what 90% of this tactical genre offers. Unfortunately, that’s everything.


     
[h1] THE BAD THINGS: [/h1]
     There are lot of them. Here are a few things that I have to warn you about.

       [b] PERFORMACE IS BAD. [/b]
One time you’re running through hallway with stable 90 frames per second on highest graphics and next time you turn the corner you’re in a gunfight with suspect that runs on 15 FPS. Devs said that they would fix it shortly after release, but as far as I know, they only added one option to graphics settings that will help with frames just a little bit. For some strange reason, DLSS on ultra performance does almost nothing with frames for me. I’m talking about like 5-6 frames difference between DLSS and Classic.

       [b] SUSPECT AI [/b]

They messed it up. That’s another thing that they didn’t even touch since ADAM update.  Suspects do not have a single problem with one hitting you the millisecond that you enter some room.
	Other thing is the awareness of suspects. Every time that I put mirror gun under the door suspects just stopped in place and hypnotized the door. Suspects do not even react to getting shot. Animations are the same on every hit. There is no difference between you hitting them in torso, or hitting them in limbs either in animations, or reactions. 
	Aggressiveness of AI is brutal. You want to tell me that some random junkie with handgun doesn’t have problem with being yelled at by 5 officers with full auto weapons? Then proceeds to open fire at us, sometimes even rushing me and my whole squad the second we spawn on the map.
And then of course wallhacks. Just being shot through walls, doors, staircases. You will feel it on hospital map, where suspect will hit you through staircases, or solid walls.

	[b] SCENARIOS AND THEIR DESIGN [/b]

I can’t talk about this without comparing 23 megabytes to Fairfax residence. Both levels do have very similar situation. One suspect, armed, hidden in his safe space with hostage. What’s the difference you ask? Fairfax residence plays as its written. You raid one house in the middle of the nowhere, arrest one civilian, in this case mother of Lawrence Fairfax and then you and your squad proceed into the garage, where you’ll find that Lawrence build a whole underground complex to rape his victims in. His spawn in this complex is completely random, sometimes he’s hidden immediately behind door into his complex, sometimes he’s hidden behind curtains, sometimes he’s hidden with his victim on the very end of a tunnel.
 There is only one suspect that can potentially kill you, yet by the design alone, this whole level has better design and feels more real than most of the Ready or Not scenarios. The adrenaline rush and that anxiety that you feel in Fairfax Residence cannot be compared to anything in RoN
	Now for the 23 megabytes. Intel says that there’s only him and one hostage, then there’s a picture of few suspicious men, but description says that those are civilians. Can somebody in the name of God then tell me, WHY ARE THERE 12 OTHER GANG MEMBERS WITH FULLY AUTOMATIC WEAPONS? Nowhere in the trailer or in the intel was said something about whole gang just chilling in this apartment complex. 

                [b] THIS TEAM IS CAPABLE OF CREATING GREAT SCENARIOS [/b]

The only map that I can say that I enjoyed was Hide and Seek, and it’s not just from the gameplay side. I feel that Hide and Seek was the only mission that developers finished completely. From a huge amount of soft point objectives to ENVIROMENTAL STORY TELLING and smart hostile placement. After previous 17 missions of just clicking mouse on hostiles and points of interest, I was positively surprised when [spoiler] after you search most of the containers looking for weapon supplies, one will contain missing people, it’s one of the soft point objectives. You will report this human trafficking to TOC and at the same time, completely different division will contact you, creating an argument, where you want to extract these people while the different division wants you to lock them back in the container, so they can then take the container with them. You will agree and lock them up, with your character ending the whole conversation on well talk about this after operation. [/spoiler]
At one point I even expected a cutscene to play after this mission, where we would see situation escalate. But I was just hit with credits. It’s the one and only mission, that has this amount of polish in it. If every mission and situation was like this, if could ignore most of the problems that I have with this game.

            [b] REPETITION. [/b]

It’s always arrest this guy, kill these people, secure civilians, press interact button on this point of interest. In SWAT 4, you had these, then levels that required you to disarm explosives under time limit, active shooter mode, where hostile NPCs move from room to room shooting every civilian on sight, decreasing score after every dead civilian, then instant action mode, that threw you into some of these scenarios with completely different objective locations, traps, enemy spawns, and restrictions every single time. It created infinite replay value that was even more extended with modes such as Back to Los Angeles, First Responders and Elite force. In Ready or Not, I will finish level and that’s it. Spawns are almost the same every time.

      [b] EQUIPMENT PROBLEMS AND WEAPON DELETION [/b]

I do not understand, why heavy armour with steel plates still gets perfectly penetrated with Glock. In Early Access I did not have a single problem with it. It made for some funny scenarios where I just put on the heaviest armour and shotgun and annihilated every single suspect in that mission. SMGs and handguns are just unusable on some of the missions, with suspects taking more than 10 bullets in their torso, sometimes even head and still walking. Other thing that I immediately saw was that some weapons that I played with in early access are just not in this game anymore. Mirror gun is just useless without Fullscreen mode because picture in picture mode lowers resolution so much, that it’s impossible to see what’s on the other side. Again, game from 2004 did not have this problem. Flashbangs are 50/50. Sometimes it will hit enemy standing 5 meters from it, sometimes it hits enemy right in the head and does nothing.


[h1] VERDICT: [/h1]

Right now, I do not recommend RoN in this state. I’m confused why all those that gave this release positive reviews never mention these problems. Do I have some extremely old version or am I just the only one with these problems? Do I recommend this game right now? No and I think that I will not recommend it for a long time. With devs focusing more on DLCs than patches. This game has a lot of potential, but from devlogs that are released on steam, it looks like that the main focus now is to monetize this game with DLCs as much as possible and actually patching this game being more of an afterthought.
It’s been a broken mess for years. The devs will never fix it. The severs are dead and a shitshow. They scammed us. Don’t buy, push to get a refund.

The game has great potentiel, but as of today there are many problems that are hard to overlook :
1) PERFORMANNCE IS TERRIBLE. I'm getting stuttering and drops to 15FPS with a 5800X and 4090. It's been 2 months since the final version release and nothing significant has been done about this. This is unacceptable considering that performance in early access was normal.
2) AI. In the previous version, AI had some minor issues like wallbanging and insane fire rate, but these were manageable and the game was challenging. In the latest update the AI was simply destroyed. Reaction time is way too slow and AI is much less aggressive. There is no difficulty anymore, you can easily solo maps and play this like Call of Duty.
3) Content. Much of the content that was promised during early access was not delivered. Some features were even removed like the ability for suspects to hide in closets or under beds.

Apart from that, the game is fun, immersive and is a pretty good SWAT simulator.

This game has great potential but still isint really there compared to its direct inspiration, Swat 4. Gun play is good and graphics are very good (for most I have to play on low and things look very bad on low) The AI leaves a lot to be desired. Strange movement, unrealistic and unfun accuracy from the enemies, and enemies refuse to give up even when its suicidal. Swat 4 really nailed this, enemies gave up when you had the drop on them and resisting would result in their death. In Ready or Not they never really do that, and choose to shoot you even when it would lead to their immediate death. This makes sense for terrorists and such but for the gas station robbers to fight that takes away from the fun.

The weapon library is also very bland, would like to see more than just ARs for rifles, possibly bring back some of the older guns that were cut.

All together, I would wait a few years to see if the game drastically improves before buying. Needs some more time in the oven

Now, I need to get this out of the way first. This game is absolutely not for everybody. So bear that in mind. But if it is, I daresay you will enjoy yourself.

Now, the bad out of the way first: the tutorial is extremely buggy and not really reflective of the gameplay at all. The squad command sometimes refuses to work properly in the tutorial. However, in actual gameplay, I think the squad command system failed me only once and was quickly fixed. 

Now that is out of the way, I can talk about the good - the game somehow manages to make gameplay both methodical and stressful at the same time. This sounds like a contradiction but this game manages to do it which is beautiful. You have to be methodical especially later on because there are doors that are booby-trapped and if you open them while close to live traps, it's a game over for you. Gunfights are also stressful because the enemy can actually quite easily kill you if you're not careful. The enemy AI is quite tough and good, but generally reasonable and if you're not a complete doofus you can generally make it out alive. I'm not an expert on police stuff but this seems to be a fairly realistic depiction of CQB. There are also quite a number of weapons to choose from although you generally want rifles (I like the AK myself) or semi auto shotguns. But I get why these weapons are there even if they aren't that good - police departments actually do use those weapons.

CANNOT recommend in its current state.
VOID has prioritized development of PAID DLC over FIXING THE GAME.  VOID has announced that update 1.2 will come AFTER the 2nd PAID DLC.  Core mechanics that were REMOVED upon release of 1.0 have NOT been re-added to the game lowering replayability. 

Ridiculously terrible optimization, even with HIGH-END specs and LOW settings the game struggles to run smoothly.  Many bugs and issues including really inconsistent and unreliable AI behaviors for both SWAT and suspect AI, which is the core part of the game.  Suspects will at random lock onto you through walls and start shooting through objects that the player cannot.  While earlier level suspects have believable levels of accuracy and reaction times, as the game progresses the suspects start to have Tier 1 Operator, 3-gun competition 10 times consecutive World Champion levels of accuracy and reaction times which should NOT be the main gameplay balancing factor and is quite frankly a lazy way to balance gameplay.  Suspects vary from gang bangers, meth heads and cultists all the way to hardened ex-military militia and actual terrorists but they all act the exact same way.

Downtime between missions is terrible in singleplayer, there should be no countdown to start the mission in singleplayer mode. The player is not spawned in front of the desk and there is no way to instantly retry a mission unless you are in practice mode.  There is no way to check which missions you have S ranked unless you walk all the way to the lockers wait for the customization menu to load and click some more and see which tattoo options you have unlocked.

Ready or Not was MEANT to be great spiritual successor to the SWAT series with a lot of potential that was MEANT to be a fun tactical shooter to play both alone and with friends, but it just isn't in its current state.

Please for the love of TOC fix the game before working on PAID DLC.  New guns and maps mean absolutely nothing and are completely useless to us when the game itself doesn't even run smoothly on low settings for some players, you are turning your back on and betraying your long time supporters to prioritize development time for PAID DLC. If we really wanted new guns and maps we would just download the free mods.

Edit: The performance is good now, and the AI it's pretty balanced, congrats, VOID team. Great SWAT 4 successor; my then ten year old me would never believe something like this was going to be possible in the future. x)


In 1.0, the game has drastically changed a lot, for the good and for the bad.

Performance is a big deal now for the bad; in early access i could run this game smooth, unless there was a bad optimized level, like Brisa Cove. Now i get constant fps drops in certain areas in every level. Is not my pc.

SWAT AI: Amazing. They're really cautious, professional, dilligent and efficient... WHEN THEY WANT TO. Sometimes it has happened to me that i gave an order to them and they decided to open doors just because, or even "soloing" areas getting themselves injured or killed. Or even open doors while i'm using the mirror. I just hope this kind of issues are part of a list of bugs/problems that the VOID team are actually aware of and so, in the short future they all will be fixed.

Suspects AI: Broken. Simple as that. They can shoot through walls sometimes, NEVER surrender even when all SWAT members are shooting at them, or just take any chance to risk their chances to fck you up while having to die in the process. It's clear that this is NOT intended, or it shouldn't be at least. In my point of view, these kind of things will be balanced in the future... Not only because a lot of people are noticing and having constant problems with the sus-AI, but because i don't think this right now, is the vision the VOID team have for their game; not a SWAT tactic game, but a plain combat shooter.

I understand for one hand that they had to release the 1-0 in the date they planned, but on the other hand, it would appear we're having the same usual problems we gamers have nowdays with "big" games releasing sooner than planned. Or just releasing something clearly NOT finished.

Even so, i would not make this a negative review, because that's not my intention. Instead, i'll make it clear what i wrote is part of a constructive point of view from a game i really like, and perhaps, will love in the future.

VOID Team, listen to your community. Thanks.

Quick(ish) Review Gaming

- I have not followed this game apart from seeing occasional big updates and videos from creators pre 2024, this includes revisions to contents or dev logs (only checking after)
- I have not previous played any tactical fps games that required 5+ minutes of planning or at least trigger discipline to be competent 
- I have 'passed' all main vanilla levels using lethal and non lethal using ~70% of the given arsenal and A+ or S ranked half of them

(As of Feb 22) 1.0 of Ready or Not is a 75/100 due to mainly suspect AI (e.g. Valley of the dolls)

Major Compliments:
- Really impressive single player teammate AI behaviour*
- Atmospheric music, environmental detail as well as story telling

*still occasionally hiccups in threat assessing big windows over doors after clearing a room (e.g. Valley of the Dolls front entrance)
Necessary Changes:
- Different Suspect AI, untrained desperate drug withdrawn teens full auto and wall bang as expected but mentally sound and trained private security (probably) don't
- Suspect spotting distance or behaviour (although mixed on how to change), suspects' AI ignore or take into account too competently aspects such as bright lighting that blinds or tinted windows when spotting SWAT before engaging

Still in early access but MAN, is this game AMAZING! 
Not for the faint of heart, it's a slow paced, realistic, police, tactical FPS.

The game definitely benefits from playing with an IRL team, but it can do NPC teammates for anyone (myself) who doesn't want to or for whatever reason can't play with others.

I got it running on my steam deck and played offline, the settings where a mix of High/Med/Low on a bunch if different things, and the trickiest part was fully mapping out the controls. Not sure if I managed to even map everything, but I'm pretty sure I got around 90% of what's available tied down with a combination of the TouchPads and back buttons.

The developers were/are absolutely uncompromising in their vision to bring a brutal and painfully realistic vision of the bloody business that takes place within the world of police tactical operations.

Violent crimes, drugs, human trafficking, child predators, bitcoin-bandits, it's all there and it's your job to bring them to justice or put them 6ft under!

This game gets ruined by the poor AI's. whether on the bad guy's side or your squad teamates, they are terrible and frustrating, to see it in this state after 1.0 is a big let down for me.

Gun play is good, graphics are nice and it fills the niche of tactical shooter.

Unfortunately, V 1.0 was rushed out the door far too quickly:

Friendly AI obeys commands erratically when it comes to stacking or executing simultaneous orders resulting in them getting killed. Performance is all over the place. While it's not hard to run the game - especially with FSR - there are certain areas in every match where performance will tank regardless of hardware.

However the largest issue is the suspect AI. In a game where you shouldn't have to kill every suspect, the Ready Or Not AI really makes it hard to resist. Every enemy whether a lowly gangster or military trained opponent all have instant reflexes. For most maps you beat this by playing slow, flashing rooms, etc. However, some deaths are unavoidable as an enemy will sprint out of the room firing perfectly accurate shots killing 2 of your teammates and you in the crossfire. All this could be forgiven if they couldn't XRay headshot you through walls. Take a look at youtube to see examples of AI tracking teammates they never made contact with and killing them. Or, your friendly AI all shooting through walls when you've made contact, resulting in them killing the perp. People recommend mods, but mods only dull the reactions of the enemies or change their morale. This doesn't fix the fundamental issue of being able to see and track through walls.

Another issue with 1.0 is the lack of map modes. Before this update many maps had different ways you could play them. These included bomb defuse, active shooter, or raid. Now each map only has one mode each.

That said the game is fun. I'm closing in on 100 hours and have mostly enjoyed my time - although most of it was before v 1.0. I'm hoping VOID will patch these issues after the holidays. If so, I will definitely change my review to a recommend.

tdlr: 1.0 brought some good stuff but a lot of bad as well. VOID has some bug fixing and serious patch work to get the game's ai, performance, and replay ability ready before I can recommend it.

Edit: 2/6/24 Hotfix 3
Hotfix 3 just came out and it seems to have helped with the AI issues. They don't seem to wallbang unfairly anymore. Performance seems more consistent - at least on Carrier of the Vines. Unfortunately, ally ai still fails to execute commands properly and it will get you killed if you play by yourself. For example, if you want them to enter the room the same time as you, half the time they won't perform the command properly and stay stuck at the entry way. Once VOID fixes or reduces that I'll be changing my review to a thumbs up.

Edit: 2/21/24 Hotfix4
Improved performance in some places but the ally AI still disobeys orders. When you tell them  to enter with you they either enter by themselves or not at all, etc.
This is officially finger lickin' good.

(TL/DR at the end)
Many years ago there was a similar game, SWAT, that hooked my young teenage brain. The first two games were tactical top down style , but SWAT 3, was a fps tactical shooter. Incredibly intense, varied missions, and very often there were surprises as to where the suspects were etc. It set a precedent that I never got to top as far as "realistic shooter" goes.

Fast forward probably 20 years, and this finally topped it. Suspects don't just empty mags, sometimes they run and hide, sometimes they give up, there's a LOT of trigger discipline if you want to get high scores.  Shooting suspects isn't fun, they scream in agony if injured, and you lose points for not capturing them alive. Some missions (Elephant example) due to time constraints, forces you to "run and gun" the way through the mission, and others, force you to check under every, freaking, door for bombs or hidden suspects. The missions have some randomised suspect placement, and they move from room to room, so even though a room has been already cleared, there's a chance someone might have snuck in from somewhere. I've had a blast replaying missions over and over, especially the harder ones, forcing me to adjust equipment for the squad and myself.

Flash bangs, gas, shields, armour types, night vision, etc. etc. There are so many load out combinations it would take some maths to determine how varied the team can be. It changes a lot, to choose a ballistic mask vs a gas mask vs night vision could change the outcome of the mission. There are plenty of guns to choose from. Assault rifles, SMGs and shotguns for main, pistols for secondary, and a ton of specialised equipment like tasers and launchers. There are even pepper ball guns (ideal when trying for an S). All of the guns mentioned here are available IMMEDIATELY, no grinding necessary to unlock a taser or gas mask. No micro transactions. The unlocks are granted after successfully completing missions with a high enough score, and they are nice, but not "game changing".

I'm 4 missions away from beating the game in practice mode. It has been 13 hours but a lot of that has been replaying missions either because I enjoyed them or because I wanted a better score. So I guess you could say it's not a very large game, it's quickly played through. Personally I find that because of the amount of detail in each map, the variety of situations and outcomes on the same mission, and the very real challenge of scoring an S will probably keep me playing for hundreds of hours. (like i did with SWAT 3 as a kid ...)

I wish I could give this game a positive review, but at the moment I can't. Everything about this game rules. It's so good, but at the moment the suspect AI is absolutely busted. In Early Access, the suspects were challenging and janky, but they weren't that broken. Since the full release however, they are absolutely insane. Constantly shooting me though walls and objects and their reaction time is inhuman. It's just not fun to bang my head against a wall on one mission because I can't finish it. I am all for challenging games. Heck I love the Dark Souls series, but at least in Dark Souls you could cheese some boss fights to your advantage. In this game you can't. They have an insane amount and armor, but I feel like that I am wearing no armor at all. I hope there is some kind of change to their behavior or reaction time, or at the least I hope they include a difficulty slider. I am willing to change my review to positive once this has been adjusted. For now, just don't get this unless you want a very unfair and frustrating time.

Edit: The AI can be toned down with mods which is what I decided to do. Still leaving this as negative since this needs to be addressed by the devs. This shouldn't be something the community needs to fix.

Edit 2: The game has had a few enemy AI tweaks. I'd say it's still not perfect but it's in a much better state. If you are slow and careful, missions can be completed fairly easily. I would recommend this game now. Changing my review to positive.

Cons:

3. Custom maps would be nice

-HONEST REVIEW- currently the game is in early stages which means there is work to be done by the devs to make it the perfect game we all payed £45 for, but devs seem to ignore basic complaints and make no effort to fix them, game feels like its still in "pre-release", enemies have the skills on john wick even though most enemies are teenagers or untrained thugs. even when the enemy is using a makarov pistol and they have no armour they can still tank over 4 upper body shots from a 5.56 rifle before reacting to you but then when they shoot you twice with their pathetic Russian pistol you get absolutely destroyed, it takes around 8 shots with a rifle-carbine for me to kill my teammate with full armour and ballistic face sheild but it takes the ai with a low level pistol less than 4, it takes me 7 shots with the same gun to kill an un-armoured thug. it has reached the point where i have downloaded multiple "realistic ai" mods to my game just to have a small amount of fun, even still the ai still obliterate me. One time a flashbanged and pepper sprayed 1 low level enemy and he just would not surrender, also i shot the same enemy 3 times whilst he was blind, deaf, burning eyes, ringing ears severely bleeding and almost dead AND HE STILL WOULD NOT SURRENDER, if i had a free trial on this game i certainly would have NEVER paid £45 for it not even £15 because its simply boring, it feels like im playing a run and gun shooter and not a tactical swat simulator, the whole point of being in the police is to defuse the situation without killing anyone or at most killing as a last resort but at the monent i feel like im killing everyone because the AI is relentless and they will shoot without a second thought hitting every shot. also why do they not flinch? im getting shot at by them and my charcater cannot stay still yet the AI is almost dead and has pinpoint accuracy. RIDICULOUS i would look for alternatives untill the devs fix the game i would rather play roblox than this mess. Also i'm not surprised that game play footage isn't included in trailers because the devs would probably get embarrassed by their own creation. the trailer looks promising until you realise it is nothing like the raw game play. obviously the devs could release gameplay footage but even still they could re-programm the AI just for the trailer to false advertise so it would still not be the real deal. If you feel like being lied to and ripped off then sure, buy this game, but if you want to keep the money in your wallet i would suggest getting a better game like tarkov, i say LIKE tarkov because tarkov isn't actually very good its just better than this cess pit of a game. Another small complaint is the micro-stutter, -J E S U S - it is bad, but not only does micro-stutter ruin the game play experience but it actually decreases the longevity of your system (slowly kills your graphics card). im sure that there is probably some silly tutorial on how to fix it but this is something the devs need to fix not the player, most of us want to game not code, if i wanted to code if would work at a Mumbai scam office. This game also lacks content; because the games gunplay is so bad perhaps a campaign could make this game worth playing but instead we all play the same missions over and over just to get a rating at the end, NO PROGRESSION, NO STORY, NO ENJOYMENT. This game has great potential but its just boring, the maps are not what anyone expected, teammate AI hardly say anything of relevance, screen FX are over the top and annoying. Overall if i could improve 3 things of the 100,000 things that need to be improved, i would want improvements on: the shooting/gunplay/screen effects when being shot at, add a campaign/story (maybe similar story type to the HITMAN series), and finally have better, smaller, more engaging maps. D E V S.....T A K E.....N O T E

Ready or Not burst onto the scene with promises of unparalleled tactical realism, aiming to set a new standard for the genre. Developed by VOID Interactive, this game has been eagerly anticipated by fans of tactical shooters, drawing comparisons to classic titles like the SWAT series. As a tactical first-person shooter, Ready or Not challenges players to navigate high-stakes scenarios with precision and strategy. Let's delve into every aspect of this highly anticipated title.

Gameplay Mechanics and Realism:
At the heart of Ready or Not lies its commitment to realism. From the moment players step into the shoes of elite law enforcement operatives, they're faced with the gravity of their decisions. Every mission demands careful planning, coordination with teammates, and split-second tactical choices. The game excels in its attention to detail, with realistic ballistics, weapon handling, and AI behavior.

Each mission is a dynamic puzzle, with multiple entry points, unpredictable enemy placements, and civilians who react realistically to the chaos unfolding around them. Players must balance their use of force, employing non-lethal methods whenever possible to minimize civilian casualties and maintain the integrity of their mission objectives.

The planning phase is where Ready or Not truly shines. Players have the freedom to meticulously plan their approach, analyzing blueprints, coordinating breach points, and assigning specific roles to each team member. This level of tactical depth adds a layer of immersion rarely seen in the genre, rewarding careful planning and teamwork.

Graphics and Immersion:
Visually, Ready or Not impresses with its attention to detail and atmospheric lighting. From dilapidated urban environments to sprawling suburban homes, each location feels lived-in and authentic. The game's sound design further enhances immersion, with realistic weapon sounds, ambient noises, and dynamic voice acting adding to the tension of each encounter.

However, the game's graphics optimization could use some improvement, as performance issues are prevalent on lower-end hardware. Additionally, character animations can feel stiff at times, detracting slightly from the otherwise immersive experience.

Single-Player Campaign and Multiplayer:
Ready or Not offers a robust single-player campaign, with a series of missions that progressively increase in difficulty and complexity. Each mission is replayable, with randomized enemy placements and dynamic objectives, ensuring that no two playthroughs are alike.

The multiplayer component of Ready or Not is where the game truly shines. Whether it's cooperatively tackling missions with friends or facing off against other players in intense PvP encounters, the game's multiplayer offers endless replayability. The addition of mod support further extends the game's lifespan, allowing the community to create custom maps, missions, and gameplay modes.

Community and Support:
The developers at VOID Interactive have shown a strong commitment to engaging with the community, regularly providing updates, addressing player feedback, and implementing requested features. The game's dedicated modding community has also contributed to its longevity, with a steady stream of user-generated content keeping the experience fresh and exciting.

Conclusion:
Ready or Not delivers on its promise of tactical realism, offering a deeply immersive experience that will satisfy fans of the genre. With its attention to detail, strategic depth, and commitment to realism, it sets a new standard for tactical shooters. While it may not be without its flaws, the sheer depth and complexity of its gameplay make it a must-play for any fan of tactical shooters. Ready or Not is more than just a game; it's an experience that will keep players coming back for more long after the credits roll.

An incredibly cinematic shooter. Your team of up to 5 is tasked with taking back Los Suenos over 19 (and increasing) carefully crafted missions, each with a full debrief, audio files, evidence to discover and examine, and more. 

The shooting mechanics are some of the best in the genre. Each weapon feels weighty and bullets land with incredible power. The audio design from the police radio banter to the firefights is extremely satisfying. Visually the game is impressive, and challenges you to follow ROE and protocol vs going in to every room guns blazing (though that is often required in my experience).

The devs are active and have been releasing massive content and bug fix patches frequently for years and have no plans of stopping. The inclusion of community content give unlimited replayability to an already impressive title.

Even in solo play, you have full control over 4 squadmates, whom you can customise the loadouts of to fit each scenario and command with an intuitive ui, though personally this does not compare to the tactical requirements of human teammates.

Overall, a great title that my group will return to several more times. The devs are great and im happy to support this project and any future ones they decide to work on.

Truly an excellent experience. Very well supported and consistently updated, and the team is very transparent about plans and problems. Only real issue I've been having is latency and performance problems while playing multiplayer, but that may be because the rest of my group is halfway across the U.S.

If there was a "neutral" option for steam reviews, I would've chosen it. Ready or Not is a successor to the iconic SWAT genre. Is it better? Ehh.

Beginning with the positives, Ready or Not's story-building is top-notch. The use of 911 calls, briefings, and other in-game things make the missions interesting and immersive to play through. Customization is also good, with the 1.0 update bringing many new weapons and cosmetic changes to your SWAT operative. You can larp as much as you want with a ballistic helmet and armor, or act as a first-responder armed with a polo and stab-vest. On the technical side, the graphics are very nice, with the general atmosphere easily conveying the theme of the map. The gun-play feels incredible, with weapons feeling like they hit hard or soft, depending on the caliber.

Now I primarily wanted to write this review to talk about the supposed "AI improvements". To some degree, the AI has been improved, particularly regarding the SWAT AI. That is to say your officers can easily clear and search rooms on their own. There's no need to go back to rooms and search for evidence, since your teammates will often times grab it for you. Moreover, you're able to mold your team in various ways, whether that be on stacking or clearing out a whole section of a map.

THE ISSUE, comes with the suspect AI, which seemed to have reverted back to their pre-August update version. To summarize, the suspect AI prior to the August update was somewhat, "aimbotty". This made a lot of missions, particularly CQC missions, incredibly annoying to finish. The AI would quickly neutralize your whole team. This AI seems to have returned with the 1.0 update. Maps such as the Post Office or the Hotel have become almost impossible due to the accuracy of the suspects. It doesn't even make sense, either. You're going up against thugs and gang members, not Tier 1 special forces teams. The 1.0 update may have made the AI even worse, because now they're usually shoot through walls and cover. The constant pre-firing and wall-banging will easily kill you or your teammates.

Now the AI wouldn't necessary be an issue most of the times. If you're lucky, you could probably clear out any map after a few tries. It's become an issue because of Commander Mode. 

In Commander Mode, you can't quickly restart missions. When your AI teammates eventually get gunned down by the John Wicks of RoN, you'll be constantly rehiring officers, unable to unlock their traits because their either always incapacitated, in therapy or dead.

I love this game, I really do. But the AI change, or rather the AI "revert", has made me so annoyed that I just can't fully recommend the game anymore. Is Ready or Not fun with friends?  Absolutely. But as a single player experience, you can't enjoy it when you're alt-f4'ing over and over again because the AI are shooting through your cover. Unless the AI is improved in the next hotfix, wait it out.

UPDATE: AI is "fixed". I'm not longer experiencing the shot through the wall situations.

EDIT: They fixed framerate so it is a recommend again =)

Been playing this game for a good while now. It's fun, intense and stressfull in an immersive way.
The game makes you feel very in the moment and connected to the events. Having completed the game once I'm now replaying it trying to S-rank each level and solo pacify every hostile with my team holding at spawn, which is not an easy task. I constantly find myself finding new ways of playing and new things you can do that I didn't realise, like commanding enemies or civs to your location instead of putting yourself in harms way to cuff someone.
At the moment of writing this, the 1.0 update did make the game a lot more laggy in some aspects. There are some rooms or areas that might start stuttering, which the devs will hopefully have fixed rather soon.

All in all it's a game I would recommend if you enjoy tactical games like the older Rainbow Six and S.W.A.T. 4. If I had to rate it I'd give it an 8/10. There are things I would absolutely change or add, but nothing that takes away the fun you can have in the game already.

I wanted to play SWAT 4 again but I’ve just bought an RTX4070.

I downloaded Ready or Not and now I can play SWAT 4 again but make use of my RTX4070!

Except that isn’t quite fair: the developers have obviously played SWAT 4 because there are lots of familiar aspects to the UI. When I played this a few months ago it was a clunky homage to SWAT 4 but there has obviously been an update recently. The AI is now very good - your squad will sort out handcuffing suspects and reporting to TOC so you don’t have to click on everyone yourself. They also make sensible decisions if they hear gunfire they investigate rather than carrying on staring at a wall while their friends get killed 3’ away. 

The mission system works really nicely now. I like the squad stress system - it means you actually care about getting your team killed and wounded, rather than being disposable NPCs in each set piece mission. The missions themselves are really well constructed as they allow you lots of tactical freedom but still manage to build up tension as you discover what the lovely wealthy mansion has behind the boiler room in the basement. 

I’m not a hardcore FPS person so can’t get carried away about the details there - it works immersively and as realistically as you would want from this game (Arma 3’s death before you hear the muzzle blast would get boring quickly here).

10/10 will panic and shoot the wrong teenager again.

I would also not be surprised if some of the suspects had a buff where they ignore damage like a real crackhead all cracked out would. But you will find that if you turn their head into a canoe they will go down quick.

It's a fun game with some tasks ahead for the devs to do further refinement which they are doing along with adding more content.

While gun-play (++), sounds (++) and graphics (+) are really decent (performance is fairly good after the latest hotfix, too), the 1.0 took away one of the most important things, that this game made stand out: it's replayability. Back during public early access, you had the option to choose from different mission types for almost all maps, like baricaded suspect, raid, active shooter or bomb-threat. With 1.0, every mission only has one missiontype of the mentioned ones, which can not be changed anymore. This may be fun for the first and, maybe, second run, but after that it become really repetitive. 
Also, while the addition of the commander mode is pretty cool, the whole stress system is pretty half-baked and rather annoying. The whole story also just ends pretty weak and it feels like, they rather wanted to push 1.0, than finish the story. A lot of the traits, that the AI officer have, do not help that much during mission either, it seems.
For whatever reason, there are also quite a few wierd "balancing" choices, like not being able to mount an Eotech, Elcan Specter or Nightforce scope on the G36, despite being possible IRL (even with the KAC rail system we have in game), not being able to run both AN/PEQ-15 and flashlight (the former also lacks it's visible laser option) or no option to equip a gasmask and NVGs at the same time (which was teased in development update #57 back in August '23).
The AI in this game is also... something. For trying to be realistic, every mission turns into a massive shootout (Youtuber "Civilian use only" talks about that part in his 1.0 review, saying, that SWAT encounter rarely turn into gunfights). Even low-level criminals have no sense of self-preservation and will shoot at you, like they are on some un-holy mission. Sure, having you go some place and only arrest suspects, that have surrendered upon SWAT arrival is pretty boring from a games perspective, but a mission or two, where it does not feel like, that you need to kill to succeed, would go a long way, cause the motto of this game kinda is "Stop the killing, stop the dying".
Anyway. I can't really recommend Ready or Not at the moment, since it just feels like a worse version, of what it was just prior the 1.0 update.

This is a SWAT game and you feel like you're in charge. The team and enemy AI is pretty good considering near limitless tactical possibilities that you can execute. Stack up on doors. Choose to stack up left or right side? Will you flash or stinger(rubber balls) grenade the room upon entering, or set up entry on 3 different doors to overwhelm the suspects? Rifle? Pistol? Flashlight on or off? Civilian? Did you order the perp to drop his piece?

 I have only played with AI team mates, but they are pretty based killing machines. Sometimes they shoot randomly at AI, and civilians, but it's not really a huge problem. It's sad when you or your squad mates die. You can spectate to see if they finish the mission, but you will likely see them fall without your tactical expertise and valor under fire. I think playing online would be cool, but I have yet to try it due to not having any friends.

 AI has a hair trigger and superhuman reflexes. Stay frosty and don't go for head shots. The perps want to kill you, and you'll always have more rules to play by than they do. "Only fools rush in", is a good reminder when opening doors. Unless you hear gunshots or cries for help, take your time. Running into trip wire is an insta-kill. You can shoot the trap or snip the wire but make sure your dudes are not near it. Very fun if you like shooting pedophiles. 

The only downside I could see is the mixed messages about conspiracy "theories". On one hand, you're supposed to shoot Q anon type dudes who are at war with the pedophile Big Brother types in government, but then you do a mission basically killing a bunch of pedophiles that are part of a huge conspiracy. Seriously, what crime is it to live out in the woods and distrust the government? Oh they shared classified documents about pedophiles in high places? Time to die rednecks! We city folk like 'em young so don't get in our way or we'll send cops to blast you. That mission was kinda silly in my estimation.

P.S. Look out for the Q-anon weirdo in the forest house who likes to hang out with his wang out. He climbs through the floor vents and cracks in the drywall (also not illegal in your own home). Very sneaky. Keep your back to the wall. Also, I felt guilty killing the 3D printer bros, but their mom has cancer (expensive) and she's old. Life is often full of sacrifice and hard choices. You can beat her or worse if she gets uppity about it. You're a COP!

If you are looking for a semi-realistic (Albeit with some liberties considering it is a video game, fun first after all) STAY AWAY FROM THIS TITLE. 

There are no aspects of this game in which it is fair on your account. Enemies will laser beam you with 7.62x39 AKM rounds while you can't keep bead with an MP5 at mid range. Enemies won't flinch when shot (Tested with .357 Magnum on suspect in apartment level.) and seemingly know where you are regardless of how fast or slow you approach certain corners.  

Armor is virtually useless as enemies tend to shoot at legs, while it is explained that certain sects of suspects ARE aware of SWAT's armor status it begs the question "Why the fuck not put armor ON YOUR LEGGIES?" 

Guns in full auto seem super inaccurate, shotguns do not have the knock down power that they should, and even when shot multiple times enemies just don't give up nor bleed out. 

There is NO safe zones, not even in spawn, as enemies can just walk up to you in spawn and blow you away. Like is there only me and the squad here? Where is like...the entire fucking department or even backup? (Officer down we need backup! TOC: Roger that, notifying the morgue, get fucked lmao.)


UPDATE: With the new update the enemy AI has gotten a little downgrade to be more manageable, which is wonderful. However four bullets don't seem to be enough to drop a suspect, or even phase them, as they zero my head and blast me like I'm an NPC in CoD. I mean, I shoot them, they flinch, but then rezero my head.

ALSO EDIT : Pistols are strangely non-lethal. A single headshot will incapacitate suspects...a HEADSHOT...tested with all semi-auto pistols. 


MORE COOL SHIT I FOUND WHILE PLAYING: Enemies don't seem to reload properly, I mean the fastest I've seen someone reload an AK I've ever seen. Sleight of Hand Pro, on the Meth they got from Twisted Nerve Mission. 


EXTRA SHIT I FOUND: Enemies that rush up to your face can shoot you for free, and you put your gun up cause realism. Can't shoot something if barrel is unable to reach target. You might think "Oh this is a good time to use Melee" you poor poor bastard, melee also doesn't work when up close. 

MORE STUFF: I am sick of shooting bad-guys once, twice, three times, an extra four and seeing them just walk backwards and keep a bead on me. 

IN CONCLUSION: This feels more like SWAT if it was made by Bennet Foddy or whatever the fuck his name was. Exceedingly unfair shit.

VOID Interactive were very close to delivering the perfect SWAT 4 succesor but the final product ended not meeting the community's expectations.
The game suffers from, i'd say, the lack of vision on expanding the content and severe technical issues that affect the players' experiencie in a negative way.

First i'll start with the positives:
+Genuinely interesting setting which is backed up by outstanding art direction and environmental story telling, i absolutely love how the missions are tied to one another in some way, 
+The maps are great, they are carefully handcrafted to provide optimal CQB scenarios.
+The core gameplay which is how you tackle missions aka lateral thinking. In difficult missions, it's critical to carefully plan out the raid taking into consideration how much of a threat the suspects are, their equipment and the design of the building, how its structured, how everything is arranged. Having these factors into account the player then chooses how to proceed with the raid, select the adequate equipment for each member of the element and the point where the team will begin the insertion.

Now, the negatives:
-The police department feels dead, empty, with no movement, none of the NPCs talk, the mission briefings could have been done in a way that feels more interactive way instead of having a white screen that pauses the game and listening to recordings.
-Lack of freedom in weapon customization which also affects they way the missions can be tackled.
-The inability to order "red" and blue" to clear rooms simultaneously without the need of looking at the doors which also severly affect your options. (so fucking retarded)
-Performance issues are somehow still a thing, there are places where the game suffers from insane FPS drops.
-They still haven't fixed the issues with the mirrors and glass, what's worse is that suspects can see you perfectly through glass doors and walls.
-Lack of animations or how i like to call it, body language, on both civilians and suspect AI, most of the time you cannot tell what they are going to do to the point that it looks and feels goofy.
-Suspect AI are straight up broken, they'll see through walls, through smoke screens, they'll arbitrarily not be affected by flashbangs or gas and the most annoying issues of them all, the absurd reaction time and accuracy they have.
-SWAT AI sometimes won't follow orders and/or move erratically, leaving openings in the formation, ironic how the suspects feel more trained than the SWAT unit sometimes.

Despite the issues that can affect the player's overall experiencie, i'd still recommend it based on the amount of fun i extracted from it due to the core gameplay. However, it was a mistake from the devs to make the "full" release since it's still clearly in a premature state, they need to listen to the player base and actually do more play testing.

best swat game ever

In the quaint coastal town of Harborview, where the salty breeze danced through the streets and the cries of seagulls filled the air, two unlikely friends embarked on an extraordinary adventure. Fynn Nebula, a seasoned sailor with a heart as vast as the ocean itself, and Miguel Hernández, a brave police officer whose unwavering determination was matched only by his warm smile, shared a bond that transcended the ordinary.

It all began on a foggy morning when news arrived of a pirate raid on a nearby merchant ship. The pirates, led by the notorious Captain Blackbeard, had taken the crew hostage, including several locals from Harborview. Fynn and Miguel, driven by a sense of duty and a desire to protect their community, knew they had to act swiftly.

With Miguel's tactical expertise and Fynn's nautical skills, the two friends devised a daring plan to rescue the hostages and put an end to the pirates' reign of terror. They gathered their supplies, their resolve as unyielding as the granite cliffs that guarded their town, and set off into the unknown.

Their journey took them across tumultuous seas and uncharted waters, their small boat slicing through the waves like a graceful seabird. As they drew closer to the pirates' hideout, Fynn and Miguel shared stories of their past adventures, their laughter mingling with the sound of the ocean's song.

But amidst the danger and uncertainty, there was something else stirring between them, a warmth that blossomed in the quiet moments between their shared glances and fleeting touches. Though unspoken, the connection between Fynn and Miguel was undeniable, a magnetic pull that drew them closer with each passing day.

As they approached the pirates' stronghold, tension hung in the air like a thick fog, but Fynn and Miguel remained steadfast in their determination to succeed. With Miguel leading the charge on land and Fynn navigating the treacherous waters, they launched their attack with precision and skill.

In a flurry of action and bravery, they fought side by side, their hearts pounding in unison as they battled against Captain Blackbeard and his crew. With every swing of the sword and every shouted command, Fynn and Miguel proved themselves to be true heroes, their bond stronger than ever in the face of danger.

And when the last of the pirates had been defeated and the hostages set free, Fynn and Miguel shared a moment of quiet reflection amidst the chaos. In the shimmering light of the setting sun, they looked into each other's eyes and saw not just friendship, but something deeper, something that had been waiting to bloom beneath the surface all along.

As they sailed back to Harborview, their hands brushed against each other, sending sparks of electricity through their veins. And though their adventure had come to an end, Fynn and Miguel knew that their journey together was far from over. For in each other's company, they had found not only courage and camaraderie, but a love that would endure even the fiercest storms.

And so, as they returned home to the embrace of their grateful town, Fynn and Miguel stood side by side, ready to face whatever adventures lay ahead, their hearts entwined as one beneath the endless expanse of the starlit sky.

as of update 1.0 hotfix 3 the game is now very playable with a lot of the bugs patched. certainty not worth 40 shillings tho. 

there is a career mode with about 18 missions for you to play through and a multiplayer mode where you can replay the missions with 12+ people (not sure what the limit is). mod support is great with just about everything being moddable although for some reason "server checksum" is enabled for everyone by default meaning if whoever is hosting never bothered to turn it off you will be automatically kicked off unless you have the same mods. the game performance has gotten better but you will still stutter at random points in the maps sometimes in the middle of gunfights and fps still doesn't go past 160 in-game. no matter the setting it always sits at 90 - 120fps at 4k, 1440p and 1080p at least for me. 

as for gameplay it has gotten a tiny itty bit better with SWAT Ai being more useful and less bothersome and suspect ai being a tiny bit fairer but still ridiculous at some points. most notably spraying you through 99% opacity surfaces like bushes, glass, railings or any extremely tiny gap with "line of sight" to you. the equivalent of being shot through a bullet hole across the map in rainbow six siege. they also can blast you at inhuman reaction times and begin to shoot the moment your playermodel is visible meaning you die before you could even see them.

at this price point I still can't recommend it. It is of better quality than a lot of the AAA dog poop that's come out through the years but a 14 shilling price bump for about 7 new missions and 2 map reworks and a few minor improvements... no.

For a 1.0 game that's about to start releasing DLCs, it's a mess. Half the menus need some serious bug fixing and actual thought put behind them. The modding scene is completely dead (and game breaking) because they chose not to use the steam workshop.

After 1.0 more of the flaws of this game came to light, the game suffers from a lack of replayability and I find myself creating challenges on my own instead of the game having interesting challenges. The game remains challenging as it always has but for all the wrong reasons, for starters the AI enemies and team need major work granted they have seen some improvements and I expect they will continue too but the over emphasis on non/less lethal gameplay ultimately harms this game with the current state of the enemies and their reactivity. There is also poor optimization throughout the game causing frame drops regularly (I run a 4070ti and i7 13700k which have no problem running other games maxed graphics I can only imagine what the state of these drops are for people with older rigs). overall I would recommend only if you're willing to stick with the game through a few updates and some dry times content wise

-- TL;DR --

Don't let this "Not Recommended" banner misinterpret my feelings towards this game; I like it a lot and have been actively following its development since I first heard about it. In it's current state though, I can't recommend it to anyone who is expecting a truly finished and fleshed out product at the price that it is being sold for. If you can get passed this, I recommend it.

-- Performance Issues --

For anyone experiencing severe performance issues and random crashing (who are not running god-tier systems) - update your video card drivers, use DirectX12, turn on DLSS balanced and lower your game settings - this helped me a lot. My friend on the other hand... let's just hope there's a hotfix in the near future that's gonna stop his game from bogging down and crashing constantly.

-- FULL REVIEW --

The game's encounter system and tactical gameplay is more akin to Rainbow Six: Vegas 2 (on the hardest difficulty) than the SWAT / OG Ghost Recon games. The enemy / team AI needs to be improved upon as some deaths / mission failures I experienced was the result of unfair encounters and inhumane reflexes all enemies have, regardless of what their experience is described to be (idk if this is intentional to mislead the player or if this was unintended programming - I'll lean more on the first option). Although, I grew to like how the buggy AI forced me to make quick decisions and improvise with the layout of the environment I was in when tackling the altercation I had with the hostile enemies. Sadly, stealth can be summarised as a bogged down experience as enemies who are half-way across the map can hear you (and even see you through obstacles) even when my gun was equipped with a suppressor. Currently you cannot you shoot out lights / kill the power when playing through the night missions (or missions occurring within buildings).

A bunch of issues that I have with this game is beautifully summarised in this 2 hour long YouTube video that I randomly came across while trying to troubleshoot my issues: https://youtu.be/c6r0cJ1wQOE?feature=shared
