I really like this game, BUT the announcement of paid DLCs right after "release 1.0" (one year of no updates, and then dev pulled the trigger to release this game.) and before the game is in a better playable state (Suspect AI, optimization) i have to warn all future buyers to reconsider their decision to purchase.


I would recommend keeping an eye on the speed of QoL updates and checking the game's state before the release of the DLC. Then check how quickly the developer can work on issues caused by new content.


Hopefully the old bugs are going to be fixed by then, but I doubt that because modders were able to fix major issues for FREE in a blink of an eye (Yes, I am looking at you Void, we have seen how many copies you sold, the game is not the cheapest one, and you are planning paid DLCs without proper maintenance of the game).

We NEED proper foundation FIRST so then the DLCs and workshop content can be built on it. The development team needs to be focused on that.

Steam Workshop is still not implemented as of the time of this review. (Which is crucial for the survival of such a game long after the developer abandons it, i.e., Arma 3, Skyrim.)

This game runs surprisingly well on the Steam Deck OLED. It froze my Steam Deck a few times, but it is playable.

TLDR: good game, bad dev decisions that lead to uncertainty about the project, better with mods.

The 1.0 release while the game should still be in alpha was the first warning sign. The DLC is the second. The third will be another price pump before they dump.

So, with a recent update changing the AI (at the least on Twisted Nerve). Its finally going in the right direction. [u]This will be updated further as I re-do several levels on my frankly dumb Solo S-rank runs of levels.[/u] But without mods for AI tweaking, it finally feels like interactions with suspects are more than "Walk in, shout (optional), see gun, get shot at, shoot suspect, cuff".
Like what I got to see was people using objects as cover. Their accuracy to hit being possible to deal with as a beanbag shotgun; But not a free win. Hell I had suspects try to walk [b]away[/b] from me without drawing their gun. Someone tried to hide underneath a wire bed in vain!

It just seemed to have make my flashbangs worse. 1/3 thrown flashes worked. Two into small rooms, one outside. Likely will go back to my gas mask and teargas 'nade strat just so I can rely on my throwables to disable.

-----(Original Review)-----
I really want to recommend it. But as it stands, the game sits in a broken state of AI. Not bug ridden, but horridly balanced. SWAT4, the game this is being a "successor" to, had more balanced AI for what was reasonable at the time. It was basic, the accuracy of the game forced you to move slowly to not hit a civvie by accident. Basic command tree for AI teammates. And a few rare sniper spots if you needed it. That was 2005, and I never felt it was unfair.

Its 8 years later. Apparently that means an immersive sim should involve really unrealistic reaction speeds and accuracy to targets you are meant to subdue. There's posters to remind you, you aren't military. Bring people in alive. But the peppergun rifles don't make their aim worse so you can actually survive. And the Beanbag gun several times on mission 2, even with a full team of AI with more LTL long-guns; Cannot get one guy with no armor to drop a gun. Tried to knock the wind out of him to stun, then two shots, three, fou- Dead.
"Well you should use your throwables!" Guess what I had the AI do when entering the room? What do you think I do when I want to do a solo run?

And that directly conflicts with the messaging police need to re-learn. Hearts and Minds, not Widows and Orphans. Even when I take anything other than one of 3 LTL primaries, I discipline my firing to be knockouts and not kills. .45 to the skull may keep myself safe; But means I failed to preserve life. The game only rewards an S rank for a perfect arrest run (that also requires to find all hidden objectives that isn't hinted at what may be important). S ranks unlocks cosmetics to help you stand out from other players. Said S rank is real hard when anything short of an AI is at 50/50 odds of dying to a new sightline.

Just use SkebbZ's [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/readyornot/mods/3169]"No Crack for AI"[/url] mod. This isn't a kind of challenge that respects you. After that, game does start to become more fun to play. And more with friends.
(Side note: Apparently the subtitles and a bunch of media is AI genned too. Is it that hard to just hire an artist? I wouldn't be surprised if the breifs are also AI voiced. Furthering the reasons why AI generated content is both a mistake and should be shamed.)

Ready or Not is like a more polished version of Zero Hour. If you enjoyed the game play to that, but wished it came with a team of 4 other lobotomized AI that get in your way like Skyrim NPC's while you're trying to fight enemies with the aim of Terminator and the durability of Robocop, then this is the game for you. Not Ready Freddy places you into the combat boots of a SWAT officer in what is basically LA and sends you on a variety of missions to "Bring Order to Chaos". This being a police sim, you aren't supposed to shoot willy nilly and are meant to take a very slow, methodical approach to combat. If you are looking for a Call of Duty esq experience, this isn't for you. 

What it does well: Graphics are great, environments are fantastically well made with environmental storytelling everywhere and some cleverly hidden jokes. Guns handle and feel satisfying and the sound design is very good. The game is very immersive thanks to the attention to detail. The story is also very dark and gritty, giving you the satisfaction of shooting pedophiles in the testicles. The ability to control the other NPC SWAT team members also makes you feel like you are fighting as part of a unit...usually. Enemy AI is also really good, sometimes a bit too good but I might also just be bad at the game. 

What needs work: 1: Quality of life features mainly. A directional hit indicator really wouldn't ruin my immersion. I think its reasonable that my highly trained SWAT team leader guy would probably know what direction he got shot from and I died many times because I lacked this critical information. 2: Better gun variety. While there are many guns in the game, they don't really feel different from each other. I never noticed it taking less shots to down a suspect with an AK than an AR despite one using a significantly larger caliber. The only guns that feel different from the rifles are the shotguns and even then all the shotguns feel the same. 3: If I have cleared all the hostiles and other mission requirements, please just let me end the level instead of wandering around for 10 minuets trying to find the last civilian that stuck their head in a toilet. It really kills the fun of clearing a level when I have to go hunt down a random civvy that I missed. 4: Please let me walk through or push a button to move my other SWAT team members. They blocked me into narrow rooms so many times but have the audacity to tell me "You're in my way." 5: If you're going to give me a timer without telling me like adding bombs to certain missions, give me a damn sprint button. I shouldn't have to waddle around the entire level hunting for explosives, let me fuckin run. 

Glitches: I didn't run into many, but I will say this. I don't mind deliberately difficult games. I like Dark Souls and other intentionally hard games. However, in exchange for harshly punishing my mistakes I expect you to not make any. It may be the lack of directional hit markers but I swear I got shot through the wall a few times. Enemy AI is a tiny bit too accurate. I understand that even a scared moron would get lucky every now and then, but when the enemy AI literally sticks its gun out from cover and manages to land half a mag into me and my team without missing, that is a load. 

Overall I would say the game is worth $30, but just barely. They claim they'll add new content and have a roadmap so I'm sure theres more good things to come. It is a very well made game with alot of attention to detail that's held back by a few poor game design choices and bugs.
Greased palms is my worst nightmare.

The most immersive tactical FPS I have ever had the luxury to put my hands on. Completed the game, currently going for S rank on all missions. Only 5 stages left to go.

Pros:
-The tactics and knowledge needed for real CQB is something you will learn quick.
-Fun as hell with a squad when everyone is taking it seriously. (Or Not)
-Large variety on weapons and loadouts.
-Satisfying when completing levels with non lethal options, forcing you think smarter and play different.
-All cosmetics are unlocked though completing stages with high rankings. You must EARN the cool stuff.
-There are some great mods to enhance your gameplay or add new maps and features.
-Tons of gunplay control. Free Leans, toggle leans, walks and strafes, ready down, free looks etc.

Cons:
-Not enough content. I've cleared all 18 maps several times, solo and with friends. I've had to resort to Mods for new maps, and zombie mode for new and challenging stuff to do. 
-The AI is sometimes too damn good. They can pre-fire to your location, often shooting through walls or objects and pixel clipping you with amazing precision and distance. I enjoy the challenge and the realism, the reaction time needed is very impressive, but sometimes downright not fair. But I guess a real gunfight would be no different.
-Your AI team will sometimes stop taking orders. Or just stop moving. Or just be in your way, not allowing you to move around. This can be improved. It's not terrible, but it is noticeable and frustrating at times.
-Finding that last damn civilian. We all been there. It sucks and is an immersion killer.

I will highly recommend for those seeking a challenging tactical SWAT FPS. Reminds me of the good ol' days of Rainbow Six on N64 or Vegas on 360. Much more impressive and difficult to master. But rewarding and fun as hell when you do.

I really enjoy this game. Even after you beat all the levels you can repeat and try for a higher score or use a different approach. Lots of cool weapons and good levels and design and options to complete levels. 

This game has so many positives I cant even list them all. Unfortunately, once you complete the Commander mode I tried to go back and complete all the levels and obtain the "S" ranking and the fact the only way to do this is to complete all main objectives (reasonable), complete all soft objectives (reasonable), have whole team survive (makes sense) but sadly where this game is completely ruined for me was needing to arrest every single hostile in the level (No kills). 

This sounds like its not an issue but sadly you've got to equip your entire team with non lethal main weapons and then remove your team members secondary ammo so they don't just pull out sidearms and blow away suspects when they need to reload in a firefight. Another thing that ruins the game is the only options for non lethal weapons are pepper ball guns and shotguns with beanbags. Both of which are awful at long range and with the pepper ball guns in hand if the enemy flanks you or you are within 10 feet of encountering them they just blast you through getting shot in the face. So basically, your only reasonable option is to run every level with the entire team with beanbag shotguns.

If you want an entry man with a tactical shield you have to remove the secondary ammo so they don't just kill everyone as they enter room which makes that one member of the team just a walking target.

I hope in the next few patches they change how the scoring is done. As real as this game is I feel like in some situations if you give a hostile multiple chances to surrender and the keep shooting at you or your team you'd be justified in shooting to kill.

I know it is possible to obtain the "S" rank even with these issues but I really ruins the game as you're limited to the weapons and tactics you use. In the later levels where you face more hostiles every level becomes the same as you've only got few tactics to take these guys down. Large rooms with multiple hostiles is basically a breach, flash bang or gas and pray the AI doesn't have god like reflexes and destroys your slow shooting beanbag shotgun team.

I'd recommend this game but obtaining 'S" rank is just too broken and not fun at all at the moment.

For lovers of the genre, the package is well-crafted overall and offers a challenging and rewarding gameplay experience, despite a few minor glitches.

I only played the game in multiplayer but i expect the same issues to be present in campain as well and therefore cannot recommand this game. If you ignore your rating and kill all sus you can have some fun with it. Otherwise you will encounter very very nasty bug - Including: Beeing seen AND shot though solid walls(no windows, no sound from us), 360° one-shots even when you were sneaking from behind, unauthorized use of force by sus vs civi while you where not even close by, weapons(evidence) glitching thou the ground resulting in a lost round because you will never geht the S rating with missing evidence. Often you clear the whole area and have to backtrack to find the soft and hard evidence you missed (if possible). Oh and never to forget the shotgun-snipers who can give you a headshot over a whole are the verymoment you peek. The game gives you 14 missions in MP after that you are done no more content. Very tricky and difficult missions true but 14 is all you get. If you ignore rating you will be done in about two play sessions. With the rating in mind we had 6 play sessions each 6-8h. But they were no fun most of the time. You are more dependent on your luck that the sus spawn good enough and your armor keeps up the protection for long enough and that no stuff glitches thou the ground or a sus stotting a civi by  accident. So yea no thx not good enough to be worth 50 bucks. Atleast they should fix those bugs then yea maybe worth 35.

The core gameplay is... good, however...
The company behind the game is god awful. 
They increased the price from £35 to £45 for '1.0' which completely broke the game for well over a month and now they're trying to sell you paid DLCs for an unfinished project. What was that extra £10 price tag for 1.0 huh? Putting DLCs before bugfixes is a terrible look for the future of your game. I hope that they'd re-add early access features like different gamemodes and maps (Carriers Of the Vine, Hide & Seek, Buy Cheap By Twice and  Wenderly Hills Hotel) however I've got a bad feeling like these devs are going to prioritise being as greedy as possible. The game has shit performance with constant stutters and frame drops and is poorly optimised. Interacting with menus freezes the game briefly for no reason and retrying a mission on Commander mode takes so much longer than it should. They removed the 'retry' button so you have to go back to the lobby, choose the mission again and then wait through 30 seconds of loading screens and pointless cutscenes. I don't know how to feel about the AI. Originally it was ridiculously overpowered with enemies locking onto you through walls and the time to kill being literal frames but now it seems like a lot of people think it's too easy post nerf. 

TL:DR - The game is enjoyable with friends but I have so many issues that I cannot give it a positive review. If you have a spare £45/$60 lying around (will increase AGAIN soon depending on how much they charge for the DLC which should have been part of the base game) then go ahead and buy it. You'll probably like it but you'll also see what I mean with its flaws very quickly.

amazing

//Update:
So, they're not fixing the absolute fluster cluck of a game they released (their 'hot fixes' are anything but hot fixes and have failed to address anything in any reasonable sense), instead they're working on paid DLC to add a few maps in, baring in mind they REMOVED a butt load of content just before release. Money before fixes. Devs are an absolute joke. Do not buy this game and avoid all of their future works.

Everything below still stands.//

------

Well, this was most disappointing. Where do I start? 

The obvious place to start is with the cracked-out super human AI. We've waited over a year with zero updates to the game, running on the promise that release of 1.0 would address most of the problems with the AI. Has it? Has it F..... It's somehow gotten worse, and it was utterly abysmal before! The AI reacts in times faster than the Human eye can send a signal to the brain and have the brain process it, and that's without thinking about how to respond, that's just receiving the visual information. It's a joke and the devs are a joke for thinking this is in anyway realistic, or more importantly, fun. But that's not even the worst part. 

They also have X-Ray vision (cue Mack's X-Ray vision song), and will pre-fire you as you're about to round corners or whilst you're behind solid objects that the devs forgot to set as solid objects (the AI can see through several objects, including pallet stacks and concrete blocks). Yeah, we all love playing against wall-hackers in multiplayer games, so lets introduce it to this single/co-op player game! I've been shot through walls, through floors, through ceilings and even loaded into a level to have all the AI just stood unloading at the spawn area. I didn't get hit and they stopped after a little while, but it did amuse me. 

//Update: The devs openly admit that the wall hacking AI is deliberate to give an element of challenge. Yeah, they suck so much at developing games that they have to make the AI wall hack to make it challenging. Absolute DISGRACE. This makes the next paragraph even more important.//

All the fun AI behaviours they claimed they were adding and which are touted in the 'release trailer' simply aren't there. The AI has one mode: Terminator. Think you're going to peek them, ask them to drop their weapon, watch them hesitate and back up? Maybe they will offer some interesting situations that require you to stop and think about how to respond? No chance. If they even get a hint of you being there then it's full on suicide mode, running at you unloading all their ammo (which is infinite by the way. Yeah, the devs gave the wall hacking AI an infinite ammo cheat). It isn't fun, or engaging. You're simply reduced to grenade cheesing tactics or playing through it like a CoD game, neither of which this game was advertised as, or excels at.

Next up, they removed a load of content. All the fun game modes that they had for the maps have gone, replaced by one singular game mode for that map. Some of the maps had alternate builds, like the hotel or park homes, they're gone. Granted, they've added a few extra levels, but they've removed more than they've added, and they've removed a massive amount of replayability with it. Also, the randomisation seems to have been significantly toned down. Now, replaying the levels, I know roughly where each target will be. I know that there's a civi behind that door without even having to open it. This wouldn't be such a problem if they hadn't removed all the extra modes, but here we are.

The new Police HQ is nice, utterly pointless, but nice. The firing range is... a wasted opportunity? You can bring targets up and down the range and shoot them, inspect the spray patterns, but you can't replace the target, so once it's used, it's rather useless until you reload the level. Could just use another lane, except, each lanes target is a different distance away. Why can't I just interact with the guy sitting at the side and have him change all the targets, i.e./ remove all the bullet hole decals?

Speaking of interacting, there's precisely eff all to do in the station. It's basically a 3D menu, but instead of being able to click, you have to run around at the speed of asthmatic snail. You can't interact with any of the very few characters that are in there, they don't ever say anything or do anything. They just sit there, like weird dolls who track your movement with their heads when you get too close. It's all very odd and an absolute waste of time, space and resources. 

Oh! The one thing you can interact with is the evidence room. You can go and look at some 3D models of items that are for the most part, utterly irrelevant to the cases you've worked on. "This a anime model, only 50 were ever made. Lots of DNA present, wear gloves lul lul lul" Yeah, we get it, the streamer is a perv and spaffed on the toy... Great, why do I need to be able to spin that around? How about letting me look through those chat logs from his computer? Or check his emails and piece together who this guys contacts were? Nah, that's interesting, we don't do interesting, we do EdGy! "LUL LUL LUL! Spunk!!"

So, the police station is an absolute wash. A dull, boring box that they force you to jog through after every level. At this point, just give me a damn menu! It takes long enough to get into a level, without having to do a cardio session before!

Speaking of level loading, loading a level from an SSD is about 9 seconds, not bad. Loading a level from a HDD is about 22 seconds for me (yeah, I moved the install to test). So why do I have to sit through a 10 second count-down AFTER the loading? It's obviously not hiding extra loading, as the timer never changes. So before each level starts, you have a 10 second countdown after everyone's hit "Ready-Up". Cool, you then have to load, that's another 9 seconds from my SSD, you then have ANOTHER 10 second countdown. So they've artificially extended their load times to almost (or even over) 30 seconds? I don't even have the words... Why would anyone do this? Also, anything over 15 seconds to get into a game is too long if you ask me. Back in the PlayStation days, yeah, fine. Now, with current hardware, no, get out. And it's not like the stupid 10 second countdown of watching the team in the back of the van adds anything. Nothing happens and it's the exact same animation on a loop. Why can't that play WHILST the game is loading? Instead of the black screen? And then you have to do that every time you start a map, after you've trudged what feels like 10km across the barren wasteland that is the pointless boring Police Station 3D menu.

That was a lot of words... And we've not even gotten onto the performance...

Performance is, well, it's fine for me for the most part. Playing on High settings @ 1440p FSR on getting a normally solid 165fps with v-sync on. Specs are: 
Ryzen 9 3900x 12-Core @ 3.80GHz; Radeon RX 5700XT 8GB; 32GB RAM.
I do get some frame drops on initial level load. I just spin around in a circle for a couple of seconds whilst the game finished loading everything in, something it apparently can't do whilst showing me that GOD DAMN VAN ANIMATION FOR 10 SECONDS!.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game. It's a chore to play, has little replayability, doesn't play anything like its scripted trailer would have you believe and simply isn't worth the price they are asking for. The devs utter refusal to fix the god awful AI is my biggest reason for not recommending this game though. It's not "hard", it's frustrating, boring and easily cheesed once you've figured out the gimmicks. I wanted an engaging SWAT game, not a shoot 'em up or cheese 'em up, but that's what they delivered, after a year of zero updates. This game isn't out of Early Access and isn't worth the money they're asking for.

Do you value your money? Do you work hard every day to fill your bank account with hard-earned cash? VOID Interactive doesn't value your money. VOID feels that backer's money is best spent squandered on physical advertising, renting the rights to put decals on public transportation and to put up billboards. That same money could have been spent on hiring competent artists and coding staff to improve their game. Instead, VOID opted to incredibly poorly implement AI art and cheapen their own product, and not even bother trying to improve their abysmal AI that they were aware of a YEAR before the "full release" of Ready or Not. "1.0" was a half-assed atttempt to grab the money of everyone interested in this game but wasn't confident in spending cash on an early access title. Ready or Not isn't completed, is in dire need of reworking and polishing, and is a laughable product. I'm angry I backed this title, and I want my hard-earned money back.

Very good game, gunplay feels excellent and the wide assortment of gadgets and utility offer many playstyles. However, I get quite a few performance issues running this game with my setup (RTX 3070 TI, AMD Ryzen 9 6900) on low-medium settings and cannot maintain a stable 120 FPS. If the graphics are optimised more I can wholeheartedly recommend this game.

The issue of a co-op hardcore paid FPS also stands: it is relatively easy to convince yourself to shell out 50 bucks for this game. It is harder to convince three other friends to shell out 50 bucks as well so you don't have to deal with randoms on the internet. The bots are surprisingly good but unless you set them up by flashing or stunning the suspects they tend to go "no russian" on the room.
Controller support is horrid and the text is impossible to read. Refunding for now until these issues are addressed

Extremely lazy devs. People been complaining for years about the AI having unrealistic aim and reflexes, and being able to see you through a lot of walls. On top of that tons of bugs that were unaddressed since the ALPHA. Modders fix it with a couple of script tweaks, something the devs fail to be able to do within multiple years. Then they release the game in this obviously unfinished state, despite these issues being present and complained about for literal years, showing a lack of care for feedback. Then charge 50 bucks for a game with worse AI than Swat 4, a two decade old game.

The foundation of this game is amazing, and in the early access I highly recommended it, but I now that this game had it's full release I can no longer excuse the bugs and poor AI. If you're planning to play this with Friends, get the AI Overhaul mod. 

But I'm reviewing the game here, not a mod, and to put it simple, the vanilla unmodded game is a completely unenjoyable experience after the first few levels in the current version of the game as of writing, and does not represent the realistic Police experience of trying to de-escalate situations and "bringing order to chaos" that was originally envisioned and advertised for the game, and instead brings a robotic, unimmersive experience that is more akin to playing Rainbow Six Siege against a team of wallhackers that requires you to . It shouldn't be put on to modders to fix a 50$ title for the devs, while not getting a single cent. 

[b]Edit:[/b] [u]The Developers just announced 2 paid DLCs coming this year without addressing the AI issues that make the base game borderline unplayable beyond the first couple missions. [/u]

I'm beginning to think this entire deal with asking people to buy their supporter edition so they can get enough funds to finish the game has just been one giant scam from the start and they never actually intended to fix any issues. Personally, VOID made sure I'll never buy an Early Access title ever again.

I really enjoy playing this game. The devs have done an amazing job making it feel super realistic and tactical. The animations and gunplay are top tier for realistic combat. 

The PvE feels very balanced, since you can get domed by the AI just as easily as you can drop them, which gives the game a bit of a challenge and feels authentic at the same time. 

The non-lethal mechanic is unique and a lot of fun to play with to try and get a high score. It is fun that you have the option to either go in hot or try to minimize casualties with non lethal/ low caliber weapons. 

The replayability can sometimes be a bit of a challenge, but new content keeps this game fresh and honestly, if I just wait a week or two, I feel like I can totally play the same missions again. 

It's just a lot of fun, and if you have a couple friends to play with, its just a great game to mess around in and have some fun. Would certainly recommend.

I wish this game was a good successor to SWAT 4, but it's genuinely a mess in a lot of ways.

The tone of the levels are all over the place. The first level is just a basic gas station robbery gone wrong, immediately followed up by the second level being based on swatting, except there's no moral ambiguity and the streamer is comically evil. get this on sale for 25 or less if you have friends to play with, and expect to do some assembly with roe, removing shaders and reworked a.i.

A.I
at base state the game's a.i. is pretty clunky, lacking logic sometimes, superhuman reaction times (vanilla is 0.2sec irc, average human is around 0.25), x-ray vision(confirmed in replay mode) and the ability to shoot any calibre of round through almost any surface (the player doesn't receive the same penetration chance as the a.i., not even close.).

Graphics
I highly recommend any mod that removes the shaders and post processing, a nice performance bonus, the game will no longer look dirty and hazy, a genuine graphic improvement.

ROE
the base ROE is a little obtuse, and if you want those S ranks give up on playing how you want or trying out any other weapons, its beanbags and spice balls for you. they couldn't think of a way to make the roe fun AND challenging, but modders did.

Final comments
>A lot of people also have very bad performance issues because this game is pretty horribly optimised, be sure to turn of world decals AND replays if you get bad stuttering.
>At least void made modding easy, these fixes will take all of 30 secs to apply, guess if you can't do the work at least make outsourcing it easy.
>gunfighter mods are also strongly recommended because of the fixed damage profiles and minor gameplay and QOL changes.
>don't buy this full price, and honestly wait for void to rework the a.i.

Don't get me wrong - the 1.0 release of this game is pretty fun. With enough playtime, you too will grow to appreciate the solid shooting mechanics and expertly crafted level designs as the game desperately tries to click through the slideshow fast enough for you to react to the suspects trying to shoot at you. My lord, does this game tank in performance if you so much as look at a room the wrong way. Chances are the first few hours of your experience in this game will be spent troubleshooting to get it running just well enough to play, and even then, the game just does not perform very well on all maps no matter what you do. Besides that, the game is just flat out buggy and evidence will often glitch through the floor, bodies will ragdoll into walls, the audio will cut out, and the AI will do its fair share of questionable things. I like this game, but huge disclaimer, its only fun with friends that dont care about getting good ranks in missions as the game will do everything in its power to rob you of getting a good score.

Do you want to know how it FEELS to fight United States Delta Squad?

You will. 

You will enjoy this wonderful experience time and time again.

You might have mistaken this game to be a S.W.A.T. simulator - it is not. It's a Spec Ops simulator, but you are the terrorist. 

EVERY enemy has a shoulder mounted anti-materiel rifle that can penetrate wood, scrap metal, steel and Chobham tank armour plates. EVERY enemy has a neural implant that gets a data stream from a F.L.I.R.-enabled drone in the sky, streaming your position 24/7. EVERY enemy has a Type IV (NIJ Standard) armor vest. 

If you think that what is described above is an exaggeration, I welcome you to search "ready or not blind firing ai" on YouTube to see the nano-augmented crackhead AI shoot through SEVERAL walls, BLIND FIRING AT YOUR EXACT POSITION. Unfortunately sometimes they do manage to penetrate your skull this way, which, for those of us that have anger management issues, might result in the annihilation of all nearby electronics, furniture, walls and living beings.

But I digress, for enough has been said. 

If you enjoy having your skin removed from your face by U.S. Crack Forces, you will thoroughly enjoy this game. If not, go play S.W.A.T. 4 - at least in that game you don't play as Osama Bin Laden.

Gritty, engaging, realistic. Supporter edition review- I absolutely love this game. It is by far my favorite fps, as I prefer a slower, more methodical approach to video games. Combined with dishing out some justice to these absolute monsters, and the very immersive gameplay, Ready or Not never fails to immerse me in the situation. The guns are the best handling and most true to life interpretation of any I've ever seen in a video game. Like reality, they're loud, punchy, and when correctly handled, are faithful to their real life counterparts. This game is not all sunshine a rainbows, however, as there are some fairly significant performance issues and it definitely will struggle with replayability down the line. I would have also liked for some more variety in the voice acting, notably when reporting soft objectives, as it would better suit the atmosphere. "Bagging evidence" and "Collecting" just doesn't quite cut it for the fairly large of amount of soft objectives you will have to report manually. However, other than this, the sound design (especially the guns) is quite immaculate and I eagerly await the full soundtrack release. While the 1.0 release had a less than ideal launch and reception, I am very confident in VOID's ability to patch it up and make the game a masterpiece. This game is definitely worth the buy, should you have the itch for a realistic fps.

I had a blast playing this game and I would highly recommend if you are looking for:

1. A realistic shooter: There is very little arcadey-ness in this game. The shooting mechanics are solid, sound design is pretty solid, you have bullet drop and other realistic details such as the actual hit is different from where the reticle is aimed because of the fact that the bullet actually simulated from the barrel. 

2. CQB first: This game is all about CQB. There are very few long range battles. Its all tight spaces, corners , hallways. 

3. Realism and vibe: Its amazing how well this game makes you feel the situation. The stress of distinguishing a non combatant from a combatant where bullets are flying, rules of engagement, the ...feel of being in an active shooter situation or entering into a place where people have been upto some heinous sh!t. With every mission the environment tells a story and I personally enjoyed the level design a lot. 

4. Multiplayer:
This game is best enjoyed with friends and the I havent encountered a lot of issues setting up a lobby and running missions. If you are running mods make sure you both have IDENTICAL mods. 

Some issues:

This mainly comes down to AI. Enemy AI can be a bit wallhack, 360 no scope good and I have seen my friendly AI just stand in a door and eat shotgun shells. Its a bit jank but the mods can make it quite alright. 

In Multiplayer occasionally the game will crash and on a good run that sorta sucks.

[h1]Early Access, Now Full Release[/h1]
The game is no longer in Early Access and so will be judged as a complete game ought to be.

[h1]Content[/h1]
More maps as compared to Early Access; however, the different game modes were removed.  Not a huge deal considering most of the other game modes were largely irrelevant.  Some of the objectives like bomb diffusing were incorporated into the missions.  There are a decent number of different weapons, but you will quickly find the differences to be negligible.  Single player aspects are slap-dash and tacked on.  Overall, decent amount of content for the price, but not amazing.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
The shooting is fun and responsive.  When things work or you use mods to correct the numerous issues, you can find yourself having a lot of fun.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
There are a LOT of problems with the game.  For a release game, it is not great.

[u]The lobby system[/u] 
The new headquarters is fine, but the readying up is less painful than EA yet still distinctly terrible.  If at least 50% of the players ready-up then a 2 minute counter starts.  If 100% of players ready-up, there is a 10 second counter.  Once the counter reaches 0, the game loads the mission selected.  2 minutes does not sound terrible until you run into it constantly and you wish it were 1 minute or less.  Once you get your weapon loadouts set up, it takes mere seconds to switch between them, thus 2 minutes is extreme overkill.

[u]Pre-Mission screen[/u] 
This is the screen AFTER loading the map that simply shows your officer and him riding in the van.  It serves absolutely no purpose as you can do nothing in this phase.  It simply is a 10 second countdown for nothing.  Time waster.  Supposedly, there will be a planning phase, but it makes no sense to leave this vestigial section in just to waste time.  This sections remains unchanged from my EA review because nothing changed.  It is stupid and should be removed.

[u]Modifying loadout[/u]  
This section also has not changed since EA.  It is terrible and needs major help.

This can only be accomplished in the "headquarters" lobby and no where else.  In a mission?  Too bad.  Pre-mission screen? Nope.

The actually process of modifying your loadout is an example of terrible UI.  So much wasted space and unintuitive design.  Select the weapon on the far left then click a small modify attachment button on the far right.  What is the middle for?  Displaying useless models of course.  

What do attachments do?  Small info box that tells you + or - to some attribute.  How much does each attachment modify that attribute?  Doesn't tell you.  You have to test each weapon + attachment individually.  

[u]Controls[/u]  
Many of the standard key bindings make no sense and require you to fix them.  New players constantly have to ask how to turn on their own weapon light etc.

[u]Weapons[/u]
Weapon damage is only differentiated by caliber and nothing else.  Ignore any and all flavor text.  You quickly realize there is no point in bringing submachine guns as their damage is simply inferior.  Within assault rifles, 99% of them are pointless since the only remaining differentiation is the recoil pattern so you select the best recoiling gun per caliber and you are done.  Also AP vs JHP ammo is still essentially meaningless.

[u]Bugs[/u] 
Still have a lot of crash to desktops post-EA.  Good to see the issue made it to release.

[u]AI[/u]  
The AI is still incredibly poorly scripted and broken.  Their most recent "hotfix" after two months since release was a simple config file number adjustment.  The kind of thing that mods did days after release.  There are 3 major issues with the AI that require fundamental mechanics changes.

[b]Vision[/b] is a major problem since enemies appear to have 270 degree vision.  It is silly, but compounded with the other problems it become ridiculous.

[b]Detection[/b] is the next major problem.  If an enemy so much as see a pixel of your body they instantly recognize you, count you as "seen" (this is a huge problem as described below), and shoot at you.  Given their near 0ms response times, it is annoying.

[b]Wall hacks[/b] is the last major problem.  The developers wanted to make things more interesting by having suspects shoot at you and your general area.  It as a flavor of realism where if a suspect sees and you move behind a wall or into cover they will shoot at that area to try and hit you through it.  Good to go right?  Except they took the laziest approach by simply giving the suspects your exact location, aka wall hacks, to accomplish this.  This means once their supervision + immediate detection kicks in, you are "seen", thus the suspect can track you through any wall for a few seconds and land perfect headshots as if they are Neo seeing through the matrix.  This is not some advanced predictive algorithm, it just gives the AI your location absent vision or any audio cues.

All this is terrible enough, but the AI's vision is not impeded by anything.  As long as an object is not considered a hard vision block, then their line of sight will go through it despite it being opaque.  Examples: CS gas clouds - you can not see through it, but because its not a hard wall, the AI can and will shoot you as if it does not exist.  Dirty window that you can not see through, AI can and will blast you.  Tall grass concealing you, guess again.

This gives an overall very poor experience while playing.

[h1]Summation[/h1]
I gave this game too much credit in EA.  The release version is a bit of a joke and is definitely not worth the asking price.  Maybe on a [b]STEEP[/b] discount, then it would be worth a look.  I hope they actually fix it, but considering the level of effort from EA to now in the critical aspects of the game, I would not hold my breath.

Ready or Not is the tactical shooter I've been waiting for! As a long-time fan of the genre, I can confidently say that VOID Interactive has delivered an exceptional gaming experience that surpasses my expectations.

The attention to detail in Ready or Not is outstanding. From the realistic environments to the meticulously crafted weapons, every element contributes to creating an immersive and intense atmosphere. The game's emphasis on realism elevates the tactical gameplay, making every decision crucial and every encounter pulse-pounding.

The single-player campaign is engaging, with a well-crafted narrative that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The AI is impressive, providing a challenging and dynamic experience that keeps you on your toes. The cooperative multiplayer is where Ready or Not truly shines – coordinating with friends or other players adds a whole new layer of strategy and excitement.

The customization options for loadouts and gear are extensive, allowing players to tailor their experience to their preferred playstyle. The attention to authenticity, including realistic SWAT tactics and equipment, adds a level of immersion that is hard to find in other games of this genre.

The developers are actively involved in the community, listening to player feedback and consistently providing updates to enhance the overall experience. It's evident that VOID Interactive is committed to delivering a polished and refined product.

In conclusion, if you're a fan of tactical shooters and crave a realistic and immersive gaming experience, Ready or Not is a must-play. It sets a new standard for the genre, and I can't wait to see how the game evolves with future updates. Bravo, VOID Interactive!

I feel that I should mention that this game is still new and the devs are actively patching issues as the find solutions, so anything I say in here is subject to change.

I cannot in good conscience recommend this game in its current state.

There are a very long list of issues ranging from graphical performance to enemy and ally AI, all of which frequently compound together to utterly ruin the experience.

Perhaps the biggest issue I have with this game is the aforementioned AI. As of the date that I'm writing this, enemy AI have unreasonably fast reactions and can also track and shoot you through walls before they ever get a line of sight on you to confirm you are there. The enemy AI also doesn't seem to make any distinction between visual and auditory detection of the player, so an enemy hearing you is effectively as good as them seeing you through walls.

Enemy bullets also seem to more consistently penetrate walls than player bullets do. I can' count how many times I tried to hit an enemy through a plaster wall or plywood board, only for my bullets to be stopped dead while the enemy then shot and killed me directly through that same material. In extreme cases, I've seen the AI shooting through multiple walls to hit me an my squad-mates from two rooms over. Enemies also can and will shoot you through the tiniest gaps instantly if they can get line of sight on you through them, and enemy accuracy is ludicrously precise across the board.

Your squad-mate AI is also frequently unreliable. Most of my squad-mate deaths were the result of them standing around staring slack-jawed at an enemy right in front of them for 3-5 seconds while said enemy was filling them with lead. I've had other instances where squad-mates simply refused to follow given orders or got stuck of doors or terrain when moving to new positions. 

The AI behaviors have a massive impact on the core experience of a game like this, so when absurd things like what I mentioned above are happening on a regular basis (often multiple times per mission) the whole experience becomes an exercise in frustration because you feel as if you have no actual influence over the situations the game puts you in.

Ready or Not is an intense tactical shooter that puts you in the shoes of a SWAT officer. The game offers a thrilling experience, with its realistic graphics and immersive gameplay. As you navigate through different scenarios, you'll need to use your skills and tactics to take down dangerous criminals and rescue hostages.

One of the things I love about Ready or Not is the attention to detail. Everything from the weapons to the maps is meticulously designed, making each level feel like a real-life SWAT operation. The game also features a wide range of weapons and gear to choose from, allowing you to customize your loadout to suit your playstyle.

The AI in Ready or Not is also impressive. Criminals will react realistically to your movements and tactics, making each encounter feel unique and challenging. The game also allows you to play with friends in co-op mode, which adds another layer of excitement to an already thrilling experience.

Overall, I would highly recommend Ready or Not to anyone who loves tactical shooters. The game offers a level of realism and immersion that is hard to find in other games. Whether you're playing alone or with friends, you're sure to have a blast taking down criminals and saving hostages in this intense and thrilling game.

[h3] Good but far from perfect [/h3]

Overall, Ready or Not is an awesome experience and I love playing it. The weapons feel amazing and realistic, also you can choose from a huge arsenal of weapons. There are many shotguns, rifles and submachine guns you can choose from. From an loved HK416 A5 to a classic MK18 Mod 1 to a M1014 to even a P90 or a legendary MP7, gun enthusiasts will have a lot of fun with the guns in the game. One more positive aspect of the game that I have to point out is the immaculate design of the many different maps in the game. The QCB encounters are in lot of moments of gameplay a quick test to your reaction time and your ROE. I do have some criticism about the suspects AI, which is not really realistic. I favor it to be more realistic, like in real life, even the most trained shooters can have a hard time hitting their shots due to the according situation and ofcourse, adrenaline. What I think is that the developers of the game tried to make it more of a challenge to beat the game, rather than just being a simple "SWAT Simulator". And this is why I am still recommending the game, even if the AI can be a pain in the ass. And the reason why, is that because this game is PC exclusive, so anyone has the ability to create or download modifications of the AI. So if you do not like the extremely strong AI, you can easily install a mod. I can understand the developers decision to want to make it a more "excruciating" experience to engage in a gunfight. But I can also understand the criticism of the playerbase that want a more realistic or casual experience. The game is gorgeous at what it is trying to be, but in my opinion, it could be so much more. The reason why I am still recommending the game, is that it has just left the early access and I have trust in the developers that there will be more content in the future.

This here's gonna be a fairly simple review.

Overall I liked the game very much. It was just the right level of challenging without being impossible. The level of tactical teamwork you can achieve with your AI teammates or friends is fantastic. Even though I play with an Xbox Series X controller, the controls were pretty good for not having native controller support. Steam's input mapping helped a lot with that. I downloaded a community created control scheme, tweaked a few in-game binds to be more in-line with how I prefer to play an FPS, and it was almost like the game actually had native support. The AI teammate controls leave a lot to be desired on a controller but given that there's no native support for controller to begin with, I can look past that. I just hope that if or when native controller support comes, Void creates a good and intuitive control scheme for AI commands.

Now my issues with the game: In the early access period you could replay missions with different modes and starting locations. In 1.0, you cannot. This completely destroys replay value in my honest opinion. My friends and I beat the game. Now there's nothing to do but replay the same missions over and over again in the same exact manner as the first time, with the only difference being [i]maybe[/i] different enemy spawns and some traps on doors. I have not beat the game in singleplayer. I am up to the last mission in singleplayer but it's going to be the exact same experience as it was in co-op with the only exception being I won't have my friends along this time. Effectively, this game is now dead for me and my friends until more content is released or the ability to replay the missions on different modes and with different starting points is returned.

The game does have Mod.io support, so my friends and I could download new missions/maps to play, but a game should not rely on mods to keep it going. Mods are meant to be an expansion of gameplay. Not to be the main source of new content.

Overall, the game is a solid 7.5/10. The lack of replay value kills it for me the most. If you get the game, play it in singleplayer with the AI first, then replay it with friends. At least that way, you get some semblance of replay value as the experience is a little different.

The game is very good, but I have suggestions for it if I play with my friends. The number of people is four or three. My suggestion is that you add the option of adding an artificial intelligence player in order to increase the number of players. My second suggestion is that you delete the system of slaughtering your companion in the game.
The last suggestion is that the transition to the map in the game should be that we drive the car ourselves and direct the location so that it is more realistic, and that they increase the lighting of the game because it is very light, and add a multiplayer system. We are SWAT, and the front one is the criminal, and he changes every turn. Thank you.

Although the 1.0 release was rough, the developers have ironed out the worst of the issues present at launch. While the game is far from perfect, it is very, very fun. My favorite parts of the game are
1. The gunplay. The gunplay aims (ha) to be very realistic and hits the bullseye. One of my favorite things is that there are two ADS modes: Conventional and Canted. This allows you to decide when you ADS whether you want more accuracy and stability or a less obstructed view. The gunplay is well complimented by the size and variety of the arsenal. The arsenal contains Shotguns, Automatic Rifles, and SMGs; with the rifles and SMGs including a wide variety of calibers.
2. The graphics. This game went for a very realistic style of graphics with a variety of lighting environments and accomplishes them all very well.
3. The variety of the maps. Very few of the maps are alike and none of them are too similar to one another. Every map presents an engaging and challenging environment.
4. The tactics. While gunplay is where Ready or Not shines the brightest, the tactical intensity is why I've poured so many hours into this game. Running and gunning like CoD will not work. This game asks the player to make tactical decisions constantly. It is up to the player to bring order to chaos and save as many lives as possible.
 
The suspect AI make or break SWAT sim type games. We as players expect them to act realistically: to place some value on their own lives rather than just be robots for the player to cut down. The AI in Ready or Not, I would say, accomplish this sufficiently. Although improvements can still be made, the developers have clearly put in the work to make the AI opponents varied and engaging.
 
Some miscellaneous pet-peeve issues I would like to see addressed, however, are:
•Weapon descriptions consist of a vague 1-2 sentence summary. These should at the very least be updated to include barrel or weapon length since your gun gets pushed aside and unusable when close to walls/objects. Muzzle velocity would also be helpful for comparing weapons.
•Shouting for compliance makes your aim dip substantially. If you're aiming at someone's chest, pressing the shout for compliance button dips your aim all the way below their feet momentarily and then back up. It would make some sense if shouting slightly destabilized your aim but the current system just makes no sense.
 
The developers have clearly put a lot of work into Ready or Not and have shown they are willing to put in the work to continue to improve their game. I wholehearted recommend this game to any shooter fan and I'm very excited to see what the future holds for Ready or Not.

I saw the reviews about the AI in this game and i was worried about it being unreasonably hard. Thankfully Void fixed the AI. After beating all 18 missions, and getting an average B score on most maps after a few attempts. And S score on the easier maps(using non-lethal). I think the game is currently in a good state. This will probably change, Good things don't usually last. But i hope this does, hopefully Void will continually update this game and add new content. One last note, the AI can still kill you very quickly. They no longer 360 John Wick you, at least in my experience. But it is still best to take your time through the each level. If your using AI teammates tell them what to do. Let them help clear rooms, if you don't give them commands they just watch your back. Sometimes not all that good. But can help in certain situations. If you read this whole review, thank you. This is my first time writing a steam review, sorry if it's a bit all over the place. And for any grammar mistakes. I don't really care how this looks lol.

I do enjoy this game, but right now I would not recommend it due to how buggy the game is and the lack of implemented features. For example, in the nightclub mission, there are suspects with suicide vests, and they are almost impossible to get to comply if you're trying to use nonlethal means. Another issue is suspects shooting you through the smallest cracks and somehow spotting you from downstairs while you are a floor above them. Then there are complaints and balancing around the suspect AI difficulty being either too hard or too easy - it was just recently toned down to make it more forgiving. One feature that could fix this is a difficulty slider, allowing players to adjust the AI difficulty to their preference, whether it's an easy setting or a challenging one where suspects react quickly and accurately.

It's a fun, semi-tactical shooter with decent AI compatriots that impressively follow orders, usually.  I've never played multiplayer so single player is my only experience.

I just finished the game before the recent 02/2024 "enemy Nerf" patch came in and I do agree it definitely dumbs down the opposition, but I see why the devs implemented it.  They have to make money and a "John Wick" enemy is not going to attract new players that aren't accustomed to Hardcore Games.  That being said, I do miss the cold, heart-racing experience of busting open a door with the team knowing that absolute Hell might be on the other side.  That's now gone.

Either way, I've enjoyed the 86 hours I've played and plan to continue more.
love this game but some times i rage

I have been playing this game since early access and must admit it has gone far and has imrpoved a lot. Since 1.0 the game has definitely gotten way better in terms of maps, gameplay and progression. First of all I loved all the new and reimagined maps and most of all I loved the way that the devs took the old maps and either gave them a new layout or gave them some new lore so that they are more interesting. They did that especially well with carriers of the vine and hide and seek. Moving on into gameplay I think it is definitely improved but its had some issues, the game is in most aspects better, both enemies and friendlies, they have gotten smarter and more "predictable" in the sense that they do not do random stuff for no reason like before. But I feel that the devs lowered the bots difficulty way too much, before and during actual 1.0 patch they were too hard, the infamous 360 one taps were still happening and a lot of bots could kill you in really unfair ways but I feel that this newest patch that changed suspect ai lowered the bar too much. Before I would take at least 5 tries to finish a level and would still get a B or a C but now its ridiculous I have just finished a level like Brisa Cove while going in solo and using less than lethal weapons in 1 try with little effort or struggle like I would before the last suspect ai patch. Which brings me to progression, I love the new progression system and think it is a great fit into the gamebut the lowered difficulty with the new patch has destroyed the fun for me a little bit. It has stopped being about "can i really finish this level with a B?" and it has changed into "am I patient enough to  clear rooms and neutralize potatos with guns for 20 mins until the game says its enough" and i can get the cosmetics i want. I understand the community was very vocal against the suspect ai but i feel like this game has lost a bit of its "hardcore" feel and its brutality but other than that I love this game.

Review of 1.0

The game's AI has been massively overhauled;

The SWAT AI has been made incredibly competent, except for 1-2 situations where they acted stupid, I can easily say that the SWAT AI is better at the game than the player, they will maintain formations, search rooms, deploy items when requested and breach & clear rooms with a very appropriate stacking up and flowing in process according to what the player specifies.

The suspect AI has finally been made deeper than a shallow puddle, the AI is no longer super predictable as it was in the pre-release. AIs now have better morale system and react to deployed gadgets and situations more accurately, this leads to more AI surrendering in appropriate situations or taking advantage of confusions better to screw over the player. 

The suspect AI has also been adjusted to fit the context of levels better, in the 1st episode the AI will be drug addicts robbing a store, they are irrational and will throw themselves to the player and have a moral more easy to break, whereas the later levels where you encounter more trained individuals they will not lose composure as easily, they will keep calm, even when they realize that you have breached another room they will generally remain in defense and not run towards your squad mindlessly.

Here are some cons:

-The eligibility for S rank is still boring, it is very difficult to reliably get individuals to surrender without less lethal options, you can shoot a guy 4 times in the leg and they might still try to kill you after recovering. To to get an S rank you must arrest every single suspect. The less lethal options in the game are incredibly boring to use, while this serves as a "challenge for those who want it." The main issue with this is that getting an S rank should be a fun and challenging process as opposed to just being a total chore.

-Cosmetic unlocks are lame and can be tedious to unlock.

-Officer morale, basically depending on what happens in a mission the AI will have a varying mental state, if it deteriorates further after the AI is already in a crisis, they will resign even if they survive a mission. 
I think this system is bad. For a lot of missions because it essentially makes it so that your only viable options are less lethal for officer mental health, I can't say that the system is very well thought given that the game provides you with an entire armory to use only to limit it to less lethal, especially considering there are tens of attackers that don't hesitate to gun you down on later levels.

This game, you need friends.

So Much better then with bots, I almost found myself Never touching the game again unless we played.

The games a tactically-slow-paced, high quality intense-styled shooter.
Where you infiltrate high risk environments for a matter of many tasks, depending if its, hostage rescue, search and destroy,  or a raid, among other things.

The loud outs give you a fair amount of freedom, you can customise your gear, vests everything and clothing,

After the new update, you can now select pants, vests, shirts, tattoo's, vocals, everything. 


The games unforgivingly brutal if you play it like an arcade, you'll be killed, or severely injured depending on how you approach situations, and depending on your awareness of your surroundings, therefore making it a solid realism-based tactical shooter, with unforgiving physical health elements, You have controlled supply so you need to be aware of whats going on, and you need to be aware on how to use and execute them within situations.

The setting and graphics are all around outstanding, same with the environmental story telling, to which you can learn a lot of certain map lore and more.

You have different tactical classes,which you can implement customisation to your own will.

If you wanna be a big brute, packing a 12 gauge shotgun but running slugs? 
You can, Or a heavily armoured breacher? You can.

A Light weight Infiltrator? you can.

It's all up to your own creativity and control.

(I highly recommend looking at the games different modes, and customisation, but also the Gameplay to have a solid idea on what to expect.)

The games a 10/10 For anybody looking for a co-op tactical shooter, realistically based.

(NEW UPDATE EDIT)

The game has been overhauled, new weapons, clothing, mechanics and details, the game has just gotten better.

Also customisation is now a option to a larger variety.

I hate having to rewrite reviews but here I am. this game was not ready for 1.0, they needed to do a lot more "thorough testing" before the release. which i confusing because that's the purpose of early access but they abandoned that a year ago. I genuinely don't think anyone played this build before the launch. I mean [actually] played, as in sat down to enjoy a playthrough. The AI and graphics are buggy, the performance is bad even on a decent machine, many of the levels are far too big for the control scheme, and the hostiles (appear to) behave less like real people than they did in early access. I bought the supporter alpha because I wanted to support this game to be the best it could possibly be, but when they dropped early access builds they sealed the game's (at least the 1.0 launch's) fate.

I know I said that I don't like rewriting reviews but I really hope I'm given a good reason to rewrite this one. I think the team behind this game really cares about making a good experience, and if they fix just a few things they will have one. I will be the first person to change my review back to a positive one if or when an update is rolled out but for now i really cant recommend this game.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
A cheap copy of the golden age of Rainbow Six games with reduced customization, actions and interactions. Overall had some promise to be more "realistic" but failed spectacularly with so much game breaking bugs and downright unbearable AIs.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics is okay, but having so much problems in terms of optimization. Poor in comparison to most modern games, but bearable enough

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The music and voice acting is decent. As players require to use the voice "command" in-game constantly, it does not register properly where AI does not seem to detect the audio commands provided by players, be it enemy or allies

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Controls are very straightforward like most FPS games

[h1]Bugs & Issues[/h1]
Major bugs may include:
1. Ragdolls causing problems to interact with bodies (dead or alive)
2. Unable to interact with objects like doors, equipment and npcs which is obviously game-breaking
3. AI ignoring commands and "freezes"
4. NPCs stuck in animation, causing unable to do any interaction with (only fix is to kill them, which is a problem)
[b]Stuck Civilian (Cannot interact):[/b]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3143336836
5. Enemy AI can shoot through 3 layers of walls with pinpoint accuracy (absolutely insane and broken)
6. Enemy AI ignores damage taken, not flinching or not being stunned properly even with a direct hit
7. Enemy equipment falling under the map and disappearing
8. Enemy or Civilians teleporting due to some weird physics
9. Enemies (not equipped with relevant protection, e.g.: Gas Masks) unphased by smoke or stunning equipment, which beats the whole purpose of using them in the first place
10. Bashing/Melee enemies do nothing, as they just ignore the attacks multiple times (not registering)
11. Team AI can't go around the player even with sufficient space and gets stuck
12. Team AI can't register if there are hostiles around properly, clearly and enemy is nearby, but will register the area as "clear"
13. To get "S" Rank is near impossible seeing you MUST use NON-LETHAL equipment, with NO DEATHS and NO FRIENDLY FIRES, only possible to do this is with friends or 100% SOLO. Your SWAT AI are downright ret@rded and 50% of the time, enemy AI WILL NOT COMPLY OR FLINCH, PLUS SHOOTING THROUGH WALLS
14. Team AI is basically are ret@rd$, clearing a room and standing still doing nothing. MANY cases where the AI just ignores commands to restrain enemies UNLESS THEY ARE DEAD (PRIORITIZE IN RESTRAINING DEAD ENEMIES INSTEAD OF LIVE ONES!)
15. "Invisible" wall, weapons (gamebreaking), body or hitboxes that can even block your equipment (grenades/taser) and bullets
[b]Invisible NPC:[/b] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3142122480
[b]Invisible Weapon (Can't Fire):[/b] https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3147040108
16. Nonsense requirements for "S" ranks:
[b]NO PENALTIES, NON-LETHAL, NO FRIENDLY FIRES M0ΤHERFÙÇKING BÙ||$HÍT!!!:[/b]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3147038759
17. Enemy AI ignores any melee attack, I was bashing using shield multiple times and AI ignores it whilst punching me through my shield and incapacitates me
18. Enemy AI shoots through shields as if they were nothing, tested whilst static, moving, peaking with variable results. Sometimes they one shot you through shields (I see the bullets on shield/visor) then suddenly die WITH NO DAMAGE TAKEN
[b]AI Shooting Across the map through shield:[/b] https://steamcommunity.com/id/hybrid_dragon/screenshot/2335747743641253007/
19. Unable to collect evidence or report dead NPCs, OBVIOUSLY when going "S" rank, this BUG screws all the hard work being put in to do a "Non-Lethal" run
20. Bugged out achievements, not only it is near impossible to achieve with the AI being imbalanced, when you actually finish it, the Steam Achievement DOES NOT POP, WOW!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall had a good concept and showed promise, but, eventually turned out to be a disappointment. Only got this game due to being similar to the Rainbow Six games (Pre Rainbow Six: Siege). For those whom like tactical shooters, get this game only when there is a big discount or when all the major bugs are fixed.

When it comes to shooters, I only play (lots of) batsh*t boomer/arena shooters like Doom (Eternal) and Blood, or dry milsims like ArmA. It's either crazy or realistic, not much in between. Call of Duty, the Big Mac of shooters, is not my thing; way too appealing to the masses, and all that dlc and in-app purchases crap makes me nauseous. I also have a bit of a dislike for multiplayer(-only) games for a number of (valid) reasons, so I stick to singleplayer games.

When I first saw Ready or Not, buying it was a bit of a gamble for me. I bought it in early access (around the time when Team17 backed the devs), and it was pretty okay back then, but I was not entirely convinced. I played it for a couple of hours but quickly forgot about it. When it released at the end of last year I didn't bother to install it again. My experience with early access is mixed, and I didn't have high hopes for this game.

A little more than a week ago I was a bit bored, and I installed Ready or Not just for the f*ck of it. Man, was I surprised! After the latest patch it has become quite a polished game! I have hardly been able to play anything else since then. It's a rather dry, systematic and business-like affair: just clean out the (varied) maps, rescue civvies and find evidence... Most missions are over in less than 15 minutes.

There are no big bombastic bullsh*t set pieces, but it just does everything right. The gunplay in this game is very realistic, the sounds are spot on and loud, it's tense from time to time and it deals with some heavy topics. This game can be pretty d*mn grim at times (and I like that). Because of the randomness there's also enough replay value. Most surprisingly, it runs like a charm on my archaic 9900K and RTX 2080S on 'epic'.

AI can be a bit janky from time to time, and sometimes the game feels just a tad bit empty. More than once I couldn't complete a mission because a civilian just refused to get on his/her knees, just standing there - all traumatized and out of contact. I also couldn't finish the tutorial/training mission because of a weird bug when splitting the team. A little more NPC activity in the police headquarters would have been welcome, but it's okay as it is. What I also would like to have seen are some options to change map variables, like day/night and weather, number of bad guys and civvies, AI aggression and itchy trigger fingers... I understand the devs chose the current form because of performance related issues. That's fine.

After reading back through some old controversies regarding Ready or Not, I saw that there was quite a bit of fear of alt-right propaganda. The state of the US of Awesome in this game is extremely bad (and in my opinion not too far from where it is now or where it might soon be with the possible second term of that unpleasant, aggressive, orange geriatric baboon). You see tents and misery everywhere, probably all the result of anti-social right-wing policies and the growing wealth gap between rich and poor. Bottom line:[/spoiler] I have yet to discover anything at all in this game that tries to light that little latent fascist flame in me. UPDATE (Jan2024): They hotfixed the enemy AI with some nerfing. It's still full of bugs but the enemy is less frustrating now. A lot of what I ranted about below is still true, but I give it a positive review now for the time being to support development.

___
December 2023:
1.0 seems to be aimed at getting it released before the X-mas perioid, since that's where the money is.

However, the game just became worse in so many aspects compared to early access.

-Unnecessary re-design (even COMPLETE redesigns) of maps.
-Removal of game modes for maps (some maps ALWAYS come with a bomb timer now, completely destroying my more tactical approach gameplay)
-Extreme increase in difficulty
-Cool switch between combat music and stealth music: Gone.
-Suspect behavior people loved during early access, where they were fake surrendering, doubting, undecided to raise gun or not, where you had the feeling of suspension, aiming at the target, trying to get them to surrender, only pulling the trigger when they point the gun at you -> Well, mostly not happening anymore. Now we got terminator-enemies where trying to have a standoff and watching them (if they even play their alternative animations, it is so rare now) is something you just regret instantly, when they turn into John Wick.  
-Enemy AI that shoots and tracks you through walls, while your swat AI team mates respond by shooting at the same wall at the enemy. Like watching a wallhacker duel. And you as a player just ask yourself: Hey guys, how do you do it? Can you give me a link to the hack you are using? ;)

-Huge police station meta hub, completely redesigned, without any purpose or function.
Feels like someone REALLY LIKES to make maps over at VOID interactice. Maybe the company is run by leveldesigners. Surely feels like it.

Someone really thought too big. Maybe the financial success of the early access phase went to some heads.

A little bit of a more conservative approach to further developing the game would have gone a long way.
But what actually seemed to happen was that they went into perfection mode, touch too many things and trying to redesign too much stuff while adding things that seem like a waste of development time.

One of these things is a completely shallow and underdeveloped roster system, with stress levels for your guys.
It's so basic and irrelevant, that they could have just used that time for something more important.
Not to mention that when you die in a mission, you basically replay it as if it didn't happen (like loading a savegame), yet the negative impact of that failure on your teams morale is persistent. Makes no sense. Either the mission happened, and it failed, or it didn't happen, cause you went back to your last checkpoint. 
So this results in a negative feedback loop, where failing repeatedly will completely waste your roster.


A lot of guns seem quite useless now, because you just need the highest possible stopping power and penetration power, as enemies being hit mostly translates to "we are terminators, we don't care being hit, instead respond with pinpoint accuracy and snap to aim-lock you in like 1 frame."
And the penetration is important for your AI mates, as they exchange fire with enemies through walls all the time.
So a lot of possible guns (particular SMGs) are just making the game harder with no benefit.
It also feels like they upped the HP of everything.



Why for the love of god was this necessary?
Why not just improve and fix your game? Why completely re-invent it without checking for ANY feeback during the process? Like, the game went into radio-silence mode for a year, and then releases out of nowhere with 1.0 full release.
Completely abandoning the player feedback process of incemental changes.
Somehow feels like the whole dev team got replaced by some other devs.


And still we got the same major problems in the core gameflow:
-Your mates still don't react to gunfire taken by another mate while the squad is on the move.
-You still run around 30 min at the end of the map to find the last suspect or civilian.
-Still no highlights of things you point at so you know what door/hallway you are selecting to give an order
-AI mates still get stuck at doors
-Many tools still don't have a purpose. Why would you use a battering ram? Why would you use a breaching shotgun? There are no barridaced doors that would require wasting that equipment slot, or any kind of different obstacles besides "open door" and "locked door".
-Light and dark areas still don't seem to have an effect on AI. Peaking out of a dark corner at night while the enemy is standing in the open bright area has no impace. Enemies will just see you at 30m and shoot at you.
-And still MANDATORY film grain. No video option to turn it off. Just why?
-AI still shoots through smoke/gas while the player sees absolutely NOTHING. I guess, just let the Swat AI and enemy AI duke it out through the smoke/gas...  How that is not a priority improvement is beyond me. But then again, so many decision made in this project are just beyond me.

Overall, in the current state, I cannot recommend it. It's super frustrating and development is just putting the priorities on the totally wrong things. Like they lost the ability to play the game from a customers viewpoint.
They could have just went with what they got and make it really good.
Instead they fell into the trap of re-designing half of the game, even though exactly THAT game sold really well and received very positive reviews.
Just baffling.

this game might be expensive but very worth it

Has a lot of issues with the enemy AI, but otherwise a polished, great-looking tactical shooter in the vein of old Rainbow Six and SWAT games.

Fights are very deadly. It really pushes you to use mirror guns to look under doors, flash bangs around corners, etc. otherwise the AI will instantly headshot you. The AI can sense when you see them if they're in "alert" mode, even if their back is turned. They can fire with pinpoint accuracy across the map even while running sideways. They can track your exact location through walls and floors and shoot through them to hit you. Yep. But once you figure out how and when to use the utility and non-lethal tools available it becomes easy to earn a perfect score on all missions, but it is punishing otherwise.

Shooting mechanics are very solid and enjoyable. The game has amazing atmosphere, environments, and fun co-op. And there's some fun mods available, including ones that make the game as easy or hard as you want it to be.

Overall: B rating. If they fixed up the enemy AI to be more realistic and believable it could easily bump to a straight A, but as-is it breaks my immersion constantly.

I honestly love this game, but there's a lot that needs to be done until I think it's "complete". There's bugs that needs fixing, weapons that could be added, much more clothing, and tweaks to the UI, AI, and changes to the ranking system. Some graphical improvements wouldn't hurt, but it looks pretty good already. 

One feature I really want for Multiplayer is a way to see WHO is ready and who isn't, so we all know who to yell at, instead of pressing Y to check if it was me. 
I wouldn't mind if there was a non-lethal pistol to use, or the ability to use non-lethals like the pepper spray and taser with the shield, to give it more versatility. Maybe a baton to help speed things along?

The cosmetics really need some more colours, especially since the basic BDU non-black pants and shirt don't match, and there's still no sign of a balaclava in the game, which SWAT often wear. I wouldn't mind some non-helmet headgear either, like caps, police hats or cowboy hats, since you can already wear some more casual gear like jeans and t-shirts. Perhaps an item could be made, like a medkit, to increase the chance of your downed officers to survive. Some more traits wouldn't hurt either, or the ability to have a Multiplayer trait when you play online, to make it so you gain some boosts like in singleplayer. Perhaps these could be unlocked for play by performing certain feats, like causing a certain amount of suspects to surrender unlocking the "intimidator" trait for use by the player in both Single player and Multiplayer. Feels weird that only the team brings traits to the table.
