Ready or Not is a gripping game that has captivated me from the get-go. The realistic portrayal of tactical operations and the variety of missions make it a true experience. The graphics and sound design contribute to creating an immersive atmosphere that truly plunges me into the world of police operations.

However, one aspect that can be somewhat challenging is the fact that enemies have the ability to shoot through walls and objects, while you yourself are not capable of doing so. This requires additional strategic planning and caution when advancing, as you always need to be mindful of not exposing yourself to enemy fire.

Despite this minor challenge, I find Ready or Not overall very well-executed. The thrilling missions, the ability to approach them with various tactical strategies, and the intense atmosphere make the game a real highlight for fans of tactical shooters. I can definitely recommend it and look forward to spending more time mastering the different missions.

Context - I've had a lot of real life tactical training. The accuracy of the tactics is pretty insane. The first time my guy told one of the team members to pie the door... I was shocked. Much of what you see is exactly how I was trained.

Pros:
-Hyper realism. Whoever you had consult on movement and tactics, knew what they were talking about.
-Decent difficulty
-When you replay a mission, most everything changes (with some exceptions) so you have to treat each replay like its the first time, nothing is predictable.
-Gear change out is smart, like the options for weapons and attachments.
-Overall fun

Cons:
-The team members sometimes get frozen, you tell them to clear a room, they don't. Tell them to follow you, they don't. Whats most annoying is that I could have a team clear a room, and completely miss a bad guy.
-Ive for sure been shot through things like metal containers, cinderblock or brick walls. 
-Needs a mission retry button. Having to go back to the precinct and go through the whole load up process is tedious, and almost kills the game. 
-Why scroll on the mission screen? The whole screen is open, yet I have to scroll through a list. Doesn't make sense.
-Should have each mission with last stats, things you missed, previous grades.
-If you're on a laptop without a page up button, good luck closing the unlock screen, which blocks a significant portion of what you need to see.
-Why have paramedics if they don't treat your wounds? 
-Should not have to slow walk through the precinct to see if the the optic you chose, is the one you want. 
-Way too much walking in general - this is where the hyper realism gets in the way of the fun.
-Should have an option for bad guy indicators. Could take 20 min to figure out who is shooting at you. Keep that for super hard mode or something. 
-Had a bad guy glitch into the ceiling after being shot (on the penthouse level) took an insane amount of time to find him and finish the mission. Had to shoot him (since I couldnt reach him) which resulted in negative points. Bad guys glitch a lot, but that was the worst one that impacted gameplay. 
-If were going for realism, you should be able to shoot through some of the doors. Scope it, see a guy, sling lead. 

Overall this is a really enjoyable game that is likely setting the standard for realism (although sometimes too much). If you put this on VR, it would 100% be decent training. (not unlike some of the systems ive used in the past for real life stuff.) I do highly recommend, and suspect that it will only get better as the devs fix many of these things.

Engaging, plenty of modes, gunplay feels good. Visual storytelling is engaging but very little overarching story. Plenty replayable. After the full release, the AI feels way more intelligent. There's so much that you can do with commanding your squad, and the enemy AI hides effectively, know how to move through their environment, and don't (usually) just stand there and shoot you. Commander mode is a bit shallower than I would have liked but it adds another aspect to the game that makes it more engaging so it's a welcome addition. The police department is a really immersive area, and it's so cool looking around all of it, there's great attention to detail. For an indie game, this looks great. Not photorealistic but very passable, even on the lower settings. Runs between 80-140 fps on ultra settings depending on the map on my 6700xt. Only real gripe is that I wish there were more maps but there's enough combinations of maps and modes (and going for a higher rank, which is really satisfying) to keep you busy until more maps come out (which the devs are clearly working on, the news maps are great). Mods also help with this. Mostly bug free, sometimes dead/incapacitated enemys spaz out glitching on a wall but that's it. I play on linux mint and this works flawlessly out of the box with proton!
Overall, 80/100, would easily recommend to any tactical shooter fan.

Update: 11/Feb/24: The issues I refer to in my review below has been largely addressed. NPCs are better balanced, so you're not fighting robots with perfect aim/awareness. 

NPC teammates are still kinda shitty, but the game is now fun enough and good enough to justify the purchase in my opinion.

7.5/10 - Playing with friends is awesome, playing with the AI teammates is exhausting. Probably wait for a sale unless you have buddies you'll be playing with.

Updated for 1.0:

This is an overall great game, with an excellent foundation and premise. Movement and weapons are largely fine, and matchmaking is pretty easy overall. New police headquarters is pretty cool too. 

DOWNSIDES: 
Gameplay and NPC balance. The devs ramped the difficulty up HUGELY, and my biggest individual complaint is this. The suspects are entirely overpowered. The have jedi-tier awareness and they *never* miss a shot. By the time I even OODA my way to realizing that a shot needs to be taken, they're already halfway through a mag. 

This issue makes the game boring. The only reliable way to complete a mission is to get a shield, and let your NPC buddies do all the work since only robots seem to be able to beat other robots. It's boring, it's frustrating, and it makes a gameplay loop that has one option to be successful. 

Lastly, when in single player not being able to restart a mission is idiotic. With superhuman suspects, I should be able to restart if I'm dead because otherwise all my officers are collectively losing their minds because I got wallbanged by a suspect who heard my thoughts and took me out. 

Overall 6/10 for now. It's not worth $50, but on a sale it's not a bad idea. If the suspects get balanced I'd give it a hard 8/10.

The game still has potential to fill in the SWAT 4 niche, but don't be fooled - it is so fucking far from a real release it's kinda disgusting that they called it 1.0.
Basically, it's still full of bugs that make it really unplayable - making AI is difficult, especially in a game where the concept is asymmetric warfare - RoE exist to make it so much more difficult for you to plan, execute, and survive. The AI always has the home turf advantage, and they are supposed to be irrational actors who might not care as much as your squadmates that they are not coming back home alive. Creating an AI that isn't fair, but 'feels' authentic, is a challenge. What isn't a challenge is that the game has tons of simple, unaddressed mistakes, such as flashbangs having the wrong morale decrease symbol and they actually *increase* suspect morale on specific maps. Or multiple maps haphazardly connected into single huge maps. Or penetration being completely incorrectly coded (for example: only cares about the material type on the surface the bullet initially hits, but ignores that some models might be made out of two or more).
Maybe next time don't withhold the testing branch from everyone who bought the game? Having the TRUE :tm: supporter edition that was THE testing environment because other plebs didn't pay enough was truly the decision of all time.
Seems good so far after 6 hours of gameplay. Would highly recommend downloading the AI overhaul mod as the AI by default are insane.

Shooting is realistic, the ROEs the game uses are NOT. I constantly get docked points for "Unauthorized use of force" after shooting someone with a gun pointed at me. Most of the time it seems they have to shoot you or at you first or else your score at the end of the mission will be lower. Also most of the time there is a objective to capture a HVT, however you will miss the mission objective if he dies. Even if he dies after shooting an AKM through a wall at you. The ROE definitely needs to be adjusted. Campaign feature seems rather bland and boring, it would potentially be fun if they allowed you to play the campaign in a co-op mode but that isn't the case. All in all I give it a 6/10

i really hate having to say this, but trying to keep this review as honest as i can. i am greatly disappointed of the 1.0 release.

i am grateful for all the hard work, but the devs simply worked so hard, on just the wrong things.

if you mean to tell me cracked AI, worse than it's ever been, massive poor performance on maps which ran fine before, where even the newer and overhauled maps are still a mess at times. swat AI being dumb as fuck but with better training, is a good improvement. you're an idiot.

the suspect AI have no brains, it's just shoot to kill. Always. not to mention their god-like accuracy, in short aimbot, wallhacks and other bullshit some people have made whole near 10 minute videos on youtube showcasing the issues. and there are a lot of em.

even if it's time consuming, in a game like this where your gun is your fate, it's certainly the most necessary.

in general, look up things such as "ready or not bugs" or glitches, issues, rant or whatever on youtube. this will give you a big idea of how the game is for others and what needs to be worked on.

Old review:

A challenging game, where you have to fight criminals that are blessed with sixthsense and see-trough-walls sight!

This game is unplayable even on the lowest of lowest settings. it goes from 100 fps straight down to 5 fps nonstop repeatedly. I can play forza horizon 5, gta online and tarkov on high settings no problem, yet this game is impossible to run smooth with a solid fps. The audio is also delayed when you shoot. If it was possible to run this game normally it would be a solid game.

Let me get one thing straight, the entire concept of this game is amazing! You can either play with friends or with an AI squad, both of which have their individual gems that make both modes of the game a re-playable experience; fun shootouts, intelligent friendly/enemy AI, amazing weapon sandbox, fun but challenging enemies, etc.

But what gives? From what I said it sounds like I would recommend this game? For me, it's a yes and no but leaning more toward no.

There is one reason for that... BUGS. 

This game is a massive bug-ridden mess with glitches happening so frequently, that is kills my enjoyment despite all my love for this game.

1. Invisible enemies: I've now had multiple experiences where enemies are straight up invisible yet are able to shoot at me. You may think I just didn't see them? Not at all! I was playing with friends and started taking fire, but I heard no shots? My squadmates came to help me and dealt with them, and I confirmed with them that he was invisible to me but nearly killed me anyway. GAME BREAKING.

Another example was on the level "Elephant" where I was corned by two floating muzzle flashes.. again, GAME BREAKING.

2. Failing to completely load civilians: Time and time again there had been instances of civilians not spawning (most likely the same invisible suspect glitch). On the level "Valley of the Dolls" I was trying to grind for S-Tier, yet was having trouble finding the last civilian. I spent about 30 minutes retracing my steps only to figure out the civilian did not even exist. Even using the "Search and Secure" command didn't even work. A glitch that costed me a successful S-Tier attempt. GAME BREAKING. 

3. Failing to load objectives: Another step to my S-Tier grind, the "Elephant" level. I brought order to chaos and defused one of the bombs, yet I could not find the other one. I searched the map 3 times before the timer ran out and the programmed death occurred. The bomb did not completely load in and the attempt was unwinnable. This game does rely heavily on RNG for replayability, but with the glitches it seems RNG also determines if a level is unwinnable or not. GAME BREAKING.

4. BS "Friendly Fire" penalties: On the singular attempt that was successful for my S-Tier on Elephant, it was cheated from me due to a "friendly fire" incident. Now that was odd.. all of my AI teammates were healthy and everyone was running non-lethal... apparently I was doomed from the start again... what a thing to run into after doing the tedious grind for S-Tier for cosmetics I want. 

There are other bugs in the game such as trainers not showing up, suspects going t-pose after killing them, random framerate drops, etc. but those to me are not important. They don't really kill my enjoyment of the game like the other GAME BREAKING bugs I listed. 

To reiterate, I really love this game. But these bugs I keep running into after hours of attempts and carefully orchestrated strategies only to cheated due glitches.. it's tiring and it makes me want to step away and never come back until they're fixed..

In the game's current state, I WOULD NOT recommend you purchase it right now. You may end up getting a bad taste in your mouth and end up giving up on the game entirely. Wait a few months.. maybe a year, and then give it a try. These bugs will definitely be patched by then.

EDIT: Recent update significantly helped OP AI to be more human like, game is playable again

*** Disclaimer: My review is based on the current official game version (08/2022) and on the experience both as Single Player with AI teammates and Multi Player with teams of friends. I cannot speak for the experience with random players. ***

Ready or Not is a very enjoyable SWAT simulation game. You play the role of a SWAT police officer in a team of 5 players in Single Player (4 AI bots) or 2 - 4 human players (Multi Player). The game is Coop only, so you don't play against other human opponents.

Before every mission, you select your loadout in the briefing room. There is a middle-sized selection of assault rifles, shotguns, SMGs, pistols and non-lethal weapons that you can choose from. The variety of the weapons feels limited, but the weapon types all feel very different and suit different maps and playstyles. In addition, you can modify the weapons to a certain extent and attach gadgets like lasers, flashlights and suppressors to your gun. Another decision has to be made how heavy your armor should be, because heavier armor will limit your mobility and the amount of extra equipment (ammo, grenades, C4, lockpicks, etc.) you can carry with you.

The mission selection itself gives a choice of around a dozen crime locations around the city of Los Santos. For some of the crime scenes you can select a subtype of mission, but not all subtypes are available to all crime scenes. The subtypes are:
- Barricaded suspects: Default mode, medium number of criminals and civilians.
- Raid: Large number of heavily armoured criminals. Relaxed rules of engagement (comparable to Terrorist Hunt in other games).
- Active Shooter: A gunman on the loose tries to kill innocent civilians in sight. You have to stop him quickly.
- Bomb Threat: You have 5 minutes to defuse two bombs.
- Hostage Situation: Self-explainatory.

There are two universal goals that you have to fulfill in every mission: rescue all civilians and neutralize all criminal threats. Please note that you are a virtual police officers, and you must not simply shoot every criminal, but rather try to coerce them into surrendering and arresting them. Granted, if the criminals are uncooperative or attack the police force, you are authorized to kill the assailants irregardless of the game mode. 

As a result, the game is rather slow-paced. You have to take time to assess the situation before you attack with well coordinated attacks. Still, it is very satisfying to breach a room full of barricaded suspects with flashbang grenades and a breaching shotgun from multiple entries. Unfortunately, you have to know the maps beforehand. At the moment, there are no blueprints of the maps available in the game.

The maps themselves have been improved significantly with more details in the most recent patches and give a variety of types of criminals and locations.

Overall, due to the recent improvements, I can recommend the game again for people who want to play a SWAT police officer and understand that the game is not intended for run and gun gameplay.

Please note that you have to manage your expectations, because the game is in an Early Access states. That means:
- The game is very playable, but you have to expect smaller glitches and bugs. Please report them to the development team!
- The amount of content is somewhat limited, but grows with previous (and hopefully upcoming) content patches.
- The performance, especially with night vision equipment, is rather lackluster.

====================================================================

Previous review (Negative):

In its current state (07/2022)  the game is a clear step back from earlier patch versions. Main reasons are:
- the enemies have aimbots and can / will hit you through walls even if there is no line of sight.
- the damage model is extremely inconsistent: some enemies (even without body armor) can tank multiple bullets from assault rifles.

This is sad because I clearly enjoy the game in its earlier state and I don't complain about the difficulty.
I hope that with the next patches I can revert my negative review to a positive review again.

This game is absolutely fantastic! So far, it is the most realistic tactical FPS on the market. With mods, it can become even more realistic as a police simulator, or it can become a more militaristic experience if you so desire. The creators did some serious homework to develop a game that captures the chaos, stress, and confusing split second decisions that police and military are faced with on a regular basis. The movement is as close to real life as you can get without adding in ladders, climbing, sprinting, jumps and drops, which would drastically increase the speed of the gameplay, making it not as realistic or immersive. The only things that need addressing; in game voice chat needs to be overhauled and updated, and the GPU/CPU settings need to be better optimized. Practically everyone who buys this game will have to go through a troubleshooting period to figure out what settings work to best optimize the frame rate and graphics for their individual gaming setup. It's a brand new release, so teething pains and little issues are to be expected. Other than that, get to playing and get to training! Amazing game, highly recommend!

I really wanted to like this game, the levels, guns, equipment are great. What falls short is the overall game design and enemy AI. Why have a full loadout of lethal force options if the game prioritizes taking enemies alive, and penalizes you for having to use lethal options? You lose out on score for not taking certain enemies alive and your officers accumulate more stress when lethal force is used. This wouldn't be so bad if the AI wasn't so resistant to surrendering. Enemies will straight up refuse to give up unless directly hit by a flashbang or stinger round (which are limited ammo) and half the time they pretend to surrender only to pull out a backup gun and fire away. These issues could be overlooked if the game play made up for it but it doesn't for one huge reason, the AI has godlike senses, reflexes, and aim. Enemies will shoot you through walls, doors, and concealment and you will not even know where the rounds are coming from, they will see the tip of your boot from across the map and start immediately shooting. Imagine getting shot twice through a wall and dying while behind a shield and wearing full body armor. Biggest problem with all of this? THERE IS NO RESTART BUTTON. You have to watch the game tell you how bad you fucked up, load back into the station, all your officers accumulate stress, then you have to select the mission again, and wait for it to load up all just to get back in the action. This is just bad design. I couldn't keep playing this game, I felt like I was trying to complete the later levels just out of spite. I have rarely ever quit playing a game because it made me hate playing it this much, and I barely ever write reviews. In this instance I think a good idea has been hampered by bad implementation. Fix the AI knowing where you are at all times, add more less lethal options, and add a restart button to streamline the process and you would have a much better game. Until that happens I can't recommend playing it.

This is a game with a downright suspicious amount of hype around it, considering on how many aspects it falls short. So either most of the development budget went to PR and marketing, or people are just genuinely starved for tactical shooter games. Either way, the hype is most definitely undeserved, and here is why:

1. Poor technical implementation
- The game doesn't look great. With all of the graphics turned up to the maximum, the image is still quite unappealing: pixelation and aliasing artifacts on anything which isn't in the immediate proximity of the player, artifacts in the reflections, a general blurry and overprocessed quality to the image of the game. Turining down post-processing helps a little bit with the latter, but the other issues persist.
- The environment is surprisingly non-interactive, to the point that it feels like playing an early 2000s era shooter. Best you can hope for are some bullet and blood sprites on some surfaces, that's it. Almost nothing is destructible, almost no object reacts to environmental interactions like gunfire and explosions. It's jarring. FEAR set a higher standard in 2005.
- Buggy and janky behavior of most objects that can be interacted with, such as NPCs and doors. Knocked out NPC bodies will clip through the environment, get stuck in it, twitch and ragdoll around, it looks and feels pathetic. Doors, one of the most important and most interacted with objects in the game, will also sometimes bug out, e.g. somehow get wedged in the open position.

2. The AI
There are many praises sung to the new AI that was released with the version 1.0. I have not experienced the old AI, but from what I have seen, it still needs a ton of work. The AI teammates will bug out on the regular, for example a 2-person squad will for some reason get split (the game treats these squads as atomic for the purpose of issuing commands) and stuck on an order, which is a huge problem in a tactical shooter where one relies on coordinated action.
The AI teammates are just terrible in general. They block your path, stand in exposed positions, ignore your orders, execute commands, which they "forgot" to carry out, minutes later, leading to hilarious incidents, like flashbanging a room which you just cleared, with the grenade landing directly at your feet. And worst of all, they will kill NPCs you're supposed to take alive and they will get themselves killed, ruining your experience and level score. So if you want an S ranking, prepare to park your AI teammates outside the objective and clear everything by yourself, like some sort of discount Batman, while hoping and praying the enemies don't find their way outside by a backdoor you haven't secured yet and murder half of your squad, who are haplessly standing around in the middle of a street, because automatically using nearby objects for cover is too much to ask for.

3. The controls
Frankly, the controls aren't too terrible, and after some moderate re-mapping, it plays okay. There are however still a few infuriating aspects of them, like for example the sequence of miscellaneous gear: if you bring both door wedges and a taser, they are both assigned to the key "4" by default, but your character will always take the wedges out first for some dumb reason, and then you have to hit the key again to get the taser out. Even if you preemptively cycle through the equipment and select the taser, the sequence resets. So imagine that you're in a pinch and want to get the taser out ASAP, because you need the adversary alive. Well, tough luck, the wedges come first. This is bad control design.

4. Game design BS
This probably belongs to the technical section, but I am putting it separately just because of how infuriating it is. This is by far the biggest issue with this game: the enemies will shoot you though cover which makes them nearly or completely invisible to you. Yes, try having a firefight with a guy standing behind a pile of random crap which is opaque to you, but he can somehow see through it. Try getting shot though a door with no transparent elements on it, while standing a good 2-3 meters away from it. Try getting shot through a thick, semi-transparent glass panel with so much glare on it, it is effectively impossible to see anything else in the room. Nuff said.

5. Level design
For the last point, I actually have something good to say. I found the level design great, all of the levels are rich in detail and fun to explore and navigate. There is a sense of realism to the locations presented in game, and it helps a great deal with immersion. Props to whoever put in their effort to design and model the maps. It is a great shame the rest of the development team could not hold themselves to the same standard.

In conclusion, I believe there is potential here. The engine is clearly capable of so much more than what has been implemented so far, and the level design really carries the game. I just wonder if the developer ever resolves to give the game the effort it deserves.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

I'm responding to the developers' question - No, the game is not ready. After the gameplay update, I found it engaging for about 15 hours, with the condition that a considerable amount of time was spent just in the lobby. Yes, you can spend another 15 hours on this game to complete all missions with an S rank, but it's not worth it. 

The main complaints are:
* The AI behaves strangely and unrealistically in some cases (not always, but it happens).
* A large arsenal, but there's not much to choose from due to the lack of variety in weapon attachments. We need more scopes and collimators.
* New locations have areas where the FPS drops by half.
* There are plenty of maps, but only one mode: eliminate all weirdos, but don't touch those weirdos who theoretically can surrender but will resist.
In conclusion, it can be said that, in my opinion, the game is not worth the money due to a lack of gameplay content. However, if we are talking about mechanics, they are excellent and well thought out.

If you've wanted to be a cop as a kid, don't even think about it and buy this game, you won't be disappointed.

They've also introduced mods which take the game to a whole different level. You can modify your voice lines to sound like Samuel L. Jackson or to sound like Tony Soprano. Also you can modify suspect voice lines and they can all sound like Big Smoke from San Andreas! 10/10

I played it completely both in beta and 1.0, What I can say is its a awesome update to what SWAT-4 was. There are a few kinks that should be noted as it is sometimes annoying. But overall it was a good game and the last mission, just wow. anyways it was worth it to me, not much to do other than replay missions once you complete it but, heres the kinks I ran into.                           

1. AI for enemies, they are better from when 1.0 dropped but still have great accuracy, I used a mod to fix this
2. The SWAT AI sometimes you will be annoyed when they all enter a closet behind you and you get stuck in the closet because they are following you. They do not always secure evidence, civilians or combatants and it can cost you from S to A-B rankings.
3. The atmosphere is amazing however, it would be helpful to know whether NVGs would be recommended or not. 
4. The missions are long and complex and it is VERY easy to miss a civilian that is hiding in a area that you already cleared so there is missions I spent 20-30 minutes clearing every room again and again to see what I missed to find out it was at the beginning in a closet or office.
5. Weapon selection screen can be redone to show you what you have unlocked after completing a mission successfully 
6. The SWAT AI again, they do not always try less lethal or arresting, sometimes they will shoot the HVT and it is annoying to restart because you cannot get a S ranking with them dead.

Other wise I would say this was a great game and the mods that are coming out will only benefit it. I have a feeling with how the last mission ended (no spoilers) they are setting it up for a further set of missions and I am hopeful that they would. As Is i would recommend this game

[h1] [i] I LOVED IT BUT... [/i] [/h1]

I must say despite my enjoyment with the game, i think even in the most fundamental level this game is deeply flawed and probably won't get fixed, ever. 

How is it flawed? Right before that i must give them some credits.

They really did a great job for optimization on this game...somewhat. I have a pretty low end laptop (i3-6006u, Intel HD Graphics 520, 12 GB RAM) and it is somehow playable. Granted i did do some trimming on my own Windows and tweaking in the game engine but still it is impressive that the game can even run let alone running above 20-30 fps. Plus there were some maps in the Early Access version that just chugging a lot like powerpoint slides of chugging but as of now, it was gone. The maps were redone and i liked some of the maps and i disliked some others but as for the performance goes, there was barely any moment that the map dropped my fps that hard. 

That being said, let's get through the negative part. 

The Police Station kinda sucks. In the early access version, the lobby was a small confined space so i could join multiplayer games easily in and out. And yes, i could play a bunch of multiplayer with this garbage of a laptop and it would perform similar as how it would be played in singleplayer. But in the release version, it took a long while to load in the station so in the multiplayer, simply it never had the chance to load in properly and screw up the visuals. Sometimes it crashes my games even. I know it's not really surprising since i'm waaay below the supposed specs but i think it's still worth to note upon. 

Next one and the most important one, the AI. I don't really mind to have a more challenging AI and whatnot but the fact that i have to take care 4 babies that doesn't even know when to take cover, when to suppressing fire. and when to follow my orders mostly, that's just so FUCKING ANNOYING. And it's not like the enemy AIs are the same. I saw with my own eyes, some of the terrorists COULD DO JUST THAT while my teammates were never NEVER EVER DO THAT. Not to mention they would FUCKING WALLBANGING IN THE MOST NON SENSIBLE WAYS POSSIBLE. This felt like i'm playing a European game from 2000s with all of those European Jank glories. This game has novelties but the execution of it just really, really flat. 

And here is the kicker, they were intended to be like that which is the most basic way of a game philosophy of giving a hard time for players. Which is, in my humble opinion, an utter bullshit. Like i get it, we wanna make the game as unnerving as possible but even so, don't break the immersion of the game by making your allies AI DUMB and the enemies AI very much more superior. I even saw an enemy AI crawling, and neither of me and my allies can do that. Having a deliberate disadvantage for the players to make things spicy is the most outdated mindset in game design and i think it needs to stop. 

If there's any way to mitigate my negative perception of the game, they would have to get rid of that ancient design and just make everything balanced and make sense. I want to take upon a role as a SWAT officer, i don't want to play where i take a role as a SWAT officer. Having these issue for me really breaks that immersion away and i keep being reminded that i'm playing a video game, which is sucks. Might as well just degrade the graphics to look like SWAT 4 and rehaul the gameplay to be as fast as COD, hell even the enemy AIs have already play like that. But if this game wants to keep the integrity of the game's aesthetic, might as well make everyone behaves like how close they are in real life. Because that's the impression that the dev had given in the past years, grounded and immersive. 

I think they really don't need to change a ton. If they think making more maps or game modes will save the game they are deadly wrong. It's not about the content, it's the core gameplay and as of now, it is an utter shite because of the discrepancies of gameplay between the players and the game's AI. I truly, truly do hope this will get rectified and by then, i can proudly say i enjoy thoroughly playing this game.

Okay, my original review was definitely cringe.

I've changed my mind about this game since Feb 6, of 2024.
Ready or Not - HOTFIX #3 was released then and updated the game.

I can wholeheartedly recommend this game without shame now.
It's still not in a state I would consider to be finished but I can say that it's a dope cop game and it's definitely worth the cheddar.
VOID clearly spent their time reading reviews and watching critiques of their work because the patch notes scream, "We heard you!" and the results are very enjoyable in-game.
They fixed a bug allowing prolonged engagements between suspect and SWAT AI, through walls, without the need for re-acquiring line of sight. They halved suspects' bullet damage through walls. They revamped how suspect AI calculates suspect accuracy and re-balanced it. They also added a lot more audio to suspect, civilian, and SWAT characters. They also added more audio to mission maps making them more immersive.
There are still things missing like icons for items in the customization menu (for example the ballistic face mask has a customization option keeping it black but tinting the visor gold. Its option's representative icon is a red, 'X,' and little text reading, "missing data."). The AUG assault rifle is held improperly and I'm guessing it's missing all of its proper read and reload animations too (from third person).
A complete product should be more polished than this game is in its current state (Feb 9, 2024.). So I'm not going to say it's ready, but I will say it is fun and it is a dope cop game and it is definitely more fun than it was!

2 MONTHS after leaving early access:
- Friendly AI is still broken and your orders are ignored 90% of the time (until you "reset" by ordering fall in and retrying which also won't always work)
- The performance is terrible and the FPS drops to 30-40 even for people with amazing hardware
- Some maps are really huge and labyrinth-like. That sounds like a good thing, right? Well, no, considering that you have to spend like 20 more minutes running around a cleared map trying to find that one last civilian that you ordered to be restrained 40 minutes ago and the SWAT AI confirmed the order and proceeded to just stand right next to that civilian instead of doing anything. 'Rescue all civilians' was a great objective in SWAT 4 where maps were relatively small and very focused. These behemoths shouldn't have such general objectives unless you're going for an S rank.
- The gamemodes that added cool diversity to the small pool of maps RoN has were removed for no reason
- AI-generated artwork, AI-generated subtitles, Ai, Ai, AI
- The replay feature is a hot mess. At first it couldn't be turned off and would fill your drive with gigabytes of files and now, after hotfix, it doesn't save the setting you choose. You have to enable the replays every time you play if you do want them. Not to mention that the system itself is just borked, has issues with metadata (you have to find your replay by time & date because every map's name is TransitionMap according to the replays)
- THERE IS NO MULTIPLAYER LOBBY BROWSER, only automatic "matchmaking" queue. I hope I don't have to explain how bad that is
- And if ONE MORE TIME I'm going to be ADADADAD strafe-killed by a low income housing resident I'm going to lose my mind

Let's start at the beginning shall we? I got this game in early access before the ADAM update. Back then the AI wasn't too crazy, the gameplay was enjoyable, if not a bit repetative due to not many maps being available. Then the ADAM update released in december last year. It introduced some new maps and several game breaking bugs as well. Also they somehow made the game run like ass even on higher end PCs. The update made the SWAT AI useless because they could not even enter a door anymore for some reason, and they made the suspect AI almost impossible to deal with. They shot through walls with pinpoint accuarcy. They would turn around and instantly shoot you in a millisecond before you even had the time to pull the trigger, even if you had an advantage over them. They never surrendered, constantly rushed at the player with no sense of self preservation. The ADAM update was a year ago. In this year the developers only released one hotfix in early january that barely fixed anything and then went radio silent. They would share some really minor details about the developement during their "biweekly newsletters". After serveral community outrages because of the lack of updates we finally got a date to the 1.0 release. I was really excited, even more so because of the AI rework they mentioned. But when 1.0 dropped it just wasn't what I expected. Before 1.0 I could run the game on high setting at 50-60 fps. Now I get huge fps drops even on the lowest setting on some maps, reaching as low as 12 frames per second. A tactical shooter where you need pinpoint accuarcy at times is unplayable like this. The update also made the suspect AI even more agressive somehow and now it's basically impossible to complete some maps alone or without casualties or non-lethally (the last two are required to get S rank on the maps). They still shoot you behind walls and through doors even if they don't see you, they still rush you, they never take cover, sometimes they are not dazed by multiple gunshots at all and they continue firing, and they very rarely surender. The only thing 1.0 brought was some new maps, and some reworks to the SWAT AI which makes them usefull again but it's still far from ideal. Ready or Not was not ready for the 1.0 release (which is quite frankly ironic) and calling this anything but still early access is simply wrong. After having a full year to fix stuff there's simply no excuse to release a game in this state and call it version 1.0. No matter how much I enjoyed this game when it first came out I just cannot recommend it to be purchased at this time especially after the price increase which came with the full release. It's a shame too because this game has so much unrealised potential and would be the pinacle of the genre if the developers simply put more effort into it.

Edit: (2024.01.18) One month after release, VOID is still not adressing (or even acknowledging) either the performance issues, nor the unrealistic ultra OP suspect AI. They released one hotfix one week after release, went radio silent for 3 weeks and just released a hotfix today. Neither of these hotfixes fixed any major bugs.

Edit 2: (2024.02.09) It's been almost two months since the 1.0 release. VOID released a really small hotfix on the 22nd of January, which again didn't fix anything major. 3 days ago they released another hotfix that actually fixed important issues like the aimbot suspect AI and such. Overall the game is much better now and actually enjoyable because you don't get inta-headshotted through a wall when you don't even see the enemy. But there are still some major issues. Even though the suspect AI has been toned down a bit they can still track you throught walls too accurately and they still lack any sense of self preservation, still rushing at you guns blazing. The performance, although a bit better, still leaves much to be desired because you still get massive fps drops on some sections of some maps. Overall I can see the improvement, but my rewiew will stay negative until VOID delivers on their promises.

[h3]cons:[/h3]
- it's buggy, your team get's stuck on staircases, stuck in hallways, stuck responding to an orders
- the enemies react with superhuman reflexes, a crack-head will see you from 100m in pitch black darkness through a window on the third floor of a house and start shooting from within half a second. This usually feels unfair, this is a common complaint evidenced by the countless mods tweaking the enemy AI
- it can be tedious, a lot of the time an objective is "secure all hostages" which means the mission doesn't end until you've checked every single room for 1 guy you might have forgot to cuff.
[h3]pros:[/h3] 
- there's a bunch of maps, 
- the game feel tense to play, 
- it's got all the tacticool stuff I think most players would enjoy,
- you're rewarded for being slow and methodical.
- random objective/enemy/civilian placement means replay-ability is good. 

I think if they made the AI less responsive and countered that with you being able to take less bullets then i'd like the game a lot more, but in it's current state it can just feel frustrating to play, maybe it's better coop but I only did single player.

Love the game. Love, love love it. The lore is outstanding, if you take your time to look around the map every mission you will find the whole story. However, I strongly dislike that myself and my entry team have to take the time to bag and tag the weapons. If anything, offer it as extra points, after all it isn't the entry teams responsibilities. I cannot express enough the time it takes for someone to search for a singular (sometimes multiple) guns. That is my ONE and only complaint.

Damage is completely unrealistic. 4 rounds to my arm are enough to kill me, but a bunch of druggies in t shirts can tank buckshot point blank or multiple 7.62 rounds to the chest without even dropping their aim. On the rare occasion they DO react to pain, they will kneel down just to one hand full auto right into your brain. Flying through doorways full speed, not missing a shot. Shooting through pixel angles in cabinets and killing you before the door you JUST touched is even halfway open. This new update SLIGHTLY nerfed their damage and aimbot, but even then you have maybe a half second more to react. Doesn't mean anything when the AI knows your location at all times and often runs with zero sound or any way to know where they are. Extremely poor execution by VOID, and that says a lot because they've been working for years.

Getting shot in the chest and staying in the fight is realistic. Happens all the time. Every single enemy being capable of absorbing half a mag while not staggering or reacting to it at all is not. VOID needs to get it through theire head that it is not a fun experience to be tracked through a wall by a junkie who will tag you as soon as you peak in, with little to no ability to stop their bullets magneting to you. I've even been instant headshot killed WHILE WEARING THE FACE MASK. Swat 4 was better than this game. Another dev needs to take a crack at it because VOID is completely lost. Do not buy this game.

If you're expecting a spiritual successor to SWAT 4, this is not it.
If you're looking for a cooperative shooter, it's a decent option.
Essentially, it's a standard close quoters shooter with minimal tactics and planning, but with good visuals and sound.
The unbalanced artificial intelligence is noticeable; homeless drug addicts shoot as well as, if not better than, your veteran special forces. At a certain point, they stop respond your flashbangs and explosives, becoming fearless or even suicidal bullet sponges, diminishing the authenticity and artificially increasing difficulty.
Some of dev's decisions are just wasting of your time. Like you have to waste 3-5 minutes to restart mission.
The game shows potential, but it feels like the developers dropped the ball at a certain point and rushed to finish development.

As of 1.0 Hotfix 3 (Feb 6) and another 50ish hours into the game, I think this is a solid pickup --IF-- you like challenges.

The complaints I had from the initial release (old review left below) are still here, but the with Hot Fix 3, the initial accuracy feels a lot less punishing for peeking your head over a window or slicing a doorway a little too wide.  The AI will still spot you inhumanly so, and react wildly fast, BUT you don't get lased by AI bullets right away.  The erratic first shots really tone down the punishment while still keeping up the stakes and the potential to recover.

I am only really speaking from a True Solo (no player / AI teammates) perspective.  With friends--and I'm sure the AI Squad/Team aspect--this game is a joy to play.  But to progress well, or complete missions with high grades, a constant self-reflection after every death and failed mission is needed.  To borrow a quote the From Soft community uses: Get Good.

A 1hr play session of constant deaths in one mission might go:
Q:  Why did I die there?
A:  Well, you didn't wand under the door to that hallway before opening the door and got blasted.
Q:  Why did I die there? 
A:  Well, you got that hostile to surrender, but you rushed into the T intersection of doors and a hallway to restrain them without clearing and got blasted.
Q:  I wanded under the door to the hallway before opening the door, I got the hostile to surrender, and then I made sure I was clear down the T intersection.  SO WHY DID I DIE THERE???
A:  Yes, you did all those things, but you could have cleared the building in a totally different path as to not open yourself up any kind of sideways scenario in that hallway from that approach.  Again, Get Good.


If you like realistic, smart, and reasonable approaches needed to accomplish difficult tasks, this game is for you.  Would Recommend.

For me AI is now max level dificulty, but NOT supersoilders (unplayable). With a good management it's now posible to do all levels without somebody of your squad dying. So for my setup (with voiceattack) AI is perfect.

That being said, if you play without voiceattack or similar I can totally understand that the game becomes imposible. In the current state the game is almost unplayable in very open maps if you dont have voiceattack or similar. So please if you are going to buy the game take into account that. I think it's still posible to beat it but probably going super slow.

Finally if you expect this to be the house raid Modern Warfare kind of gameplay, DON'T BUY THE GAME. You will get too much frsuted starting from the 4th level or so. This game looks as good as most of the new MW games, but don't be fooled. The dificulty of the game it's not like the ones you can find in AAA games. 

To make an idea most of the players do not even have the achivement of completing all levels with a C (only the 1.3% of players have it, as of writting this) or greater. In order to have a C or lower you have to commit a lot of faults, more or less equivalent at killing 2 civilians (in points). So yeah keep that in mind.
As an LAPD member for 9 years and for NYC SWAT for the last 3, this game gets it right, obviously, it can only be so realistic because it's a video game, but what it can do, it does well.

Save your money (for now). It is a good game just needs a lot of ironing out. Once that happens I'd say buy it.

This game has SO much potential. In its current state, I cannot recommend it -- it is borderline unplayable to get an S tier. 

The Devs absolutely need to re-work suspect morale, because it's absolutely insane for a suspect to still be a crackshot head-eyes aimbot after being pepperballed with a full mag and also getting a direct flashbang 5 feet away. 

Mods completely fix most of the issues that people have gripes about with this game, which is almost the only reason why I would recommend it in its current state. It is incredibly fun to use VoiceAttack to give your AI voice commands in Commander mode. Multiplayer is fun, but good GRIEF it is impossible to go non-lethal even WITH gas, pepper rounds, beanbags, etc. These should absolutely be disorienting to the suspects, but for whatever reason it doesn't make a shit of a difference.

Devs, you've fixed so many of the gamebreaking issues but I am still not sure I would call this a finished game with the state of the AI (but thank you for fixing the ridiculous shooting through walls, or addressing the issue). 

The game has come a long way, but it still has many finishing touches it needs. There is hardly any time to coerce a suspect into compliance, and I wish there were more hang time for a suspect to decide whether or not they are going to promptly headshot you or your teammates. Mods address these issues perfectly -- but the game should not need those mods, nor should they need to be the top downloads.

With all of that out of the way, I really love this game. I love the tactics, the strategy, and I love the grittiness of the game. It is innovative and I believe it will shape future tactical FPS games. It truly is a great game. 

P.S. Devs, the maps for tactics and strategy on the phone could use added details IMO

"Ready or Not" is a stellar tactical first-person shooter that delivers an immersive and intense experience for players. From its realistic portrayal of SWAT operations to its deep gameplay mechanics, the game excels in providing a truly authentic and engaging tactical experience.

One of the game's strengths is its emphasis on strategy and teamwork. Players must carefully plan their approach, coordinate with teammates, and execute precise maneuvers to succeed in their missions. This level of depth adds a layer of challenge and satisfaction to each gameplay session.

The attention to detail in "Ready or Not" is remarkable. From the intricately designed environments to the realistic weapon handling mechanics, every aspect of the game feels meticulously crafted. This attention to detail contributes to the game's immersive atmosphere and enhances the overall gameplay experience.

Moreover, "Ready or Not" offers a variety of content to keep players engaged. With a compelling single-player campaign, challenging multiplayer modes, and regular updates and expansions, there's always something new to discover and enjoy in the game.

Overall, "Ready or Not" is a must-play for fans of tactical shooters. Its blend of realism, depth, and thrilling gameplay make it one of the standout titles in the genre, and a highly recommended experience for any gamer looking for a truly immersive tactical experience.

I had a lot of good things to say about this game but after it took nearly 2 hours to update a 2.4GB patch I had a lot of time to think about the game in it's current state as my frustration mounted between the dismal update speeds. That being said, I'm going to have to err on the negative side and not recommend this game. Keep in mind, the patch itself only took around 10 mins roughly to load, so it wasn't an internet issue. It was the verification process that took ages because as of update 1.0 it is still a pretty buggy mess.

Okay, lets start with the positives: great AI, world building, good gameplay and fun with friends. It is in every sense of the world a successor to the acclaimed SWAT 4 series and it does its job well. The maps are expertly detailed, the gunplay feels solid and impactful and the tactical aspect is pretty fantastic, as expected. The SWAT AI has seen massive improvements too with 1.0 and its pretty great how they've thought out how the AI could be helpful rather than a hindrance to the player like in former versions of the game.

Now, onto the negatives. Lets talk about the fact how the developer is just really absurdly inconsistent with keeping the community informed. At times they are excellent, providing detailed overviews of whats to come in new updates with gameplay footage and explanations in laymans terms, as to help the average player understand. But then, out of the blue, they'll go radio silent for MONTHS on end. This is behaviour I'd expect from amateur game devs, not a studio that has a solid reputation and thousands of supporters. This behaviour would have flown years ago when the game first entered early access. Its been literal years and the game is still in early access, but the devs have not shown a good commitment to improving their standing and keeping their community informed. 

Next, what the fuck is up with the enemy AI? All that work put into the friendly AI is frankly negated if the enemy can 360 blindfire and one tap your character when they are completely flashed. To put it nicely, the enemy and civvie AI in this game is a buggy mess. For all the improvements of the friendly SWAT AI, the game completely nullifies them by the lack of polish and work done on EVERY OTHER ASPECT OF AI in this game. Don't believe me? Check out the subreddit as well as Youtube; there are plenty examples of what an inconsistent mess the enemy AI has been. Frankly speaking, I am very let down by this considering the game is considered 'completed' at 1.0. This is acceptable for a game early in the development cycle NOT a game that has been in early access for several years only to be presented with a buggy mess like this. 

Lets also talk of the lack of polish. While the levels of the games itself are very detailed and clearly have a lot of love put into them, the fact that much of the game lacks any real polish cannot be ignored. Simply put, the game just FEELS unpolished and janky, even with years of work put into it. The sad fact is, this inherent jankiness can be ignored if there was more love put into other aspects of the gameplay, such as the AI, but both of these problems in tandem just make for an unpleasant gameplay experience. The textures of the game are inconsistent, compounding the issues of lack of polish. The overall feeling is just...not great, even with years of development. Extremely disappointing as I've been closely following the development of this game for years and was extremely excited when it touted itself as a spiritual successor to SWAT 4. That being said, even SWAT 4, a 20 year old game at the time of writing feels more polished and smooth than this game does with it's next generation graphics.

All this to lead into my next point, which is that, as of 1.0, this game is a buggy, unoptimised mess. From weapons glitching through the walls to absurdly poor file optimisation, the game is just messy in every aspect. It is unbelievable that, even with a dedicated team working on this game and no other projects, they have no found a better way to get the game to update. It is absurd that a 2.4GB patch takes 2 hours because of poor file optimisation leading to slow verifying times. For 176HKD, I honestly expected a bit more. In the past year I've owned this game, I've found myself coming to it less and less because of its frankly awful load times; in the past week alone I tried launching this game TWICE for quick play sessions only to realise that the slow patch cycles paired with the buggy mess of a menu made it impossible to even join a lobby to play the game. 

It is precisely these issues that make the game a novelty and unpleasant for new players to actually get into. With development progressing at such a slow rate, I'd expect most of the dedicated playerbase to continue to decline until this game becomes a forgotten relic unless the developer takes strides to improvement the subpar gameplay experience as a whole.

I know I've been very critical of RoN thus far, but it really isn't to say I expect a triple A experience from a developer clearly unequipped to provide one. But for fucks sake, some communication with the community would allow for more leniency from the playerbase. The fact is VOID has neglected to do this, letting down the entire dedicated community and it is with a heavy heart I must say this game is just simply not worth buying at its current state. I was once a proud and outspoken supporter of the devs, constantly coming to their defence when people criticised them for various reasons online, but even now I am forced to say that they were right and I feel extremely let down over the years of development this game has seen so far. 

TL;DR: At its current state this game is undoubtedly NOT worth buying.

I can highly recommend this game as someone who's been playing tactical shooters since their inception in the 90s. IMO, it has the smoothest animations and "feel" for CQB combat in recent history, and is extremely reminiscent of the old SWAT 4 formula, and in many ways can be seen as it's predecessor. Even some of the UI for commanding your SWAT team in single player feels almost ripped directly from SWAT 4. Online, with a few buddies, this game absolutely freaking shines if you're all on the same page. If you're looking for thoughts on the game, don't bother with the forums... This community, like most in this genre is extremely hostile and toxic. But, take it from someone who's still got the original CDs of many of the original old tactical shooters - this game is fantastic. 

Some of the highlights for me are:
- Weapon barrel length matters. It's hard to clear doors with long barrels, or stay close to other members of your team.
- The friendly SWAT AI is generally fairly competent compared to the contemporaries in the genre.
- Lots of weapon porn. The animations for the weapons, look, and function is absolutely spot on, and closely reflects what many actual real departments both past and present have used, even down to the bolt hold on the MP5/10.
- A few "game" like devices to make things a bit more fun (optical wand, door wedges, etc.). Do they exist? Sure. Are they really used? Not much that I experienced IRL, but they don't detract from the game in any way.
- Builds on the concepts of SWAT 3/4, both of which I adore.
- Plenty of achievements, customization, etc., that I feel add to the gameplay.
- Lots of little things, such as in-between mission story elements at the HQ changing, as you can see the story evolve, etc. The story isn't super rich, but they're all tied together in subtle little ways that reflect as you progress through the campaign. Take a few minutes and look between missions. 

Some other notes:
- At first I didn't care for the ultra large maps, but they've since grown on me. Still, I'd prefer to see more linear and/or smaller maps included in the future.
- AI isn't perfect, but it's still damn good. The recent patch (as of this review) has helped a bit. Be prepared for suspects to shoot through walls, and flank. Go slow, methodical, and think.
- There's a few UI and other little bugs, such as the compass not working properly, etc.
- I'd like to see a bit more intel on the briefings to help determine kit loadouts for new players.
- Doorways are kinda funny in that they open both ways? I can overlook this, but I'd like to see this adapted.

I refunded this game because after 2 hours, I saw something coming: This game doesn't have great replayability. Yes you can bring a different loadout, yes enemies will be in different places, but all of that didn't really stop me from finding the mission repetitive really quickly.

The game has a charm, it's really great to discover a level and run it for the first time, the game is gorgeous, the environments are fun. But aside from wanting a higher score, there's no reason to replay a level, and all of the wow factor will be gone.

So, if you're like me, and don't think you're going to beat the same levels over and over again just to see a score number go up, well this game is 18 levels that last about 20-30 minutes each, they don't get much longer as the game progresses (confirmed by friends who beat them all), so assuming you're good at shooters, you're looking at around 15 hours to beat every level. I personally couldn't justify 60$CAD + tax for 15 hours of gameplay.

I truly feel like the 1.0 price increase wasn't justified.

I love this game for exactly what it is supposed to be: a slow-burning tactical shooter that prioritizes controlling a situation over lightning reflexes.  It's not an original formula, but in 2024 it might as well be.  In a world where everyone wants to develop the next big live service MMORPGFPSPVPVEMOBA game, Ready or Not just wants to be a tactical shooter with big brass balls.  The game strives to be realistic and mostly succeeds, but it does so without feeling as sterile as something like ArmA III.  Instead, Ready or Not presents its grimy, dirty setting in a way that might make you believe the developers wanted to score a horror tag for their Steam page (as of this writing, a sizable portion of the tags actually are for horror).

There are a lot of things to love about Ready or Not.  I already mentioned the setting, which is so thorough that people are able to make lore videos for each level on YouTube.  The gunplay is weighty and crunchy and full of consequence.  The squad controls are simple, intuitive, and as of 1.0, enable the player to command their team with far less micromanagement than similar shooters.  Speaking of which, the 1.0 SWAT AI is fantastic:  they take cover, arrest suspects, gather evidence, and even take initiative to move into connected areas, all without your prompting.  There's a lot to love here, and not a ton I don't.  I absolutely recommend this game.


Now...that said...I have some concerns.  As of hotfix 3, I'm worried that the game might be getting too easy.  A very vocal subset of the community seems to have spooked Void, resulting in Void nerfing enemy AI considerably.  People were angry because they claimed to be repeatedly massacred by AI firing through walls after seeing just a little pixel of the player character.  I haven't had this experience at all and I think it's a skill issue:  anyone who takes the levels slow and really thinks about their next steps while taking deliberate measures to control the situation can successfully play this game and do well.  I don't think that Void is right to cater to the people who routinely get their whole squad killed by a booby trap because they didn't take the time to scan the threshold.  Before hotfix 3, I felt a lot of tension on each mission, believing that death lay in wait for me or my team behind every door.  I was always very careful and very deliberate because it was what the game required.  Since hotfix 3, I haven't lost a single squad member, and I feel less tension.  Hotfix 3 didn't ruin the experience, but for me it has altered the experience in some unpleasant ways.  Hopefully this doesn't become a trend, because I like the high stakes hardcore nature of the game.  I'd like to see that preserved.

[h1]Review for RoN 1.0 (After finished the campaign)[/h1]

The current version, the newest update, and this game, Ready or Not in 7th Feb 2024 is [b]STILL[/b] the definition of [b]2 steps forward 1 step back[/b].

[strike]Call me noob I don't care, but the AI has return to its ridiculous state, aimbot or smart, I call that a bullshit. Wall-banging? Yeah, it has return with horrible ways. Other than that, I can mostly tolerate. 

[b]Edit: After tried various way like human being would do, I understand that the game intentionally wants you to play extremely methodical and no run and gun which is understandable, but the suspect AI being able to snap-aim is just unbearable, only thing to have an advantage over suspect is to stun the sh*t out of them. Because stunning suspect is a requirement, it defeats the purpose of being "Special Weapons And Tactics" unit, its just "Special Stun And Arrest" at this point.

Edit 2: After finishing the campaign with multiple failures on my belt, I have to say that the suspect AI is extremely inconsistent. 
[list]
[*]First of all, suspect morale. Most suspect I encounter are stubborn and will get up asap when you're out of their sight, AI SWAT will not keep their morale in check which is dumb. (Only certain characters such as the disguised workers in the Port map will comply without problems.
[*]Second of all, suspect accuracy. Yes I've noticed they finally took note of some of the older AI overhaul mod where if your distance between suspect is farther, they will more likely miss the shot and vice versa. But in this current version, [u]it's inconsistent[/u]. Sometimes, suspect will don't have any problems hitting you in 40 meters, other times, bullet storm without a single scratch which is very frustrating to deal with.
[*]Third of all, the suppression mechanic. I understand that even in irl, you will definitely be flinching if bullets fly right by you, well, that is when its only [u]a problem to the player[/u]. You see, suspect won't even flinch or lose accuracy or any visible decrease of morale when being suppressed. Making the suppression mechanic felt like it working against player rather than AI.
[*]Fourth of all, AI interaction with world geometry. As many people and I already pointed out the nature of suspect's wall-banging behavior, another issue is that any semi-opened doors are a danger to the player due to whatever the logic running behind the scenes determines that {if door is open = visible behind the door}. Same goes to windows and certain semi-transparent object as well, where there are many graphics rendering issues (which I'll mention below) making it difficult to look through whereas suspect won't have any issues with it (same goes to CS gas).
[*]Last of all, the trailer units are broken, only appear in Gas station level once. Felt funny when they mention about trailer units in the announcement update just to only work in one scenario huh.
[/list][/b][/strike]

[b]They've now mostly fixed the suspects AI problem. Yes, read again, you got it? No? I said MOSTLY. They sometimes still shoot through walls without line of sight. (My first playthrought on Neon Tomb) Other than that, you can mostly stand a chance against suspects alone which is plus.

Ah ah ah, you think that's all? [i]Weeeeell[/i] in return, we got a significantly worst SWAT teammate. One or two of your member is like having hyperactive ADHD syndrome and start walking to the next room and losing against an enemy who sprays their gun for 5 seconds in their general direction to react. Or even unable to shoot their gun due to being too busy panicking and stand around like a sitting duck waiting to be killed. 

Even greater is that any civilian you told them to exit DOESN'T COUNT TOWARDS ALL CIVILIAN RESCUED. SERIOUSLY? I WASTED MY 26 MINUTES METHODICALLY CLEARING THE DANCE FLOOR AND NOW YOU DECIDED TO F ME OVER? You know what I'm done, I will keep playing for the sake of "fun", not stupid "immersive" logic. [/b]


And whoever working on the graphics department, I hope you have a pair of thicker glasses as the game is awfully blurry as hell with or without anti-aliasing, only way to make it clearer is to slide the render resolution up to 150. No, I did not have motion blur on or any fancy thing just to write an excuse, this is serious and it's frustrating to play. (same thing applies to opti-wand picture-in-picture mode.). [strike]For the object semi-transparency issue, certain objects such as hair, glass, and many other transparent object will not render correctly making it look like someone put a fishing net on objects.[/strike]


[b]Edit: Glad they fixed the shield glass glaring issue, just forgot to mention here. And other semi-transparent/opaque object fixed. [/b]


And whoever is working on the technical side of things, I hope you played the game and understand how much broken UI you introduce while older UI bugs left unfixed. [i] And why is choosing entry point doesn't work on certain maps? Is the UI for show?[/i] And why can't I see other player's ping with your new fancy chest tablet? It's just ridiculous how much things can be better but it always require extra step to do so.

[b]Edit 2:[/b] [i]After a bit more playing and fiddling around SWAT AI morale & benefits mechanics, first of all, for the positives, I definitely like the little details about each SWAT member, their small ability perks, personalities during in-scene (dialog/ comments on certain environment) and morale system. HOWEVER, when it comes to how morale affect their performance in-scene, it isn't really noticeable at all, and the small ability perks each member provides are barely even useful when the main problem is still hasn't fix (suspect AI morale, behavior & accuracy).[/i]


[b]Worst case is when you're regularly being killed by ridiculous suspect AI or killing suspects, SWAT member morale will drop due to being arbitrary traumatized by your death or their death until they either got KIA or disbanded which made an even bigger mess in terms of gameplay variety for player choice.[/b] (I literally fired all my SWAT members go in empty handed with default SWAT members)


Overall, I appreciate the update, the new/ overhauled map, the new weapon, the new campaign, more cosmetics and achievements. But the technical side of things is just unbearably horrendous. And as I already mention, current state of the game is the definition of [b]2 steps forward 1 step back[/b]


Edit 2: The credit scene serves good enough purpose when you click from main menu, except when it is done after Port mission where the environmental rain sfx isn't removed, making watching the credit scene felt annoying and poorly done.

Graphics and Immersion - Comment on the graphics and how they contribute to the overall immersion. Compare the visual experience to other tactical shooters in terms of detail, realism, and atmosphere.
Tactical Gameplay Mechanics - Discuss the tactical mechanics such as planning, coordination, and decision-making. Compare these mechanics to other games in the same genre.

Mission Design and Variety - Assess the variety and design of missions. Compare the depth and complexity of the missions to other tactical shooters.

AI Behavior - Evaluate the artificial intelligence of both enemy and ally characters. Compare the AI behavior to other games, especially in terms of realism and challenge.

Multiplayer Experience - If applicable, provide insights into the multiplayer aspect of the game. Compare the multiplayer experience, including modes and maps, to other tactical shooters.

Community and Support - Consider the developer's support for the game and community engagement. Compare ongoing updates, patches, and communication with the player base to other games in the genre.

User Interface and Controls - Assess the user interface and controls, highlighting any intuitive or challenging aspects. Compare this to other tactical shooters and discuss how well it facilitates player engagement.

Remember that personal preferences play a significant role in reviewing games, so it's essential to convey your own experiences and opinions. So it's 9/10 due to weakness of UI menu.

Team AI bugged out and got stuck in one area, had to clear the rest by myself, get rinsed by turbo enemy AI, Ironman run over, save deleted. -First Review after 9 hours. After 57 hours - Swat AI is still hit or miss, they will either clear a room like CQB supermen and eliminate all threats in one shot, or they will blindly meander around getting shot to pieces like Officer Murphy, while not reacting or getting hung up in killzones. Many times it feels like the enemy AI is better trained than my Swat AI, with preternatural reaction time and aim, with many runs ending because I get bushwhacked by a suspect who's skill is on the same level as the morlocks who dominate lobbies in shooters. But despite the glaring issues with AI tuning, I love this game. The setting of a fictitious LA/California analog called "Los Suenos" (with a squiggle over the n) is honestly one of my favorite aspects of the game, as it allows the narrative and environments to reach further than mundane urban policing; Los Suenos is like Detroit in Robocop, where all the contemporary social, economic, and criminal issues are dialed up to 11. The environments the missions take place in are a wonderful example of environmental story telling, with clues, details, and ambiance that paint a larger picture; in addition, the overall art direction of these environments really shine through in certain areas, where something like as simple as a highway overpass over car dealership, is an oppressive cyclopian monolith that blocks out the sky, it's realistic, yet there is something over the top and dramatic about the set pieces. The over all narrative of this game exudes feels like season 1 of True Detective, film nior, mixed of course with pulse pounding, tactical CQB law enforcement; there is always an implacable sense of unease and dread found in the locations of Los Suenos, with conspiracy and tragedy around every dark corner. It feels odd writing all of this about a shooter with no cut scenes or narrative beyond mission briefings and environmental clues, but after 57 hours, there is more to Ready or Not than just a successor to SWAT 4.

Step into the shoes of a SWAT unit, sent in to deal with dangerous crime in progress scenes. There will be some extremely troubling situations, including active school shootings, mass murder with piles of corpses, hostages with bombs planted on them, suggested child sex offending, drug overdoses, and more. The shooting is great, background sound is mostly ambiance with slightly more pumped up music when in acive firefights, and every engagement is life and death. If you hesitate or slow down too much, it might lead to you or your squadmates death. It is an extremely difficult game, and you might need to try missions multiple times, and with different equipment to succeed. In the tension, it can sometimes even feel like a horror game. The levels are varied and well-made, full of details and visual storytelling. 

A lot changed from early access with the 1.0 release, but some of it is almost hidden, and mentioning it might improve the game heavily for some people.
1. There is a fully voiced intro, map and info on suspects and civilians on missions. This autoplays if you have your pda open by pressing TAB. But if you havn't, you have to press TAB and press the play button in the briefing window to hear it. Without this, it just feels like selecting random scenarios, instead of getting some story to go with the missions.
2. You can tell civilians to leave the scene, if it is too dangerous to cuff them, or you simply do not want to. Aim at a civilian at a decently close range, press middle mouse and press 5. But do note that some civilians might still be dangerous.
3. You can tell your AI to search and secure with middle mouse + 6. This can help end missions with a missing civilian somewhere faster. If you have not beaten the map yet, this becomes "Search Room", which is also useful to make the AI teammates secure any evidence, suspects or civilians in the area.
4. Just as another big tip, you can far lean up, down, left and right (or combined in many directions), by holding ALT. If enemies keep hitting your legs, you can almost prone with this and force them to hit torso area, by holding alt + press down + press left/right around a corner.

AI as of patch 1.03 is good, and they value their lives more.

You are also very often in a situation, where you need to find 1 civilian or so to end a mission. The tip above with ai swat searching only seems to work if the civilian is somewhere you have looked already, and can really drag out a basically finished mission. Time to pull out the PDA and look at the map.

Another downside is that the players hub, the police station, feels extremely dead and lifeless. Nobody is talking, or doing anything really, except for a speaker asking for a person to show up at the desk sometimes. Even the chief of police has nothing to say. And you spawn random places after each missions, instead of just near the missions table and equipment station, which because the hub is extremely dead, is just time waste. You also cannot simply "restart" a mission, which I understand because of the new commander mode, but most people would probably like the morale penalty immediately, and just be allowed to retry without being sent back to the station.
