Ah, Ready or Not... let the truth begin.

I picked this game up in mid October 2023 after seeing a video of a team of Marines run the hospital mission. After the first ten hours or so, I was hooked. The mechanics, the gameplay, the graphics, all of it was amazing. And it was still Early Access, believe me, I was stoked.

In early access, you had multiple missions with multiple different modes they could be played on. Customisation was limited, but unless you're a Fortnite player, skins shouldn't matter all that much. The SWAT AI was reasonably intelligent and got the job done, but could've done with some improvements. Suspect AI was pretty damn good, if a little silly at times (having five armed SWAT officers pointing guns in your face and screaming at you to get down isn't exactly a prompt for the average bystander to take out their phone and take pictures), but beyond that, the game was a solid 8.5/10 and I happily recommended it to my family (my sister ended up getting it) and building a 'clan' of sorts, a small but tight gaming community centred around RoN.

After some thinking and deliberation (and admittedly, the temptation provided by that glorious FBI drip) I bought the Supporter Edition and began taking part in the SE Exclusive server, providing feedback, suggestions, asking questions, etc. $100 for mulitcam and some same-but-different guns. Meh. I didn't care, I wanted to support VOID and that was enough for me, plus the promise of early access to updates was a big draw for me, because it would mean that I got to personally have a helping hand in the game's development.

However, VOID failed to deliver on their promises. Supporters were given little more than an extra idea of what would be included in the 1.0 update, when in fact, we were promised early implementation, playtesting even. There hadn't been an update, no matter how small, in well over a year. In short, VOID Interactive took cash for nothing and lied to their supporters. A scam.

Speaking of 1.0, the flagship update was hyped up to the point where you simply couldn't go a day in the discord (either SE or standard) without having someone ask 'when update'. Truth be told, it got remarkably repetitive, rapidly. 1.0 itself was to be the crown jewel of RoN, the biggest and best thing to happen to the game since the ADAM update. However, this was not to be the case.

1.0 has actually taken the game from 8.5/10 to a 4.5/10. It has removed the various gamemodes, made enemy AI frankly impossible to play with (think COD hackers level of infuriating), introduced countless bugs, crashes, start-up errors, glitches and more, whilst adding the bare minimum content. The aesthetic customisation is purely surface level and honestly lacklustre. The new and improved police headquarters (pregame lobby) is, while admittedly beautiful, utterly for show. The maps are excessively large and difficult to play through, unlike those in EA, and many features listed in the changelog (notably the presence of 'trailers', those being Officers who come in and clean up after SWAT has done their thing) not actually appearing in-game despite the Devs themselves listing them as being implemented.

The hallmark of 1.0, Commander Mode, is a weak and poorly implemented shadow of a storyline intended to act as a 'campaign' whilst having no narrative or storyline whatsoever, with the closest thing to a cutscene we receive being the audio-only briefing available on our in-game tablets.

The Stress mechanic does NOT work well with the hyper-aggressive new SWAT AI (which, tactically, is a major improvement, however is a let down in nearly every other regard) and essentially makes the Commander Mode, the only singleplayer mode in which one can enjoy the game with AI companions, a clunky XCOM-esque micromanagment simulator, and that is without even touching on the ludicrous new mission requirements for S rank, the restrictive manner in which we are forced to play, AND the lack of ability to remove stress and linear level playthroughs whilst still playing singleplayer.

In short, 1.0 has overall reduced the content within the game, introduced countless bugs and issues, destroyed replayability and made the game effectively multiplayer only while managing to p*ss off and disappoint every player who happened to get hyped up at the prospect of Commander Mode being an ACTUAL story-based campaign (I know I was).

In conclusion, while I do indeed love this game and believe it to be the future of the Tac genre, it is absolutely NOT worth buying at this point in time. Come back in 3-6 months and check my review then- if VOID can get their collective sh*t together and unf*ck their game, I will gladly edit or even rewrite my review entirely.

Let the butthurt begin.


ONE MONTH UPDATE

As I'm sure many of you are aware, VOID just released Hotfix 2... a month after release. And still, the disappointment continues. Are we Asian Parents? Must be. For starters, their 'hot' fix fails to fix any of the issues I or my friends have encountered, bar one, that being suspect death animations.
Second, more lies and empty promises from VOID, as they promised Russian VAs on release, and yet still fail to even mention them when they talk about localisation in their 'hot' fix. Oh, and they managed to misspell Portuguese.
VOID and their moderators continue to lie, bully and silence anyone who dares to call them out on their thievery and failures. Their so-called 'brief' break was a longer holiday than I've ever had in my life for a job that was probably about as taxing as my morning dump.

For all of you who are tired of being told 'skill issue' or 'get gud' whenever you raise these legitimate concerns regarding the AI and poor overall work by the devs, take the video linked below. Post it, share it, spam it everywhere the Devs and their cult can be found huffing pure Copium in their Cope Dens. Don't let these c*nts gaslight you.

https://youtu.be/EiL1b3obwwI?si=CYmon7M-zRrc4Nyo

UPDATE: HOTFIX #3 (07/02/2024)
Hotfix 3 has, thankfully, tuned down the AI to playable levels, however, there are still a plethora of bugs and glitches that hamper the game from getting a positive review.
Now, you are unable to change which firearms you carry, no matter how many times you select one. Changing to certain loadouts will also crash your game completely, effectively limiting you to a fraction of the content you had access to prior.
Additionally, wedges can now no longer be placed under certain doors. The prompt simply does not appear.

These are just two issues I've noticed after playing for another couple of hours. Some may say "it's a mod issue, remove your mods" but no, it's not. I tested it. I uninstalled my FOUR mods (I know, I'm practically playing an entirely different game, it's soooo many) and it still didn't work. Even if that was the case, you shouldn't be forced to play vanilla in order to play with different guns or not have your game crash.
People are having RAMPANT issues with game crashes, including my friends and I.
The devs need to bring back all the content (namely maps/mods) they cut from Early Access, as well.

Still do not recommend, although the game is actually worth buying now, it should still be in EA/at EA prices.

[h1] Before 1.0 I had an on-off-relationship with RoN. I knew I had sth. special at hand, but many things were holding it back. Now RoN pulls me in. Unfortunately the issues the game still has, though minor on their own and having very strong gameplay core, leave the impression, that it hasn't left beta yet and bring it close to a point, where it is hard to recommend, to players who have a perfectionist play style, in which these problems become a game breaking issue.[/h1] 

RoN is among the best in this medium in handling violence. RoN (among few others) taught me how I want violence to be shown in games I play: dark, gritty and brutal, with no glorification about what is going on. In RoN violence never is fun. The game makes a statement by letting the violence speak for itself; not shying away from the dark theme; rewarding the least violent gameplay; shocking settings close to reality and impactful environmental story telling. It is an important, grown up, mature game, like we have seen very few, if at all and it achieves this without additional commentary. Everything done well in this game, serves this purpose.

The Maps, already amazing pre-1.0, now 18 in total, all very different from eachother, having their own narratives: dark, gritty and beautiful merged into one another or in opposite contrasts on the same map, delivering scenarios that mirror the hell, real life can be. Don't spoil yourself: the missions develop their narrative, while doing them. At times, I stopped playing for a moment, due to their emotional impact. At the same time you get interesting cqc-puzzles, not easy but fun to solve, without being streamlined for purposes of game play. Only later on the maps feel too big. It didn't worry me much, but it might others.

The enemy AI may be one of the best I have seen. Suspects react in the frame of their training, state of mind and have a very diverse pool of behaviors. It rarely felt like I was encountering the same of enemies on different maps and the voice lines enhanced the atmosphere. However, the AI is still not where it should be: most at the time they are too accurate, react too fast and see you even through pixel peeks. Especially in none lethal attempts - the only way to get a S-rating - they respond late to gas and stinger grenades. This is easily solved by very good in-game mods. But for a game at full release, the vanilla AI, while very impressive overall, is a game breaker when it comes to its aim bot qualities.

The SWAT AI in SP also does its part. You have to control your team on every step. Easy to command for tight gameplay the AI enhances the seriousness of the missions. One mistake can cost a team members live and on the higher levels micromanagement is very important. The game is unfair by design. Counter balances are your wits, tactics and team control. Simultaneously the game was not taken from me: I was an active commander, who had to be ahead of the game by preparing the encounters for my team. I found this puzzle very compelling and interesting to solve. However: the more I went down the rabbit hole, the more I had to navigate wrong or no responses. Minor at first, it became a real problem, once I was going for the most difficult achievements. It definetly ruined a considerable number of runs. I am OK with dying to my mistakes, but when have to play around broken mechanics, that's an issue. 

That said: all this is better, than playing with randoms. That's where the real chaos happens.

Unfortunately SP is the weakest part of the game right now, which is really disappointing. Providing nice challenges and unlocks,  managing the stress level of your SWAT-Teamin in particular  – while in itself a good idea - has no real impact. You will always have a full team, even with every SWAT-member in therapy, dead or incapitated. And this mechanic is the selling point of the SP. But every level is available in MP anyways. That way there is no point in the SP-campaign besides the unlocks. 

And there are  other problems: fps issues, not game breaking but noticable; guns not different enough, to even bother; smg's are useless; no weapon stats; limited number of loadouts you can save, the game doesn't tell you: saved loadouts get lost. All these issues don't hurt the game at first sight: RoN could be a 9 or 10/10 but all this added up over time and RoN it is closer to a 7 or 8/10. This is underlined by the fact, that game modes from early access have been removed in 1.0.  This hurts the staying power of the game at least for now. 

One has to notice, the issues mentioned are especially noticable, due to everything else being so strong and a gameplay, that is all about micromanaging tactics. Flaws become more obvious, than in other games or genres. The developer has shown that he cares and is trustworthy. I'm sure, these things will come or be patched. RoN is inspite its problems one of the best games I have ever played, which is why I still recommend it. But it would be ignorant, not to mention its problems and at this point I have to say: depending on how hardcore your approach is, these unfortunately are close to gamebreaking.

[h1] In sum RoN is a diamond in the rough for any player who likes hardcore tactical shooters, doesn't shy away from difficult themes and want them to be taken seriously in a morally responsible manner. RoN is for those reasons a thematically heavy and difficult game. Besides its issues, RoN manages to set new standards in the genre or maybe gaming overall, even when this might not be noticed by a broader player base. More hardcore players though, might have to consider the issues the game has until they are fixed. I love the game but there is no denial that it became a disappointment over time.[/h1]

i bought the game for early access n' all. wanted to wait 'til release to review it. 

so, i only play commander mode since i dont have any friends that play ron, so everything i say will be based on that.

the levels are good. i like them, however, a few depict fairly sensitive topics (and ive heard the ron team is planning to add a literal school to the game) 

honestly, my biggest problem with the release is that i like to play whatever level i want whenever i want, i dont want to have to complete other levels to access a level. 
[spoiler] god i freaking hate that i cannot just throw a teargas grenade at amos voll right now [/spoiler] 

the guns feel good to use, responsive n' all and i like that. 

the suspects have smart AI's... which is all fun until you realize that they have automatics and that basically any headshot is gonna kill you (ive had memories where i open a door and immediately die to a makarov-using suspect)

the taser is not just a typical sidearm now which is cool, and you can have other pistols with it
the SWAT ai is now a lot smarter than in the early access and they're just more useful 
they'll report suspects for you, they'll arrest people for you, all without the need for you to order it (unlike early access)

 (ok this one was patched for the most part so mostly disregard this) AND THE SUBTITLES. lol the subtitles are HILLLLLLARIOUS. they get quite a bit wrong, like for example, the subtitles say "merit" when judge actually said "mirror it" or, "talk" instead of "TOC" -- even "wand it." becomes "want it?" -- i get how "wand it" can be mistaken for "want it" but thats legit kinda funny 

also i freaking HATE the officer stress system this is a tactical shooter not the freaking sims games. its easy to get the hang of but somehow officers can spend like 324765239 years in therapy. as im writing this i have 3 officers in therapy, ive been playing so much its clear that i dont touch grass and theyre still in therapy.  like literally how are they still in therapy, thats 5 real-life hours. and like, ingame thats canonically weeks -- so like, idk, either theyre doing real wacky things with their therapists, or theyre living in the therapists office. 

tl;dr buy the freaking game if you have money.  [spoiler] look if you really need a "tl;dr" paraphrase, you either have a low attention span or you suck at reading and avoid it like the plague. why am i writing one of those essay reviews you might ask? well its 'cause its fun! i love typing! The game looks great, and it's a sound platform to keep building on. There are some framerate issues, especially when just starting a level, but they smooth out within a minute. The game design is excellent, and I really see this as a worthy successor to the old S.W.A.T-games. However, the game has one fatal flaw, which means it'll be a refund for me; the AI is shit.
Not only are the enemies elite 360noscope gods with wallhack enabled, but your team members are as bad as the enemies are good, and they constantly get in your way and refuse to move.  
Furthermore, since the game's release you've been forced into a campaign-ish mode, where you need to babysit your team members, so they don't get PTSD. Try to be tactical and arrest all suspects, and die trying? Tough titties, now you gotta send your whole team to the shrink, or else they'll be sat in a corner in the fetal position the next mission. This forced game mode means the safest bet is to go in all guns blazing, full-autoing everything that moves, consequences be damned, because trying to arrest someone could get you or a teammate killed. At least it's realistic, and I now understand why US cops are so triggerhappy.

There should be a toggle between fun mode and commander mode.

It wasn't ready. Everyone points out the ridiculous aim of the enemies, but there are so many more problems than that that become more apparent the more you play.
First of all, the SWAT AI still sucks.
-they don't take cover
-they shoot blindly into walls at enemies even when using pepperballs and wasting ammo (which the enemy has an endless supply of that they take full advantage of)
-they botch their grenade throws constantly (hitting object in room, hitting doorway and affecting team, missing enemies entirely
-they stray away to pick up evidence and secure suspects/civilians when you don't want them to and subsequently get shot to pieces
-they let suspects take the first shot even when using nonlethal arms
-their pathfinding messes up so sometimes when you order them to stack on a door or follow you they'll wander off somewhere else (where, I don't know since they die before I find out)
-can't navigate around you so you have to move out of their way and don't recognize when you're trying to enter the stack
-just plain don't listen to some orders, like telling one to watch a direction

other things of note:
-bullet penetration feels VERY biased in favor of suspects. Bullet penetration is so inconsistent that sometimes armor-piercing bullets can't penetrate wooden doors or cardboard walls. Maybe the same goes for the enemies, but they have the advantage of infinite ammo to full-auto and suppress you with all the time.
-vision is weird. Some windows that you can see out of easy are seemingly opaque to suspects, while others that you can barely see through they'll lock on to you through. Peeking feels worthless with how the enemy can identify you by your earlobe and just as easily shoot it off
-your aim suffers when moving, but the enemy can strafe-sprint and gun you down 40m away no problem

weirdly missing or removed features:
-level ranks aren't visible until you beat them again
-weapons and attachments have little-to-no statistics or explanations. only way to figure out the differences is to feel them out by test firing and comparing, which the game makes annoying by placing the loadout and firing range/training room far away. attachments have a vague "more accurate, less recoil" tag with them, but they don't help you compare attachments against each other. there are 2 night vision headsets and I have no idea what the functional difference between them is since the game doesn't explain jack. 

there's so much that's messed up right that I can't even put into writing. I urge you to not buy the game until the devs at least make a statement about the direction of the game going forward.

Positive:
A Good tactical game.

Negative things for updates/patches: 
1. At a certain point way too early, heavy armor and shields become the default loadout for your AI.  Boring.

2. We need to be able to set up delayed breaches. IE: I want to approach a space from 2 angles and can't give commands to the AI remotely or have red and blue breach their different spaces at the same time. 

3. There are not enough small to medium maps for a two-player co-op. 

4. Should be able to resurrect downed human players or treat downed players. eh.

5. Al should have the option to order the AI point-blank (Gas from behind a closed door works), short-throw, or long-throw munitions.  

6. Pepper pistol for when using the shield.

7. A sniper for missions with big spaces for overwatch.

8. Speaking of two-player co-op, each player should control one AI bot.

9.  Red teammates should stay together, and blue teammates should stay together their constant mixing has delayed so many actions as they run back to each other.

10. When arresting a named suspect AI should try not to off the target.

Not worth a dime unless they greatly fix this game, and actually apologise to the community.

People are defending the game and developers, saying it's skill issue. The skill issue has come up in so many posts on the forums from so many trolls, who state the game is perfect as it is!

 Perhaps they are right the developers didn't have the skill to create believable and fun AI. They made AI with Aimbot that can track you and shoot you through multiple surfaces regardless of ammo or gun type!

 They also lacked the skill to complete and polish a game with little to no bugs. There are videos of all the bugs inside of the release of 1.0, which don't even talk about the horrible AI.

 They probably even have the lack of skill to communicate with the community who are very upset. There was hardly any communication for a year just repeated new postings of their current status of the game. Once they released the game in December they then took a month break, and had 0 communication with the community. In-fact they still have not replied to a single forum post!

Most of these reviews were made before the release of 1.0, so there is still a very positive experience, based on pre 1.0. Content has been removed or broken from 1.0 so these reviews are not even up to date with experiences.

This game is a bare-bones shooter with auto aim bots who react faster than humans can in real life. they know where you are at all times soon as you make a noise on the map due to how your tracked by the ai. Many users are complaining about horrible performance on decent hardware. Not to mention some of the features in the game such as bounce lights don't even activate in the options menu!

There are features in game trailers during EA that have all been cut from the final release which is 1.0. As well as the latest trailer depicts a game with a story-line and cinematic. There are no cut scenes, just dialogue you can hear before a mission and see some photos taken!

The developers are relying on you not to look at the negative reviews and just assume the negative reviews are trolls. They are relying on people with no integrity, to praise this game for it's pretty graphics. They are expecting people to use mods to be able to enjoy their game, and fix the issues they can't be bothered to fix. 

There are even rumours going around that VOID is making a new game now, and will not be supporting this game, or giving the game the huge of amount of support the game needs to be a fully functioning game as advertised.

Don't listen to the positive reviews, they are either lying or trolls, or accept a broken game that has pretty graphics as an excuse that the game will be patched later on. 

There has been no communication from anyone from the company on the public forums at all. The community has been torn apart between those who hate the game, or want a refund, and the trolls who say the game is great, and it's a skill issue!

If you still choose to buy this game after everything I have listed in it's current state, then you are the reason game developers continue to release game unfinished, and the community accepts this waiting for a patch that may never come!

I love tactical shooters. Grew up playing all the old Rainbow Six games and Swat games. 
Ready or Not at $50 is overpriced. The "AI" are just laser aim bots. I get it's supposed to be hard. But in a game (key word game) where you aren't just shooting your way through a level. You need to attempt to arrest the targets. Which sometime is impossible leading to you or your team getting shot and killed. Putting your own laser bots up against them is sometimes the best option. The Leader moral aspect is a cool idea although I feel definitely needs work. Honestly my biggest gripe about the game is simply how long it takes to get back into a mission. I don't want to see a silly grading scale I can't skip. Just to have to walk back through the damn station, select the same mission and wait for a timer to tick down. I'm playing single player, why do I have to wait around? Movement speeds is ridiculous I get you don't want players sprinting around. But to make us be forced to move at a ridiculously slow speed when getting around a corner to get sights on methed out cyborgs is the order is just unfair. That is not how SWAT moves. Give us some realistic speed, but make the AI respond to it. More speed more noise, more noise more likely AI investigate or just start executing hostages. 

All them guns but I can't use them? Get lost.

One thing I'd suggest is considering a virtual reality version. The gameplay and graphics are ripe for VR, and I think it could be a hit in that space with some development. Also, I feel the game could benefit from tougher AI bots. As it stands, they can be a bit too easy, leading to a somewhat lax approach when clearing rooms or dealing with enemies. If the bots were more of a challenge, it would force players to stick to tight tactics and stay alert. While there are mods out there that tweak the bots' behavior and intelligence, they don't fully solve the issue.

I was in fact, not ready. This one of the hardest and most painfully frustrating games I’ve ever played, and I love it so damn much. With each failure comes a new strategy to try and it’s so satisfying to see those strategies work. Be prepared to be stuck on one mission for 8+ hours (Greased Palms made me verbally abuse my whole neighborhood). The AI is stupid cracked, makes Call of Duty Veteran/Realism mode look like light work. You could be absolutely saucing a 20 minute run through, 95% of the way completed, and get a bullet placed square in the temple from a Yemen terrorist with an AK, hiding behind a box 50 yards away. But you just can’t help but run it back up and try again. If you don’t like learning curves, have little patience, and need to play something that will hold your hand every step of the way, then you would absolutely hate this game. Ready or Not is where boys become men.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

There are 3 major problems:
1-When a gun is shot within a few meters of you your screen gets blurry and shaky and full of smoke basically turning you blind and mitigating your abilities of responding fire. This makes NO SENSE, that is not how guns work. A experienced ember of swat should be able to maintain composure during a firefight, one of the first things you learn when shooting is NOT to flinch or close your eyes,  this is nothing more than theatrics at the expense of realism and gameplay. I hate to see a game with gunplay so realistic have such a stupid and easy to fix problem.
2- The bots AI has improved massively but is still not enough. Bots will often walk into rooms without checking their corners, they will shoot through civilians to get to enemies, they will randomly switch to their sidearms they flash rooms too slowly leading to enemies shooting them while they wait in front of an open door, among other problems. And in multiplayer people play like its COD, so unless you have some friends who are interested in buying the game and playing with you this will be a major problem.
3- you cant shoot anyone to get S rank, even if you do not kill anyone and just injure them, you will still not get S rank. Simply stupid. In real life the rules of engagement are very simple: If a subject is pointing a gun at you, shoot to kill. If a subject is brandishing a gun and refusing to comply, use of force is authorized. Death of an armed suspect is completely expected and not frowned upon. The perfect run is a run in which the basic objectives are completed without the injury of any civilians or officers, that should be the criteria for an S run.
There are other small problems here and there but that is most of it. I am aware the game will continue to receive updates and I am willing to change my review in the future, but for now the game is not worth this much money.

I've played a bit of this game on multiplayer, and from my experience, I would say don't waste your money while it's full price. If you could get the game for 25 bucks on sale then go for it if you're really interested, but otherwise, maybe consider finding another game like Insurgency Sandstorm, Arma, or some of the other realistic shooters out there.

Before I elaborate on why I say this, here's some pro's and con's that I've found with the game, in my opinion.

Pros...

* Pretty great graphics overall. (Guns look great, building and environment textures look great.)

* Movement is smooth, and feels pretty good. (Slow, "realism" movement style?)

* Sound effects for guns are alright.

* Can be fun with friends with mods, and once you have the maps memorized

* Some bugs and glitches can be pretty funny in multiplayer


Cons...

* Many, many bugs and glitches, including *some* game breaking ones. (Ex. gun disappearing, animation locks repeating while fighting, laser attachments suddenly disappearing, attachments always showing your flashlight even if you choose a laser attachment, etc.)

* Ballistics aren't real. There are times where you can magdump an enemy from maybe 10 feet away aiming center mass, and the enemy will either keep shooting you without being affected, or they might start twitching like they're getting stung by bees just to raise their gun and blast you while you're reloading.

* AI is pretty poorly designed. They do some cool things like pretending to surrender, however I'm referring to the important part of the AI. It is very common for enemies to track you through walls, and sometimes you'll even hear them shooting at you from another room, without ever having seen you. It is also important to note that when this happens, they tend to shoot through one or two walls and can hit you. This usually happens when they are relatively close, not when they are across the map. Also, there are plenty of times where you can see an enemy standing against an object or wall looking directly at you through said object, with their gun raised.

* Playing in hand with my previous point-- shooting through walls. This is a pretty major issue with the game at its current state. Countless retries have been caused by an enemy shooting me directly through walls, doors, statues, trees, and pretty much every other object you can find in the game. Most commonly, this happens through two objects at the same time. For example, you might have an enemy ahead of you that is inside of a building, but they manage to shoot directly at you through both a wall and a tree at the same time. It can be pretty frustrating, and the only thing that has often kept me playing was spite for the AI.

Now, you may think that this has a simple solution. Just spray and pray through the walls and doors. Unfortunately, these same physics don't apply to your character. Enemies will shoot you through metal doors, but if you dump multiple magazines through the same object directly back at them, the chances are slim that you'll damage them. I've tried plenty of times, especially through wooden interior doors, to no avail. Keep in mind that you can sometimes see their arms and guns poking through the doors, and while you mag dump them through the door, they will stand completely still and not take any damage at all. This is one of my biggest gripes with the game, aside from the AI tracking you through the entire map.

* Lack of updates, bug fixes, or really anything. The developers haven't really done much to the game since its release other than a few minor hot fixes to my knowledge. 

* Customization. Customization is another thing that I don't really like with this game. There's quite a few unlockables you can get by playing the game and beating missions with high ratings at the end (B, A, S, etc.), but it seems very half-assed. Most of the clothing does not match, unless if you want to wear all black clothes, or gray. There are, of course, different colours and camo's like multicam, black multicam AOR1, AOR2, green, and blue. However, you'll be hard pressed to match your top, bottom, armor, and/or helmet with any of the listed colors. 

What I mean, is that you may unlock green pants and a green shirt, but they're not the same green. Somehow, the colors and camos noticeably do not match each other on different pieces of clothing. There are a few that come pretty close, but usually never the same. The AOR2 clothing is usually different shades of the same camo, and sometimes the camo looks slightly different. It's hard to explain, but its almost as if the texture might have been stretched for, lets say, a shirt, and shrunk for the pants. The same goes for the solid colors. The green shirts don't match the green pants, which don't match the green armor.

It may seem like a silly complaint, but the reason why I mention it is because I fail to see a point in including the different customization things when none of them match in the first place.



Anyway, overall the game can be fun if you aren't against replaying the same missions mid to late game over and over again until you can get an S, but I wouldn't buy at full price because of the state it's in. I would also highly recommend looking into some mods to make the game a little more enjoyable.

AI has been broken for a few updates and devs do nothing about it. The game is meant to be hard and stressful, but in a mission based in a post office shipping facility, AI will just wallbang you with no indication that they are even on the other side. At first I thought it was between packages and they just had super vision or something until I witnessed a barrage of gunfire with audio queues in front of me, and impacts in front of me straight through a blue wall. There was no gap and there was no way that he saw a pixel of me from the other side, just terrible AI. And everytime you die, your team freaks out like and either quits or goes to therapy, forcing you to get a new team while 3 of your guys spend 3 months in therapy and are just completely useless. Any progression with your team just goes straight down the toilet instantly.

TLDR: Great game with great mechanics and realism, but with equally terrible and gamebreaking AI. If you want to get it on sale, it might be worth, but $50 for an unplayable game is ridiculous.

Also optimization is not the best, but not the worst.

[h1]steam decided to eat my previous update to the review so I wont bother typing out the full version again, but here is a short summary: [/h1]


[h3]1. old review as of may 2023 found the game to be broken and development momentum to be lost[/h3]
[b]i.VOID had a jolt of creativity but development slowed down and communications broke down,[/b] they then resorted to their "newsletters" and "developmental updates" to try and keep the playerbase happy, and the effects are as expected.
[b]ii.the hype was real closer to the actual 1.0 launch,[/b] where the simps happily licked VOID's boots and proclaimed that all the haters will be proved wrong

[h3]2. 1.0 update has brought about some positive changes [/h3]
[b]i.vastly improved SWAT AI,[/b] where your bot teammates will now proactively clear rooms, secure personnel and bag evidence. They can also be told to search and secure areas, making it much easier to find that last stupid civie
[b]ii.new weapons and locations,[/b] we got a bulpup rifle that would hopefully be less prone to running into walls, new and really gorgeous maps and the "story line" is starting to form
[b]iii.ability to highlight evidence,[/b] which should honestly be enabled by default. well at least it is available now

[h3]3. unfortunately, VOID being VOID, updating the game somehow reminds us of how much is actually lacking [/h3]
[b]i.new maps are not optimized at all and fps is low on even decent hardware,[/b] forcing graphics downgrades and defeating the whole point of making those new maps nice looking.
[b]ii.newly added mechanics are broken,[/b] as the officer stress level system is completely ridiculous. The best way to play is now to just unlock as many slots as possible then let them resign whenever, since you cannot send them to therapy until they are literally about to break. Why bother adding "personal traits" when your game mechanics do not even allow for the officers to stick around for more than a couple missions?
[b]iii.hit reg and throwables are still inconsistent,[/b] CS gas being the obvious thing (and it also still magically dissipates in less than a minute), pepper ball feels slightly better but is still a joke, and actual bullets occasionally just stop working, too

[h3]4. and perhaps even more concerning[/h3]
[b]i.RON is still a point and click FPS, not a police simulator,[/b] AI are still going terminator with their aim and nonlethal options are too weak, with the embarrassingly bad animations and transitions still being a thing, leaving the player with little to no choice during engagements
[b]ii.VOID has now adopted the tone of "yea we meant to do that",[/b] spewing utter nonsense such as "AI is supposed to shoot through walls, we just made them a bit too accurate", and "spamming voiceline and waiting for a reaction is a solution for finding the missing civies". this is a new low even for them

 [h1]to summarize: 1.0 as a milestone means nothing if the actual game breaking issues are not addressed (which is the case here).  [/h1]
this update would be much better received if it came out as an regular update, not the crossover from early testing to official release. moving the goal post does not actually mean progress. and look, I really want RON to succeed here, because honestly why tf would I not want a SWAT simulator that I paid so much money for to be good? Ironically, the game is far from ready, yet VOID is adamant on pushing it out the door.

Before you buy, go search up Ready or Not AI on youtube and decide weather this game is for you after a few videos.

AI has no weapon collision, they just point the rifle through walls and shoots you dead as you struggle to keep your weapon up when standing behind a teammate holding a shield that is crouched in front of you.

The same traps that instantly kill your fully trained and armoured SWAT officer will only cause the AI to flinch.

Their pistol calibre weapons seem to have more penetration through walls than your armour piercing rifle rounds.

They seem to be able to see through smoke perfectly as long as they aren't inside it despite you being unable to see through the smoke at all.

They can shoot with near perfect accuracy when moving at almost full speed while you can barely keep your weapon steady unless you're slow walking or crouched.

The AI can somehow hear you arresting someone or telling them to surrender better than you shooting an unsuppressed firearm in an enclosed space.

At this point you aren't a SWAT team fighting gangsters and criminals.

You're a team of militiamen fighting a legion of superhuman bio-weapons.

In its current state, the game is a garbage heap. Multiple new features promised with their 1.0 release are broken and not present at launch, and other features previously in early access versions are gone completely. The enemy AI is a mess, somehow landing in both the laughably stupid and frustratingly overpowered/broken categories. Your SWAT team however, will get stuck on doors, walls, each other, and many times just refuse to obey your commands like restraining suspects, leading to them just picking their guns back up and shooting you because you took too long to restrain them. There is no setting to make your team go less-lethal only, and though you can equip your mates with less-lethal primaries, they will still switch to their pistols in some situations and routinely kill suspects that way, failing any S-rank run you were going for. You can then however, take the ammo out of their pistols, but they will still switch to them, pointing empty guns at suspects until said suspects gun them down. In rare cases, even though you took all the ammo out of their sidearms, they will still spawn a single bullet into their guns when they swap to them, killing the suspect anyway. Commander mode lacks a quick restart button, making the gameplay loop essentially: load to the menu, load to the lobby, load to the mission, you or a squadmate gets killed because the AI is terrible, close the game, re-launch the game, rinse and repeat from step 1. Cant recommend in its current state, while there is fun to be had, it fades fast and the game becomes more and more aggravating with each restart. If they fix some of the more glaring issues, I will probably give it another try. The game feels close to greatness but still so far at the same time.

Ready or not is an enjoyable tactical challenge but it could be excellent. 

It offers a refreshing FPS experience that forces you to think how you approach every corner, and the pace of the game is much slower than your typical action shooters like call of duty or battlefield. If you attempt to move with haste, the game will severely punish you. This lends more weight to your decisions, and when you are successful in clearing a room, there is a reasonable sense of achievement which is accomplished without having to give cliched cosmetics that are attempting to drive the rest of the industry. When you do clear a level, sure, the cosmetics earned are a bit more sensible to give a tangible reward, but if you were to ask me, the reward is in the entertainment of seeing a room successfully cleared. 

The major short comings of the game for me is that there are no characters, or character development in the game, and a limited AI (though I think this is slowly improving), which could take this tactical engagement to the next level. The AI enemies and hostages are generally superficial, and this probably could be developed a bit more, but I dont think the team have the resources to develop this out like a standard AAA game. More enemies are scattered through the map than would be realistic in real life situations - though this is the game attempting to jack up the difficulty in what would otherwise be a 'too easy' situation. The hostages are boring, and I would like to see them react more dramatically to stressful situations. 
The team AI are not bad, but I would like to see more robust teams that replicate real life SWAT. It would be nice to be able to command the team remotely, as you have to move your team mates through line of sight commands. i.e. its not easy to have your AI squad flank around the other side of the map. It would be nice to have more AI team mates, and approach situations from multiple simultaneous angles like a real life SWAT. Too often I find the AI can flank me, because I cant move my team efficiently. 

All in all a good experience, but I would just like to see a bit more development in how the AI handle, some character development and some more realistic situations. I feel the latter is not currently achievable as it would probably blow the budget out for the developers - but in time and perhaps if there is a strong community and reasonable sales, iterations of the game could possibly make this one of the best FPS franchises - but it will require smart development leadership.

The full release of this game has been disappointing. Instead of fixing the underlying issues with enemy AI behaviors and nonsensical gameplay (like not being able to rush a shooter), the devs instead figured that they should keep adding maps and a needless therapy system rather than fix the underlying issues people have complained about for years. Suspects will shoot you through walls like concrete barriers, and on some maps the devs decided to add several one-way viewports for the AI to do this safely. SWAT Officers are given tasks that shouldn't be theirs, like securing evidence. The viewmodel inertia feels horrible, like my arms are made of jelly. The only progression and unlocks is cosmetic and for new missions, some of which are like torture of the balls.
This game does not look good in my opinion, as it visually fails to stand out in a world full of Unreal Engine tactical shooters like Insurgency and Squad, and a whole lot more. It's as if tactical shooters in Unreal Engine should be its own genre.
Also the game has several instances of AI generated artwork which screams to me either laziness or a need to rush a 1.0 version through the door to sell more copies.
I feel like the development of this game has been painfully slow already, and the fact that the devs have refused to listen to feedback and fix what's already there makes me lose interest in playing this game any further. I think I would rather play Six Days in Fallujah (another Unreal Engine tactical shooter) where the AI at least behaves as they should, and I can use my legs to move faster than a brisk walk.
With the label of early access I might have recommended this game, but seeing as this is supposed to be the finished product I can no longer endorse it.

Cons

Great game but they broke their game loop when they removed the single player restart button.

Right now, you start the game and get a loading screen.
Choose single player, loading screen.
Get to your precinct, walk to the map picker.
Click to choose a map, loading screen.
Choose map, loading screen.
Ready up for the map, wait 5 seconds, loading screen.
Finally the gameplay starts. This is very fun.
Things go very badly, as it does.
Now I get an unskippable score screen to tell me ive failed.
Only option I get is to go back to the precinct. So. Loading screen.
Spawn into precinct. Walk to mission board. Go to select mission. Loading screen.
Select mission. Loading screen.

Rinse and repeat.

Bring back the restart button in singleplayer so when things go bad its not a full ten minutes before you get to play the game again. I understand trying to go for a simulator aspect but when it kills the gameplay, its pretty bad.

The developers still haven't fixed major issues with the game (some of which weren't present in early access at all) and have only put out two hotfixes since it's "full release" 1.0 version on December 13th. They still haven't given their supporters the soundtrack that was promised upon full release or the 1.0 version. The AI of the game has become worse than it previously was in early access. There's accurate wallbanging from suspects as if they can see you through walls (which from my testing and experience they absolutely can), They rarely ever instantly surrender after being pepperballed or at least stun they usually just keep full autoing you, they can run into you and stunlock you while still being able to shoot you while you can not shoot them as your gun goes into high ready, numerous new bugs and old bugs that weren't fixed and are still present from early access, the campaign mode "Commander Mode" is an absolute joke to even call it content. Commander Mode is essentially Practice Mode with named officers who do not have any unique attributes or personalities except their name and what they can do as an "ability". I type ability as "ability" because, people have tested them and most of them don't even work and you can't restart your mission you have to go back to base each time. There's essentially no point in playing Commander Mode unless you want a worse version of Practice Mode. Other than maybe the Permanent death aspect and the abilities that do work and of course the achievements and one cosmetic associated with the mode. I waited a really long time since 1.0 launch to make this review because, I had hope for this game, but as a Supporter Edition owner I can tell you they absolutely flopped this game which shows in it's plummeting review score and player base as of late. It can barely get above Resident Evil 4 Remakes player count. I really thought they would fix it by now, but as of February 2nd they have put out two hotfixes since release which was December 13th, neither addressing the major issues with the game. The player count is dropping and is abysmal for a CO-OP game, the developers are way to slow with updates and to make all this worse a lot of content was cut in version 1.0 or full release. I can't recommend this game again until we get the actual "full release" or "1.0 version". In my eyes for now, this game is worse than its early access version game play wise, which for a game like this with no story elements to care about is the worst outcome.

Once upon a time, I adored "Ready or Not." But that love affair has turned into a bitter breakup, thanks to the developers' misguided quest to turn every AI character into a superhuman killing machine. It's like the game's sole purpose is to punish players for daring to enjoy it.

Let's start with the absurdity of the AI. Apparently, the developers decided that even crackheads should be elite soldiers with X-ray vision and psychic abilities. Meanwhile, your character, armed to the teeth and clad in heavy armor, might as well be made of tissue paper for all the good it does. It takes a whole magazine to take down a guy in a hoodie, yet one shot from a revolver wielded by a crackhead through a closed door spells instant death. Talk about imbalance!

And don't even get me started on the bugs. Oh, the bugs! It's like the game is determined to find new and creative ways to sabotage your enjoyment. Mission-breaking glitches, crashes, you name it, "Ready or Not" has it all. It's like the developers wanted to add an extra layer of challenge by making sure you never know if you'll actually be able to finish a mission before the game implodes.

And let's not forget the joy of trying to go non-lethal. Spoiler alert: it's impossible. Pepper spray, tasers, flashbangs - none of it fazes these AI killing machines. They'll just keep coming at you, guns blazing, until you're lying in a pool of your own frustration.

In short, "Ready or Not" went from being an awesome game to a lesson in game design gone wrong. Save yourself the headache and steer clear of this mess unless you enjoy banging your head against the wall in frustration.

TLDR: Very mixed feelings about this game. I really want to enjoy playing this game, but it's extremely frustrating at times. The AI needs an overhaul especially the AI that is with you. Half the time they end up just blocking you in entry ways and I don't have the time to click and give them instructions to leave the room so I can actually exit. I mostly play now because of the mods. 

Pros:
- Great graphics
- Decent amount of customization thanks to the modding community
- Also a decent amount of maps to pick from 
- There's co-op which is nice if you want to play with others 
- Great amount of tools and gadgets to pick from 
- Firing range is half decent and you can run CQB drills

Cons: 
- The AI either end up blocking you in doorways, or killing you from across the map (hide and seek)
- No restart function for single player, but there is for multiplayer? why not implement things in both? 
- The game doesn't give you tips like when to use high-low or having a smaller firearm to peak around corners without getting blocked by terrain
- Diffusing takes too long. While I know this is a game it's still too long imo

Areas of improvement: 
- Be able to load directly into the briefing room
- More customization options for weapons such as barrel length, optics, grips, magazine size, canted sighting 
- AI not gatekeeping you from exiting a room or doorway 
- AI not flopping around when being restrained then throwing themselves 15ft into the air
- AI not allowing you to restrain so you have to be exposed for longer periods of time
Gun play is amazing and is a lot of fun.

Given McDewgout and SirToasti (I'm sure there are plenty more) having produced outstanding reviews explaining the issues of RoN, I feel very much cheated.

The main arguments include a comparison to SWAT 4, the slow pace to fixes, the unfinished product at release, and the backflipping of a statement during an AMA about dynamic lighting (first it was the unreal engine cannot allow for shooting lights out or disabling the fusebox to prepare for a night-vision raid, then it was backflipped after it was pointed out modders have done this already). This is just a few of the issues mentioned in SirToasti's video "Ready Or Not 1.0: OVERRATED & UNDERWHELMING".

In short, SWAT 4 had far fewer developers and managed a knock-out title in a couple of years. This title has been in development for nearly a decade. While it mostly copies or is inspired by (you choose) SWAT 4, I feel this title very much was not ready for launch and was likely a means to generate profits. I'll check in on the state of things after I finished an entire university degree....

EDIT: in regards to dynamic lighting issues.
Ubisoft produced Splinter Cell as a Metal Gear Solid Killer. What blew everyone out of the water with Splinter Cell was precisely dynamic lighting and audio; shoot out the lights and sneak up or around the map to complete your mission.
The fact games were created on (comparatively) sub-par hardware and software (ps2) and can outperform RoN reveals to me that the state of modern gaming is just abysmal.

Enemy AI ruins the game. Every enemy is suicidal, never surrenders even when having a pistol pointed point blank at their head (one pulled a pistol during this very situation and had his brains appropriately splattered less than a quarter second later), charges armed and armored swat teams solo, has as much health or more than ceramic plate body armor even when wearing a shirt and hoodie, and will randomly 1 shot you with a headshot when the game decides it wants you to start a level over just because. There is persistent teammate status in singleplayer that deteriorates when you do poorly, so you are randomly punished for things out of your control with no 'reload' option available.

Breaching takes too long, by the time one teammate opens a door for another to use a less-than-lethal grenade, they are getting shot to death by the people on the other side or the suspects have fleed.

The devs wanted to make a realistic game but made the enemies quake-level of twitchiness and cracked out while the player and their squad are as slow and sluggish as real life. (Movement is actually too slow for the player compared to real-life physically trained SWAT officers wearing armor and gear.) What was the development goal here, VOID? It was almost a great time. Almost.

This game has SO much good going for it, it just needs a couple changes before I can recommend it in it's current state, ESPECIALLY with the new $50 price tag.
[list]
[*] Sprinting. When you're a cop and your job is to run towards gunfire, you should be able to sprint. Violence of action is a valid strategy sometimes, and it's hard to be aggressive without the ability to run. 

[*] Multiplayer not only needs PVP, but also a rating system for PVE - There's an opportunity to do this in a really creative way, where you can view other player's stats (unauthorized UoFs, D-S rating finishes, etc.) as if it's an Internal Affairs report. In addition, "bad" cops should be paired with other "bad" cops in public matchmaking, so that the players who are actually trying to do well aren't dealing with as much trolling.

[*] AI (both SWAT and suspect) needs some more love, but I know this is hard to refine and that the devs are working hard on it. If suspects would stop aimbotting through walls as much, that would go a long way.
[/list]

Gun play is great and the game is very fun. I do wish the set of missions was a more balanced and realistic example of what real life SWAT deal with. It would be great to respond to a bunch of armed terrorists on one mission (which does happen in the game) and then the next mission respond to a phony bomb threat. The streamer mission comes to mind as one where I think it's a real shame that they decided it had to be connected to a child trafficking ring and a gang instead of simply having it be a streamer you go and arrest because of a "swatting" from an audience member. I do also wish that the suspect AI was more willing to surrender when a bunch of armed SWAT officers tell them to get on the floor or get shot. Finally I wish that there was less of a clear distinction between civilians and suspects. It would be excellent if those who seemed to be civilians could pull guns, suspects could spawn without a gun and try to grab one or pose as a a civilian until an officer stepped close enough for them to pull their knife on them, or if some missions had civilians who were lawfully carrying a concealed weapon or were roaming the halls of the building looking to shut down the same shooters you are while looking like they could be said shooter. Overall however, the game is fantastic and tons of fun. The SWAT AI teammates are great and playing it co-op with friends is also a great time. It's so much fun to methodically breach and clear every room or smoke out suspects with tear gas. Experiencing some of the story for the missions through the briefings and the environment is great too. I remember going through Brixley's Talent Time with my friends and after clearing a room we find a desk with an action figure and a doll arranged in such a way that they appeared to be having sex. The effect that had on us was incredible, it made us feel very immersed as we all said: "Jesus fucking Christ, these bastards are sick." The gun selection is great and the animations are excellent and realistic to each gun. For example, it's possible to check out many rounds you have in your active magazine, which with most guns involves briefly taking the magazine out of the weapon, checking it, and inserting it back in the gun. However, with the P90, the animation for checking how many rounds you have left in your magazine is just tilting the gun up slightly and looking at the magazine sitting on top of the gun, without unloading it. Overall it is a blast and if you enjoy games that are more realistic or slower & tactical, you will absolutely enjoy this game.

As an early access, Ready or Not bodes a benchmark experience for the tactical shooter genre once fully realized. 

Bottom line upfront: Totally worth the buy if only just to give you hope for the future

An exceptionally well handling and visceral shooter with an emphasis on darker tones. The world Void Int. is creating in its fictitious amalgamation of a West Coast mega metropolis is going to be very dark indeed, but let's be honest that's what we want. As a top-tier SWAT team we are playing the good guys, therefore the badder the bad guys, the "gooder" we feel right! Anyway, Void has showcased in early access well executed level design with immersive tiny details that make each environment feel truly unique. From filthy derelict ghetto housing slash methamphetamine labs to ultra-luxurious mansions slash tomb of reprehensible secrets, I am looking forward to inspecting every inch of the final game while genuinely feeling unsafe in the environment as a SWAT team leader hunting down armed and dangerous suspects. 

The weapons handling was given a lot of attention; Speed & Tac reloads, mag checks, swapping mags for different ammo types, even a thumb animation gives you a short visual and auditory que when switching selective fire, all these things will now forever make any "tactical" shooter without them a lesser competitor. 

Also, explosive breaching FINALLY looks passable in a game, much love. 

Looking forward to Void rounding the hard corners and shipping a polished gem that I am sure will set the tactical community ablaze with many many hours of entertainment. 


1.0 update:
Good - AI
New friendly and enemy AI improvements are noticeable, palpable upgrades to their individual competencies. Good guys pie and take rooms systematically, and automatically cuff and stuff bad guys and evidence. Makes them seem much more human. Bad guys will pull some sneaky tricks more often which keeps you on edge too. This is 1.0's greatest strength. 

Not so good - Single player
The commander mode is ok, its not much of a campaign as the missions are map specific, would have benefited more from a branch narrative where player score and evidence found directly influences the unfolding sequence. Also, this is supposed to be a full fledged SWAT team and I don't feel like im in command of anything besides 4 guys, because I am not. No snipers, K-9, negotiators, EOD robots, drone usage, cyber capabilities etc. These are tools a player should be able to use as a "SWAT commander" to tackle a volatile situation and preserve life. Probably too late for any of that but, there is also the plethora of type edit mistakes and unpolished audio clips that make it seem like the single player experience didn't get a thorough scrub before release. 

Bad - Mental Health
Ok guys, good idea but bad design. I like the idea of having to manage a team with personal elements, truly. But there is probably a better way to accomplish this with training and real injuries sustained during a mission. For example, maybe none of my officers have any advanced skills so I send them to a "tactical-paramedic" course. Which takes them out for awhile but upon their return then they unlock that trait. This would also prevent the annoying trend of having 5 of the same useless traits like pacifier on my squad. And if anyone gets shot in the plates maybe they sit out for a round, doctors orders. Or if they take heavy damage maybe longer. But a bunch of SWAT guys getting "anxious" just because they used lethal force, its a little unbalanced and not fun having to send them to therapy because they decided that SWAT plays too rough with pedophiles and terrorists. Lame

Really Bad - Planning 
The 'planning' element needs some serious work. First off, I have to decide between vague spawn points before the brief. Whoa cowboy, tell me whats going on before I commit to whatever 'back alley' or 'Side 1B' is. In addition, the player is not clearly shown starting locations on the tablet, this prevents orientation to the crisis site at mission start and you usually have to roam around for a minute to know where you are. Very annoying as this robs your sense of planning and limits your tactical approach to basically figure it out from 'the elevator' every time. Yes, in some crisis situations you wont have time to plan for a perfect raid with handy architectural interior layout's. BUT, even in the worst case scenario I WOULD know which side of the building I am starting on, and SHOULD be able to decide where I park my truck AFTER I hear mission details. It should be Mission Brief -> show map with clearly defined start locations -> choose one and then go. Ready or not is instead; Pick between "stairwell" or "elevator" -> here's a terrible napkin map with the start point you picked not even labeled on it -> into the mission blind 

Review over

A brief note about the genre, not Void int. 
Time, time is the most essential element of tactical dilemmas. Even more so than space because space is related to a problem with time. Time is not used effectively in this tactical shooter and it could have made them stand out more. Bomb threats on a countdown timer are cliche and uninspired (and not true to realistic IED's or conventional initiators as they are largely command det). How about a bunch of hostages that are going to get killed if you don't get to them after you are compromised. How about choosing the time of day for the assault? How about the number of civilians killed is directly related to how fast you can find and stop an active shooter. What about the Bank Robbers demand for a getaway car in 30 minutes or he starts blasting. Or serving a warrant to seize a pedophiles computer but if you take too long he fries his hard drive. No one in the genre does this (If I am mistaken let me know!) and its a huge gap in design for "tactical" shooters. Essentially, you can count down to a goal or count up to a goal and I just wish more games would put you against the clock. The goal could be mission pass/fail and it would put real contextual stress on your team as you attempt to bring order to chaos. Anyway, wow you read this far? Well, thanks friends, have fun being Ready!....or not.

Excellent atmosphere, mind-blowing missions, and excellent thriller. Especially if you play alone as it's perma-death.

--------
However, the optimisation a piece of crap, you gotta fix the issues for hours.
For 3060 I somehow managed to fix the freezes after some hours of research on forums. Yeah, I finally got rid of freezes, but sometimes the FPS drops up to 12-20, which I don't know how to fix.

----
Conclusion:

If you love shooters, action movies about police - this game would be an absolute brilliant for you.

Super good now compared to early access!
The accuracy on the npc's is a little insane tho, but still, the difficulty is welcome!

So maybe tone down the npc's aim just a tad, maybe make them flinch a little after getting 2 hits in the shoulder and arm.

And maybe some optimization since it can run a little choppy if you team up with friends in different countries.
Very realistic compared to normal fps tac shooters (val, cs) learning curve but it is fun :3

The magic of great visuals, sounds, animations and worldbuilding quickly fades after you're restarting the same level for the 10th time because a person on meth apparently becomes Chris Kyle and domes you without looking while your AI teammates are busy going around the entire building to open a door from the other side.

Playing with friends and mods elevates the experience, but we're laughing about the state of the game 50% of the time

It's pretty unrealistic. Combat-wise the "realism" ends up just being criminals with super-human reaction or the ability to eat half a clip as if we're playing Halo or Apex Legends. The setting and premise of the game overall is very good though. It will keep you hooked and replaying the same level 50 times, so I have to recommend it.

A bit clunky at times with the AI, especially during solo play. Managing the teams is fun, syncing breaches and running through maps flawlessly for that S rank non-lethal. But it can be tedious, managing each team clunky, sometimes spending so much time trying to get the AI to walk to the destination door (maybe 1/10 chance) or tabbing through actions that it feels like a minigame in itself. Sometimes the bad guys have made a decision before I've had time to get the AI to do what I want.

Online is a lot of fun (If you use you mic! A must!) with some connection issues or bugs with using the mission table, locking you out of interacting with the UI and forcing a restart. But by and large it plays exactly how you would expect it to. You and some Joe's kicking in the first door only to getting blown up because there was a door trap. The next run, there might be a bad guy, there might be nothing. It might not be until a few rooms in that you encounter resistance and BAM, another door trap because you got complacent. 
It's punishing in an "I KNEW IT!" way, and it's a lot of fun.
Buuut, sometimes the AI will just yeet you with precision accuracy cross-map and that can be tough.

In the end, I think it's a good game, with a good chunk of new maps recently added, standard character and weapon customization, and plenty of gadgets to make navigating those door traps as well as baddies a little easier, it has a lot to offer. But, selfishly, I want more.
With future map releases/updates and a better unlock/upgrade systems, game modes or another method to keep missions replayable for longer than S rank, I think this will be a THE SWAT SIM game for the foreseeable future.

It's pretty unplayable in its current state. The enemy bots are all expert marksmen, instantly able to get a 9x19 round through the gaps in your armor, see you through walls, and are all tactical geniuses. The friendly bots are all middle school drop outs, who will walk past suspects while said suspects are shooting at them, they will ignore orders, and stand there picking their nose while you get domed through a wall.

Throw in the performance issues, abundance of long loading screens, and the comparative lack of levels, and it's unfortunately not worth the money.

It's a shame, since the gun play is excellent and, when the suspects don't instantly blow your brains out, can be a lot of fun, but the issues with the AI and performance massively drag the game down.

[h1] F.B.I Open Up! [/h1] 
Ready or Not was the best selling game on Steam in the week after its release and has been celebrated as a spiritual successor to the Police Quest: SWAT series and early Rainbow Six games.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td] I absolutely love the graphics for Ready or Not. The night maps are the absolute best maps to play on. The lighting is top tier and the animations are some of the best out there in terms of shooting games. The flashbang effects are incredible and the particle effects are top tier. It truly looks impressive and intense. Every map is so unique from each other. Some having a weight of dread, some having a terrifying back story, etc. The graphics overall is just incredible, and feels Triple A worthy.
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]So Ready or Not finally released 1.0 and I have to say that it's pretty darn good! Each mission has a unique objective (for the most part). Some are pretty easy, but others can be a true challenge. You also now have a new Commander mode (basically a singleplayer campaign). in Commander mode, you'll be accompanied by up to four AI-controlled SWAT officers who will follow your orders to the dot. A new great feature added is the stress system for your SWAT teammates. You have Content (green) to Anxious (yellow), Stressed (orange), and Crisis (red). Make sure you give some of your SWAT members a rest so they can come back to a more stable mental health. It's a super unique feature and I'm all for it! You have a ton of weapons and a good amount of customization for a swat game. You have a choice of lethal and non lethal weapons that can make a difference in your endgame score and survivability. You do have to deal with traps and the enemy can trick you and kill you really fast so be on your toes! You can play singleplayer with bots, or co-op with friends. I do prefer co-op for this game, but I have to say that the AI bots have had a major overhaul in the 1.0 update. The AI teammates now are pretty good and follow orders much better than before. They will check under beds, closets, watch your back, and stack up in a much more realistic way. This game does have mod support which allows you to add new maps, weapons, attachments, skins, etc. This is an early access game so some of the game modes are not complete on all maps just yet. The developers are really active so expect a lot of new content and improvements in the future.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎭Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]The multiplayer makes this game perfect. It’s super easy to invite friends even when they have mods. There is no PVP mode in this game so it’s pure co-op. That’s not a problem for me, but some people may want it in the future. Personally I feel like the movement fits co-op only since you do move pretty slow. The game is beatable with 2 people, but having more is just so much easier (especially trying to get a S rank).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]With the mod support and the monthly updates, the playtime is pretty good. The game has a great challenge and the enemy spawn randomly each time you load a new match. The mod support is pretty good and you can even install modded maps to more replayability.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td] The sound effects are breathtaking. The gun shots are so punchy and sound like they can do some serious damage to you. The enemies can taunt you and make threats which is pretty immersive. The flashbangs are loud and sound really realistic. I am really impressed with the sound design. It’s one of the best games in terms of sound design. Also the music in this game reminds me alot of the movie HEAT. It's perfectly designed for the maps and will keep you on edge. Just incredible soundtracks throughout. Probably the only tactical shooter I recommend having the music on.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I have still seen some annoying bugs present that have not been fixed. For example the enemy AI will not react to some non lethal shots (not sure if this is a feature). Also the character customization menu doesn't show all the items properly (some items have a "no data" symbol on them). Nothing game breaking yet, which is a plus.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The performance has gotten worse since 1.0 for some odd reason. many people has had issues with DX11 (including me). The framerate will tank so low for no reason, then go back up to 60fps randomly. DX11 does feel broken on my end. Now the only way to play this for me is DX12, but even that can give me some annoying stutters that has gotten me killed multiple times. Now I am playing on a HDD so it may be worse for me than for others. If you have a higher end PC compared to me, then you will be fine.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Mod support
[*]Amazing gunplay
[*]Beautiful graphics
[*]Good optimization
[*]Amazing map design
[*]Incredible soundtracks
[*]Good amount of content
[*]Developers are really active
[*]Great character customization
[*]Commander mode is a welcome change
[*]Stress system for AI teammates is unique and immersive
[*]Enemy AI are pretty good (Some issues but better than most game in this genre)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]AI can be insanely accurate and fast
[*]Optimization has been a bit worse (DX11 feels broken and super stuttery)
[*]Some bugs are still present on 1.0 (also some new annoying ones)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]8.5/10
I would get this game on sale for around 25-50% off[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]This game has an extreme amount of potential and they are having a promising future. The content updates and mod support give me hope for a bright future for Ready or Not. If you are looking for a Swat game that you can play with your friend on, pick this gem up. This is the experience you been looking for.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

This game has so much potential but it is not worth purchasing in its current state, due to the following two reasons:

1. [b]OP AI.[/b] You will get one-tap wall-banged or prefired frustratingly often. It is ridiculous.

2. [b]Searching for civilians after all suspects are incapacitated.[/b] This can take upwards of 20 minutes at the end of a mission for literally no reason. This straight up does not have to be in the game. Even worse, sometimes civilians will bug and [b]not spawn at all[\b]. On top of ruining your score, the only way to confirm with certainty that this is the case is to spend a ridiculous amount of time inspecting every single inch of the map, wasting even more of your time.

Other than that, the game is really fun, especially played co-op. If and when these two issues are fixed (the devs have mentioned they will be addressed), I will revise my review to be positive.

Updated review: Having played this game from its early release I was hoping the update would fix many of the issues I found were critical to the enjoyment of the game. The biggest issue with this is the AI of the suspects. No matter where you are they will see you and you will get hit/die and have to restart the entire mission, usually one bullet will take you out despite wearing all the armour you can carry. Open a door, booom, they're standing behind it pointing a gun at you, enter any part of the building and they fire upon you, even from upstairs. Its so unrealistic and the response times of the AI suspects are far superior than any human.  The developers don't seem to mind that they have created a game that can take 25 - 50 attempts to finish a level because you get caught out by some random AI suspect appearing from nowhere with pinpoint accuracy on every shot. Seems a common gripe that developers wont address. We don't want it easy, just realistic.
