This game is bit like flying the Concorde: The equipment is high-speed, it's a beautiful work of art, it's been ruined by simple design flaws, and we'd all be willing to pay a lot of money if we weren't in imminent fear of a disaster every time it operated.

The AI is just game breaking. Enemies will see you through closed doors and shoot through the door before continuing to shoot you through the wall as you move off of the door. Enemies will also detect and shoot you through smoke, frosted windows, anything that isn't coded as a completely solid surface. You call out to enemies to surrender and before you even get a chance to react, they're shooting you. But if you shoot the man armed with an AK facing your direction before calling out, you might fail the mission. He's not going to throw down the gun but you need to wear a few bullets before the game considers shooting the dude who planted explosives and is looking at you while holding an AR justified. 

Unfortunately, if it were just the enemies it would be one thing, but your team is also borderline suicidal. You just killed an enemy who was rounding a corner at the end of a long hallway? Well, there goes your teammate running past you into the middle of the exposed hall to secure the weapon he dropped. Tell a friendly to secure a suspect you convinced to surrender? He's going to walk circles around the suspect before the suspect gets bored and starts to move for a gun upon which your teammate will instantly execute him.

How is it that you're expected to secure a sprawling 10 acre facility crawling with a dozen or more heavily armed gang members with a 5 man SWAT team? While simultaneously there's no over-watch or surveillance. Suspects will run a quarter of a mile on city streets around the exteriors of buildings with no issue or warning or police cordon to deter of slow them down. You'd best be prepared to jam every door so that no one comes sneaking out behind you. I guess the defund the police movement hit Los [strike]Angeles[/strike] Sueños PD really hard if the city can only afford 1 SWAT officer on duty per million residents.

This game makes me sad because it could have been so good. It's a mess bordering on greatness.

Straight off the bat, I'm going to recommend you DON'T play single player as I see too many reviews complaining about them. You'll get the best experience in Multiplayer, and there are tons of multiplayer servers.

You can only join a multiplayer server if they're at headquarters and not in a mission, so if you're repeatedly trying to join and it won't let you, host your own server because others will be doing the same thing you were doing.

I've played for 13 hours so far so good and have had no issues. The community is great and I even went through Green Team and a string of ops with one of the hosts that gave us a great time. His name was Alasku if anyone plays with him.

Everyone has a desire for tactics so you'll be getting the best experience as long as you can communicate a plan, even if its a short plan, and have fun executing it. Regarding the AI in multiplayer experiences, they are smart but not overly intelligent as to portray a realistic simulation. If you flashbang them and tell them to get on the ground and surrender, they will. If you shoot them to near death, they will likely surrender. If you use non-lethal weapons on them and tell them to surrender, they will. However, if you take too long to secure a surrendering suspect, they may pull a weapon if they see the chance.

Overall, to anyone checking out this game, don't listen to reviews that say the AI is bad etc etc. Normally, a ton of people are just starting out like you and are terrible at the game albeit it not having a steep learning curve. When someone doesn't like something or understand something they will definitely complain. Still, check it out for yourself and I can very much recommend you get it and don't let other reviews discourage you.

This game lures you in with the veneer of a slow, deliberate, tactical fps - aka a thinking person's fps.  You play a few missions and it feels like you could really get that top score if you just nail down your strategy.  Then you keep playing, and you see that the AI is actually some of the dumbest you've ever seen.  Most of them hardly do anything except wait for you to come into their view.  There's tons of other problems detailed in various YT videos, including AI seeing through walls and tracking your exact position, 360 spinbot inhuman response, and more.  There are other problems too: hit reg bugs, movement bugs, rendering bugs, etc.  Mods can make the game playable but they can't make it what was promised.  As others have said, the devs aren't doing anything.  They made something like 50 million net profit and can't even talk to their community about a path forward.  I can't recommend in the current state.

Really feels like 1.0 was 3 steps forward and 10 steps back....

My frame rates and overall fidelity are significantly worse in 1.0.  From a near locked frame rate at ultra 1440p on a 3060ti before the 1.0 update to stuttering constantly and medium 1440p.  

AI are horrendous and worse than before if that was somehow possible. The new AI controls they've given us are janky and buggy and only work sometimes.  The QOL features they added like auto reporting suspects and civilians are very nice though.

But man...  For a game that tries enforce strict ROE, the AI is no where near adequate...  Suspects are unstable at best.  Going from shady looking to headshooting you in a second or less.  They are very buggy without line of sight in this update where they'll instant hit you when you peak the corner, but if you shoot within that timeframe you'll often get hit with an ROE penalty if you didn't yell compliance even though if you do you'll die half the time.  

AI team mates are still useless at best. They'll often flashbang you instead of enemies when clearing a hallway or anyroom where there is a wall near the door.  

The new campaign mode is needed, but mostly useless considering how useless your AI teammates are. They'll stick themselves into line of site before a flashbang goes off and get killed. The new map and breifing are what the game was sorely needing and a great update, but the rest of the package is pretty buggy.  Lots of stuttering in the mission select screens.  

I've also encountered numerous ingame bugs that are new to 1.0.   IR Laser sights refuse to toggle sometimes unless you turn off your NVGs, turn the sight on, and turn your NVGs back on.  Which is kinda useless.  

Overall, it feels like a pretty rushed 1.0 that wasn't ready for release and needed a lot more ironing out before rolling it out.  

THE AI NEED TO BE FIXED. That is really what 95% of my frustrations are centered around and I can live with a lot of the other issues if the AI could just  work.

TLDR:
Is it worth 50€ price tag? NO. Definitely not. It is an incomplete early access game still even if it claims to be ready. For 20€ it could be a good game but for 50€ I would like to get more for my money. 

More in depth:

For some reason this was better before the official release, the game runs very poorly even though my computer passes the recommended stats and it ran much better before the release. Also there are still a lot of things missing from a tactical perspective, prone for example. The AI has aimbot which is super unrealistic. Much more realistic would be if the enemies were scared and some couldn't even shoot straight. Enemy morale is incredible and they can take multiple shots to the knees and still charge at you.

Also the "story mode" is entirely pointless and just consumes some more time as there is no longer the possibility of a quick restart. Mu whole team died on a door trap and in the ending screen only one of them died and the rest went to therapy. If your entire roster is unavailable it has no effect on  the game, because you'll just get random guys instead. You cannot freely configure your team's loadout anymore either. Also now if you shoot, accidentally or on purpose, a restrained suspect you will be promptly executed without trial by your fellow policemen. Yesss, veeeery realistic.

Still if you download a mod that fixes the terrible ai and play with a friend or friends instead of the ai it is indeed quite a good game resembling SWAT 4 and games like it.

I've been following this game for 2 years in anticipation of it leaving early access and once It did i gladly snatched it up. I have to say presentation wise the game is pretty decent, been looking for a tactical multiplayer squad focused shooter akin to Rainbow Six Vegas 2 Terrorist hunt mode and this game certainly delivers.

As of the 1.0 update the game comes with 18 level's each ranging from different objectives and difficulty.

Pro's

- Weapon customisation allowed me to tailor my play style exactly as i wanted and the aiming and shooting feels natural.

- Enemy AI presents a challenge and constantly makes you feel on edge, they could be anywhere at any time so clearing out rooms requires tactics and forward thinking.

- Level design has lost of lore and themed focused objectives which are fun. Accomplishing them feels like you are increasing in skill and the progression systems goes towards getting better upgrades.

- Squad customisation can be tailored to support you and your play style. Want the squad to arrive decked out with heavy armour and riot shields? sure no problem.


Con's

- No official controller support by the developers. However i was able to rectify the issue with community controller mapping option through steam. However I would recommend mouse and keyboard for natural play as certain bindings for squad commands assigned to the directional buttons can be confusing.

- Enemy AI as of 1.0 can be infuriating especially during the later levels, fast reaction times, shooting through walls, instakilling you on sight and aimbot from across long corridors felt unfair at times. Community has addressed this, and hopefully the developers will fix or scale the difficulty going forward. In the meantime i recommend scaling the difficulty spike with nexus mod's as community fixes can tailor the experience to play naturally.

- More levels, I haven't played it prior to the 1.0 update but having completed all 18 maps i am eager for more. Community mods has a supermarket themed map, that would be a fun inclusion in further updates, or maybe a plane hijack akin to Airforce one or Executive Decision 90's throwback.

- Squad AI sometimes can be unresponsive to commands and will remain stuck, this can be annoying especially during shootouts. Once your dead the AI will do its best to complete the objectives without you, however i found more often than not the AI has pathing issues and sometimes is unable to proceed forwards after getting stuck beside a wall.

The squad AI also needs to be scaled with the enemy AI in its current form it feels like the enemy is operating with 100% hit detection accuracy where as your squad is handicapped with a 50% chance they won't die trying to find the enemy.

Id say the game in its current state is 7.5, i bought it at full price and looking forward to jumping into this game with my friend however i am eager for further updates to bring more content and or fix the AI whilst adding official controller support.

With the exception of a few minor bugs (which are being addressed by the dev team as of this review), this game is the most fun I've had playing a shooter in a very long time. Highly recommend, play with friends and surround sound.

EDIT: 
After playing this game from the release of early access to now (May 31st as of this edit), I can say without a doubt that this game has a very bright future. I can't say that I've played another game with AI of this level of uniqueness and sophistication. You occasionally still come across the John Wick .357 or shotgun suspect who's doped out of their mind and couldn't care less about the well being of themselves, but over all the interaction with all the different types of civi's and suspects has been quite a joy. Best gun play of any game out there, every shot can be felt throughout my body and induces this very strange form of enjoyable stress that's almost craved. Other than Insurgency: Sandstorm, the firefights are of the most intense nature I could imagine having in a game, knowing that any one shot could be the one that drops you, and the amount of screen shaking and adrenaline-fueled vision blur from near-misses will leave you a damn mess. With the June update just around the corner, I'm very excited to see how this game continues to go above and beyond, rejuvenating the FPS genre in ways I thought had been lost to the 2000's.

EDIT: 
It's been just about 5 months since the June update hit public servers, and I have to say that it's blowing my mind at how addictive this game still is. I'm definitely not hitting this game with the boys nearly as often as I was a couple months ago, but it's still getting some love from me about once or twice every 2 weeks or so. I was really worried that, after waiting this long for the next update, I would grow tired of this title and move onto something else, but that's not the case. What keeps me coming back for more is that I seem to learn something new every time I launch the game, be it AI behavior, gun-play, or even environmental story telling. On top of that, with the induction of in-game mod support, it increases life expectancy by a very long period of time.... With that being said, I am beginning to feel the longing for a new update with additions coming strait from the developers, not nearly as bad when the June update was being worked on, but still feeling a bit of craving for the next chapter of RoN.

EDIT: 
With the Adam update in full drive and plenty of hot fixes put in place, I can honestly say that this is, by far, the best tactical shooter that I've ever played. With every update, they up the games enjoyment far beyond my expectations. The new maps are so much fun and challenging, good environmental story telling, new and intriguing AI suspects, crazy interactions with AI civilians, and the addition of new missions continues to add replayability. I find myself wanting to play them over and over again, even when my whole team dies and we fail repeatedly. The new subs and hand-gun are just top notch, they feel good, sound good and increase the enjoyment of gun-play substantially. Personally, my favorite thing about this update is the overhaul of AI behavior. I can finally say that, 90% of the time, if I die then it's because I faltered somewhere in my game-play skill. I don't find myself feeling that I got screwed during a gun-fight because the suspect was like the second coming of John Wick, it feels balanced. I will say, my biggest complaint is the new map, Ridgeline. It needs a lot of improvement, the mission doesn't deliver the kind of raw, intense, dreadful feeling of being hunted that I was expecting. I thought that Gerard was going to be playing a high-octane game of cat-and-mouse with the SWAT team, constantly hiding in places that you'd never think to look, changing positions in the house at all times to prepare for an ambush, traps all over the place... And I just didn't get that. In conclusion, I really enjoy where this game is going. Keep it up Void, y'all are making something amazing here.

EDIT: After a year of waiting with the utmost patience, I can confidently say that I am very disappointed in this game. I expected something huge here from VOID, but all I got was map changes, new guns and some new character models. I couldn't care less about the police station, the new one looks "better", but it's not something that I was overly ambitious about waiting a year for. For starters, the AI have not been changed in the slightest, it's the same mega-accuracy bulls*@# I experienced when the game first came out, so from that perspective we've moved backwards instead of forward. There's no new animations from the suspect and civilian AI, which is also very disappointing. The animations that were in the game aren't even present anymore due to the new update, which the devs have addressed and are (supposedly) working on. The campaign mode is absolutely atrocious, the new SWAT AI have superhuman senses or no sense at all, there really is no in-between, and that's quite frustrating. The map rework of Hotel (which was my favorite map in the game) is trash. They took a fantastic map, and completely ruined it by making it into this dark, compact map that has no character or interesting factors, its just some hallways, some hotel rooms and a lounge area. Finally, my friends are constantly experiencing crashes and glitches in this game, ruining the immersion and fun-factor of the game. Overall, I'm quite unhappy that this is what the 1.0 version of this game looks like. I understand AI is very difficult to get right, but that doesn't take away from the fact that a full release and a price increase is unacceptable for this version of the product.

This game would have been a positive review, if it was STILL early access (which is when I bought it).

This game is fantastic, or rather could be. 

Pros:
The gunplay is amazing.
The levels are well made and designed.
The graphics are gorgeous.
The customization is incredible.
Multiplayer (can) be tactical as hell.

Now, with pros like that, whats holding this game back?

The lack of quality of life features. Why when im playing in commander mode (this games "campaign"), do I have to be sent back to the hub, re pick the mission, re-ready up, and sit through yet another loading screen? Would it be so hard as to simply add a restart button and have an OPTION to go back to the hub?

Why can the AI see me through walls (as many others pointed out). Why do they have near instant reaction time? 

Why is the optimization HORRID? 

This game is NOT anywhere near worth a FIFTY USD dollar price tag.

If this was early access, okay fine, its early, but for a supposed FINISHED product? This is flat out dropping the ball.

This is like going to a chef, handing him the best ingredients possible, and then he makes like an overcooked burnt BLT.

This game has the POTENTIAL to be a FANTASTIC EXPERIENCE, and all the parts needed are ALREADY MADE! So with a couple quality of life updates (which should have been in the game in the first place, for a 50$ price tag), this game will be worth it.

As of right now, if your looking for a singleplayer SWAT experience, just get SWAT 4. 

VOID, please listen to your fans, I love this game and want to see it succeed, but you have really gotta fix these issues, when nearly every other person is complaining about it.

Totally different from your typical shooter. You're not going in guns blazing - gotta be careful about who and when you shoot. Save hostages and civilians, detain cooperative suspects, even give combative suspects a chance to surrender. All of these count towards your score, and it's better to take suspects alive if possible. Very difficult, real split-second decision making oriented towards saving lives. If you've played games like Insurgency or Escape From Tarkov, and want slightly faster games but at a slower and more deliberate pace with much more situational challenge, try this one.

Civilian hide and seek simulator. Seriously, finding all civilians is a real buzzkill and should be an optional objective, especially in the larger missions, where if you miss one hostage you must spend an eternity rechecking the entire level once you are already done clearing suspects. Sometimes, civilians don't make any noise when you use the get down command, and at other times, you have to tie up dead civilians to clear the objective which makes no sense. Being forced to locate all civilians soured the whole experience for me, as finishing the final level was impossible. 
 
Gameplay can be quite fun and tense, but it is also ruined at times by enemy ai, which will wallbang you or instantly kill you without a moment's warning if they have a line of sight. Friendly ai also has a tendency to trap you in rooms or corners, which becomes incredibly frustrating. 

Also, the games runs very poorly. Even on a good pc, the game struggles to maintain 60 fps in any area with lots of ai. In a game where reacting instantly means the difference between a lengthy restart and success, this becomes a real problem. 

It is unfortunate because the level design and story telling within each mission is incredible. Each mission is varied in its setting, and highly immersive with the premission briefings that provide background on the suspects, known civilians, and 911 calls for the incident.

[h1]This is the worst tactical shooter you will ever play.[/h1]

Just go to GOG and buy swat:4, it is not even comparable how much worse this game is.

If the 1.0 update is meant to be the complete package than this game is a failure and they've just been doing nothing this whole time, not only is EVERY SINGLE ONE of the issues this game had during early access still there completely untouched, but there are even more bugs than there was before. 
Even worse, systems that were good and functional in the previous build are either completely worse or just straight up gone and more than half of the content they teased for more than a year of them not updating the game is nowhere to be found...

-The game runs infinitely worse than it did before for no reason despite actually looking worse and some of the maps being smaller, this game would look dated during the xbox 360 era and somehow it needs even more powerful hardware than some of the most visually impressive games of the current generation.

-The AI is still John Wick despite supposedly being fixed, perfectly one shotting you and pulling impossible maneuvers and still shrug off 5.56 and even 7.62 rounds like they're nothing and sometimes not even being affected by flashbangs, pepper spray, stingers.

-The ROE(Rules of engagement) still make no sense and punish you for shooting back at someone who is shooting you or civilians, there have been times i got deducted points for "unathorized use of deadly force"for shooting back at a suspect after they literally KILLED one of my guys.

-Your guns still have such exaggerated and unrealistic recoil that im convinced the devs entire experience with a firearm is rb6 siege.

-You still have to kindly wait for the suspect to be polite and comply to your orders which they will always ignore and you can't put them on the ground yourself.

-Friendly AI still can get stuck somewhere on the map and ignore your orders.

-You still have to play forensic and walk through the entire map at the speed of Bizarro world flash to find that one piece of paper the devs FORCE you to find on this awful poorly designed maps with zero clues as to where they are otherwise you can't leave, this has been an issue since day one and like many things they refuse to change it, except now it's an even bigger issue since you're forced to do it to access the other maps in the awful commando mode.

-The """Realistic"""" and """gritty""" story is something that not even an 8 year old would write for their creepypasta, all of the maps have some of the stupidest most on the nose edgy garbage story that is downright impossible to take seriously.

Additionally before you could select what situation (hostage situation, active shooter, bomb threat, etc) you wanted to tackle on whatever map supported it, this was great as it added replayability and truly made every encounter unpredictable and pushed you to try and get the highest score on all of the maps and situations, now you have to go through this awful career mode that is not thought out at all, you can't restart to try and get better ranks and can be cheesed easely, completely removing what little there was of the "tactical" portion in this "tactical" shooter to the point that the only way you could consider this a good tactical shooter is if you've never played anything else like it before, even the game its supposed to be a spiritual succesor to.

Overall such wasted potential.

I loved this game when it first came out, both because it was neat to see a tactical shooter and controllable A.I. in the same game. But with the latest update the enemy AI has went from bumbling B-movie bad guy henchmen to John Wick2.0. I can get past that and move on from the difficult AI enemies because you have controllable characters of your own to work with. But the one thing I cant deal with is the fact that half the time this game physically cannot run. Like 70% of the time i try to run the program it loads in to the main menu, i hit continue, and it freezes. I've tried uninstalling mods, i've tried uninstalling the game and reinstalling it, installing it onto an SSD, updating my graphics card, literally anything possible to get it to run better. On the off chance the game actually does boot in and lets me get to a playable level, half the time spent playing is just waiting for the terrible FPS stutter to stop just to get 360 no scoped by an enemy 200m away. I'd love to be able to play this game on something besides the lowest possible graphics setting and get decent FPS at the same time. Until that point there's no way it's worth the $50 price tag, if anything the game should be free until they optimize this shit better.

Seasoned players will hip-fire full auto 7.62, shotguns, 40mm in pubs because it's impossible to aim after already being shot at. Title: "Ready or Not: 

In the whimsical and imaginative world of "Ready or Not," players are treated to an extraordinary gaming experience where tactical operations meet the unanticipated charm of monkeys mastering mathematics. This unique fusion of adrenaline-fueled tactical gameplay and the joyous allure of numerically inclined primates offers a delightful escape into a world where bullets and bananas coexist harmoniously.


As the commander of a squad of highly trained monkey operatives, players find themselves navigating through diverse scenarios that demand both strategic acumen and mathematical prowess. The core objective revolves around overcoming challenges by harnessing the distinct math skills of each monkey. This unconventional blend of tactical decision-making and numerical problem-solving elevates the gameplay to new heights of entertainment and cognitive engagement.



At the heart of "Ready or Not" lies a series of math challenges that players must conquer to progress through the game. From calculating trajectories for banana projectiles to solving complex numerical puzzles, players are immersed in a world where mathematical dexterity becomes the key to success. Each level presents unique challenges, ensuring that players not only advance in the game but also sharpen their mathematical skills in the process.

Monkey Agility:

Beyond mastering math, players witness the dynamic agility of their monkey operatives. Commanding these primates to swing from vines, climb structures, and execute acrobatic maneuvers adds an exhilarating physical dimension to the gameplay. The combination of tactical strategy and nimble monkey antics creates an immersive and entertaining experience that keeps players engaged throughout their mathematical journey.

Multiplayer Monkey Madness:

"Ready or Not" embraces the social aspect of gaming by offering multiplayer modes where players can team up with friends. Cooperative missions become a test of teamwork and collective mathematical proficiency, while competitive modes add a layer of unpredictability to the equation. The result is a multiplayer experience that not only fosters camaraderie but also showcases the diverse strategies and math skills of each player.

This is not a realistic shooter game. This is an immensely challenging tactical FPS game. This is what you should keep in mind before getting this game. Quick points to go through below:

In short: Enemy AI is very hard at this point. They are beyond the point of realism. They have crazy aim, tankiness, crazy running speed, and other craziness, which like I said is beyond realistic.

Enemy AI:
1) Enemy AI is WAY too hard - I mostly solo this game without NPC officers. What I observed in my solo adventures:
a) Enemy AI can shoot precisely through cover without peeking. The nearer you are to the said cover, the more accurate the enemies' wallbang gets.
b) Throw a deployable/nade to disorient the enemies without having a proper line of sight? The deployable will always bounce and go to the left. Dunno why.
c) Flank the enemy AI stealthily? They will know where you are, always.
d) Hold your position and aim at a medium distance so that you can get him when he jumps out of cover? He will almost always prefire and kill you when his aggression is high
e) Shoot his arms to disarm him? He will simply shift the gun to his other hand. 
f) You will need to shoot him 3-5 times in non critical areas to incapacitate him and 2 shots in the center of chest or head to kill him
g) Take cover behind a hostage? He will shoot you through the hostage and the hostage wont get hit. Beware you cant do the same
h) Enemy AI can strafe-run at full speed and shoot at you with above normal accuracy (maybe even kill you)
i) And then there are other minor glitches and bugs

[h1] After revisiting the game 7 months later, I decided to change my initial review. [/h1]

[h3] Pros [/h3] 
• Excess weapon variety.
• Lack of grind for weapons & tools; as they're all available. 
• Nicely done weapon customisation, and attachments.
• Great selection of maps with greatly designed interior.
• Accurate and well-made weapons.
• Push to talk! 
•  Great gameplay experience especially if it's done when people constantly communicate.

[h3] Cons [/h3] 
• Very poor optimisation. (With MSI GTX 1650 Super, I had to lower all graphics settings to minimum to get stable FPS).
• Not able to select which region you want to play. 
• Poorly performed voice acting in general. [Compared to SWAT 4 (2005)] 
• Not able to join games from a server browser. (Server browser that is similar to Left 4 dead's)
• Uninteractable NPCs at the headquarters. 

[h3] In Conclusion [/h3] 
•  As it can be seen, all the negatives mentioned above are to subject to change for other people, and are subjective opinions too - excluding the optimisation. 
•  Therefore, I would definitely encourage people to give the game a try.
•  The gameplay is done in such a great way, you don't have to grind for anything. Just select your preferred guns and gear, and roll in to the mission! Big thumbs up for that!

[h3] Verdict [/h3] 
I recommend it - after giving the game a more ''objective'' look compared to my initial review.

Either on sale or not, up to you.

Ready or Not is very fun to play and it is a good game... but it isn't much more than that for [b] for now [/b] .

[h2] The good: [/h2] 
This game really lives up to the tactical shooter genre premises. Most of the times it has a very slow paced, intense and anxiety inducing gameplay where you often find yourself not being sure of what to do and just doing it anyway.

Of all the FPS games, tactical or not, I've played in my life, this one is amongst those that have the heaviest and most distinctive atmosphere. It is not like Call of Duty or Battlefield where you feel like you're in a movie, no. It is as if you were in an actual realistic and possible enviroment/situation where your life is just about as fragile as of the suspects you are shooting.

The level design is pretty well made, diverse and detailed. It can and will subtly give you hints of what you're experiencing more in depth. It is also "edgy" in the proper way an FPS like this should be, as in, it portrays the reality it tries to emulate very well (even if it is a heavy dramatization, which kind of very necessary in almost any story).

[h2] The bad: [/h2] 
Even though this is an actual good game and certainly a fun experience, specially with friends, it does not come without its flaws. Let's start with the mildest of the problems and then a little worse one.

I've never been a soldier or a police officer, but I can assure you from talking to anyone who is acostumed to constantly shooting guns that there is no way on earth that guns should have that absurd big of a recoil. And keeping on the weapons theme: 9mm here almost does not kill. It does barely any damage even to a suspect with not even a kevlar vest.

This might be a subjective thing, but I really think there should be more morally dubious missions, as in like Ides of March (Brisa Cove). In that mission you have to neutralize a situation in which military veterans barricaded themselves and plan to assassinate a presidential candidate, Senator Freemont, because in his campaign he proposed a bill which would cut veteran funding.
On an emotional level and on trying to emulate a reality:
You can't sympathize with school shooters,
You can't sympathize with illegal arms dealers,
You can't sympathize with p*dos (not sure if steam lets me say words like that here),
You CAN sympathize with people who are in a fucked State and are getting more and more fucked by it by the government cutting its assistance and shit to those in need. That seems an awful lot like a reality because it is. And that is why this mission is plot-wise, in my opinion, the best and most meaningful in the game.

Now onto the less worse part of the suspect AI: It is way too simple. way. too. simple.
The suspect AI doesn't really make any meaningful decisions beyond fighting back, giving up or killing themselves. Sure you got the ocasional perfidy, but they don't do anything much more than that. As an example, they could very well be programmed to run away and flank you and find the best routes to do so, but it seems like they just try to find the nearest route to you and only really shoot you from the back without any meaningful thought to it, even going as far as making the stupid decision to do that while 4 other officers are aiming at the door.

[h2] The ugly: [/h2] 
I am going to get straight to the point: The suspect AI is absolute dogshit. Not because it is too easy to fight them, no, it is quite the contrary. They seems to have aimbot and wallhack hacks and they can hear you from miles and miles away. The suspect AI is the main thing that ruins this game. Yes, you can mod the AI to make it less John Wick-y, but Void, what is the point on delivering an unfinished AI on a game you made such big promises on? 
And even if you do download mods for the suspect AI, in all the cases I did, it fucks up your friendly AI, so it is like a trade-off of some sorts, which is stupid and would be unecessary if the devs actually took the time to fix the AI.
Yes, I know that they left us, early access players, one year without any meaningful updates, yes. But I would rather wait one more year to get a FULLY DEVELOPED AND COMPLETED GAME than this.

...also, the optimisation is also dogshit.

[h2] Conclusion: [/h2] 
Should you buy this game, full price or not? Depends.
If you want to actively see the development of the game and feel the changes and all, then yes, buy it.
If you want to have a fully developed and polished tactical shooter experience then don't for now. Wait a bit.

Hands down one of the best milsim type tactical shooters I have played to date. The enemy ai, admittedly, is a bit op, but it adds to the immersion of the game, causing you to slow down and think about your next steps instead of just rushing into every room you find.

Ready or Not is a realistic SWAT team simulator made for both milsim enthusiasts and average FPS players looking for a challenge. 
The game has full mod support from an integrated mod.io menu as well as an active community on NexusMods (as of this post the Vortex extension for the game does not work, you must manually install mods from Nexus).
The overarching story in the base game maps is highly detailed and fleshed out for the singleplayer campaign, integrating as many story related objectives into the maps as possible. 

- Gameplay wise, the gunplay is well thought out in terms of how it affects suspects and officers alike according to body armor worn and rounds used and where targets are hit. For example using high caliber AP rounds vs non-armored targets have a high chance of over penetration causing little to no damage. In the same fashion, by using small caliber AP rounds they may not be able to totally penetrate heavy armor and thus require more rounds to down a target. 
The AI is famously unforgiving with quick reaction time and a detailed "Suspect Stress" AI system. (Suppressed weapons and low grenade use is your friend!)

- Story wise, as a SWAT team simulator it is highly emphasized through the main campaign that you are largely part of a police force trying to keep your corner of the world from falling into total decay. Though it's plainly obvious mysterious forces behind the scenes have their own objectives. You can only do what you're told and perform your duties to the best of your ability and hope that after you do your job the detectives, federal agents and lawyers will do theirs. 

A great experience alone and a fantastic experience with friends.

[strike]Ready or Not in its current state is an extremely competent and fun shooter, where you and your special forces team of[/strike] - oh wait, it's not a military tactical shooter? It's a police procedural where you're supposed to arrest people?

Ready or Not in its current state is a dumpster fire of a police procedural. Suspect AI is the main thing you will be engaging with during the game, and it has both superhuman (.1 second) reaction time and accuracy, often shooting you through walls and doorways after spotting fabric from your uniform poking from concealment. 

This would be fine if it were not a gritty tactical SWAT simulation - but that is the game that RoN portrays itself as. The suspects run the gamut from drug addicts robbing a convenience store, to armed security, to die hard criminal types - however every single one of these suspects acts exactly the same - armed suspects regardless of type will unflinchingly refuse to surrender unless less-lethal options such as flashbangs are utilized, and otherwise will proceed to commit suicide by cop. Suspects who do surrender will unerringly be faking it and will pull a holdout piece to shoot you if you don't immediately order them to turn around to be cuffed, only to be blown away by automatic weapons fire upon drawing a weapon by your AI squad mates.

SWAT Officer AI similarly behaves in this superhuman manner, as in the aforementioned scenario it will often look like they are executing an unarmed suspect, but also incredibly dumb – the go to for Officer AI is to “move and clear” rooms. This works fine if the room is a box. Things go haywire as the levels become more and more complex and labyrinthine, as Officers will stand in hallways next to open doors and call out that “the room is clear” before being blasted by a suspect 5 feet away in what is technically another room.
 
The effect this has on the massive undertaking that VOID has gone under to provide a gritty and realistic depiction of the scenarios in Ready or Not cannot be understated - this obliterates all sense of immersion. This is honestly such a shame because the level design of Ready or Not borders on incredible. But here we are sabotaging that again with the sudden 1.0 inclusion of a ton of AI generated artwork. Some of these are funny like anime girl posters with 8 eyebrows, but almost all of it is unnecessary. This is such a bizarre choice when compared side by side with the massive level of detail that these levels have – it’s very clear that there is someone on the team who is very passionate about what they are doing, and being absolutely stabbed in the back by whoever else was responsible for these assets.

The only other conclusion I can draw from this is that VOID has absolutely phoned it in across the finish line. For a game that was charging 80$ for the early access “supporter edition” that came with all the levels in development, it is hard to believe that this is the current “finished product”. These issues with suspect AI have been the state of the game for multiple years as levels were being produced. (In fact, I remember it being better a year ago.) Game modes that existed pre-1.0 have been removed. The replay feature is broken and borders on nonfunctional – but don’t worry, it will be filling up your hard drive with replays and cannot be disabled. The only way to select a mission is through the elaborately designed HQ, which is slow. The touted Commander mode that 1.0 has launched with is a mess. It is barebones and after completing the campaign using it I can say that it adds nothing to the game. S Ranks for levels, which is what you will be shooting for (besides the suspects) after completing Commander mode, are not tracked on any of the game screens besides when you complete the level. The only way to tell what levels you’ve S Ranked is by checking what tattoos you have unlocked in the cosmetic menu. 

All of this adds up to a massive bummer. I loved SWAT 4, and while I’m certainly no tactical shooter expert, I can appreciate when an FPS does something different from the typical Call of Duty style cinematic military rooty tooty point and shooty. Slow, cerebral pacing through levels where you are trying to keep everyone alive, even the bad guys, makes for an interesting dynamic for a video game in an industry where nearly everything is just the opposite. Ready or Not, however, is basically only fun if you play it as it’s not meant to be played.

With all of these issues, it’s very difficult to recommend Ready or Not.

Sadly at this stage I feel like I have to say that I do not recommend this game. It does deliver on a very unique tactical shooter experience that there are simply no other games like it. That swat fantasy alone might be worth paying for in most cases but objectively speaking the game still has lots of issues.

The biggest reason why I do not recommend this game is that it basically brings nothing new to the table. The game is essentially SWAT 4 with a little better graphics. I would expect there to be a more noticeable difference in games that are more than 15 years apart. Things like modern gadgets could be implemented, better animations, better ai, more meaningful procedural generation. Things that would make the game innovate on the formula. The point I am making here is that while Ready or Not does preserve and deliver that superb formula of the old SWAT games, right now there is absolutely no reason for you to buy this game over SWAT 4.

AI deserves a special mention as it is very disappointing still. Commands for your team are just very limited. Most obvious example I can come up with is that there is no option to force your team to switch to less-than-lethal weapons like tasers and tear gas. The game encourages you to arrest suspects rather than kill them (which in itself is pretty dumb in most situations like when dealing with outright terrorists) but the ai teammates just make it harder by killing a suspect who is alone in the room and you could easily overpower him.

Optimisation and bugs are sadly another thing I have to mention. The game runs outright bad and it does not look all that great either. AI teammates get stuck on doors and there is clipping. Also a super weird glitch is that some doors do not full cover the opening so you can basically see into the room for free without being noticed.

Finally another minor but concerning thing is the suspicious marketing. Idk if its just me and I am willing to give the devs the benefit of the doubt on this but it seems to me like the 1.0 trailers make it seem as though there is a deep campaign and/or highly scripted set pieces and drama. In case anyone else gets confused that is absolutely not the case. The game is 18 levels where you are in charge of a swat team. You are given an objective to save civilians and clear out bad guys. There is no dialogue, no cut scenes, no characters. Do not expect a flashed out campaign with a deep story

Things like these make me say that I do not recommend this game. I miss SWAT series so much and there is simply no other tactical shooters like this game out there so I still do not regret my purchase and will probably have lots more fun with this game. It is just that at present I would expect more

The so-called 1.0 release was supposed to be the final version of the game. It seems the very much opposite of it however. The performance is worse than pre-release, some content got (unnecessarily) cut, and the enemy AI is inconsistent at best and supernatural at worst.

My main with the game is its structure. Now the campaign consist of separate missions with a police station serving a purpose of hub/intermission, when you can manage your squad, equipment and see briefings before starting a mission.
The most aggravating feature is that you can't restart the missions and exiting them will count as a failure (which punishes you by increasing your squadmates stress level). It adds nothing of value to the gameplay, as you will be either forced to sit through loading screens while going back to hub and choosing mission again (while being punished for failure) or ALT+F4 and restart the game, again sitting through the loading screens. This design isn't very coherent within the game story as well, as realistically SWAT team couldn't retreat, regroup and try again next day.
The game would work best if progress was mission-oriented as well, with no penalty for trying again (something akin to other mission based games, like old R6, Splinter Cell or MGS games).
Also, please let us see our best score on completed missions.

All in all, the game is more frustrating than enjoyable in its current state.

I loved this game when it first opened on steam for purchase, but if I knew it was going to end up were it did, I probably would have ignored it. It is the game that "Could have been".

I bought this game for myself and friends, I also bought the support pack DLC because I wanted to help give this game every chance that I could, and in its earlier days, regardless of the bugs, it was turning out to be well worth it.

The game had a dark sense of realism to it, human trafficking, active shooter, hostage situations. It didn't shy away from showing you the real kinds of things Police Services deal with. it hit you on a different level that left you really thinking. Nothing was over done, but with the changes to maps, One (Of Many) that comes to mind being The Port map where it felt like a fast moving operation for human trafficking, finding people in shipping containers that you just felt terrible for and you'd have an urge to want to search and clear every last inch of that map to insure justice. Well, at least that's how it was. Now you get some over done Hollywood movie take where you find cheesy eye rolling text inside an unbelievable "Hide out" that appears to be run by the VIP's of "Squid Game". I'm sure their dialogue would have been just as good...

A huge down side was the removal of the different modes you could select. For every map there were 5 different modes. Barricaded Suspects, Bomb Threat, Raid, Active Shooter and Hostage Rescue. (All of which are still advertised on the games steam page in a video as this review is posted) All were ripped from the game and you're forced to go with a standard pray and spray into John Wicks Cloning Facilities.

Everyone is saying it, and it is true. The AI is WAY to fast. If you want to argue on some maps that they should have faster reaction time because they are trained, sure, I'll buy it, but when I walk into a drug den and get 360 no-scoped in a way that would make John Wick blush by a guy whose veins died last year I have to wonder... 

The scoring system is way out of wack, you want a perfect score? Bring flowers and ask the bad men to handcuff themselves, because if you even think of shooting someone who tries to do someone harm, it's okay, you'll always be average. I don't know why I can walk into a club where I can see 60+ Bodies on the ground that were slaughtered trying to escape and piled up by their killers with their phones ringing probably from their loved ones that will never be able to speak to them again and I get in trouble because I yelled at guys in full body armor carrying LMGs to get down multiple times, and didn't listen but because they didn't point their gun at me I'm the bad guy because I shot them.

All in all the game feels different, I view posters with passive aggressive tones towards Law Enforcement. The game feels more like an over-done movie than it does trying to create order in chaos. I'm still waiting for the day I find a shirtless guy with bullets strapped to his chest calling himself "Rambo". If you are looking for a small fun time with friends, sure. I don't recommend the game aside from that, it's "Okay" at best. I wish it had gone in the direction it started but it honestly feels like different people are working on it now. I don't like the passive aggressiveness towards law enforcement or veterans in the game at all. It appears it will always remain as the game that "Could have been".

[h1] VOID lacked vision and initiative to develop Ready or Not into its true spot as a realistic and refined tactical SWAT simulator. [/h1]

[h1] INFO [/h1]
I go by Tomato, I have 400+ hours on RON, and have learned and practiced CQB tactics.
Why would I negatively review RON after all of this? 
I’d be very dishonest and in contempt of all of my findings and experiences and the findings and experiences of others post 1.0 if I were to choose a positive review over a negative at its current state. If sufficient changes are made for the better, I will absolutely change this review to a positive. If you have any criticisms of this post, say such, ask questions, the comments will be open. 

[h1] WHAT I THINK RON SHOULD BE [/h1]
IMO, Ron should be a tactical SWAT Simulator. 
But based on so many design choices and lack thereof, I can’t be sure of that being the design focus, and It's terrible. The lack of tactical mechanics and development is questionable. Shoulder tapping, a fundamental applied real world CQB tactic, is completely absent in Ready or Not 1.0 base game. Must you rely on your modding community to accomplish what should've been implemented in the base game to begin with? It's true with AI too, which will be covered.
Another opportunity for a mechanic not implemented is the ability to change which shoulder you hold your weapon with. 

[h1] 1.0 RELEASE [/h1]
1.0 was NOT ready. Full release was an absolute dastardly decision IMO.
What really puts it into perspective is the current state of the AI. Basically, what they said was: "Here is our full release of Ready or Not Suspect AI! Full with insane accuracy, aimbotting, wallbanging, insane cover penetration and reflexes among other things like instantly taking and killing civilian hostages during gunfights." The AI is just unrealistic and boring. 
Also the amount of bugs never ceases to shock and surprise me. Have fun with your clothing / accessories / helmets / vests having occasional clipping or layering issues as well. I understand that fixing things like that are very hard and may take unique innovation, but is it not worth it? Anyway, there are substantial bugs like the physics system being literally insane, making suspects throw AKs / Machine guns across the room or map, completely invalidating S runs. Doors on the ground from C2 literally bouncing around the concrete map AND teleporting the player around if stepped on. The AI can literally shoot you WITHOUT their barrel of their gun being pointed at you, even after being shot and flinching (to add insult to injury.) There are animation issues and carelessness. What the hell?? Sounds ready for a full release IMO.
I've been a bit sarcastic, so I'll be blunt; Devs have seemed quite frankly willfully stubborn towards their game and the Ready or Not community. It feels like a "Do the devs even play the game?" type of ordeal, and the lack of accountability from them is stunning.  I have heard that VOID likes the AI reaction times, when everyone should have been hearing "we are sorry". I feel if this continues or is not resolved, Ready or Not will be one of those games that had their big moment of fame (Perhaps for their advanced 1.0 SWAT Ai) but miss the mark completely and fizzle out over a period of time.

[h1] MISSIONS - From another players perspective. [/h1]
[b] “Is this game supposed to be a Police sim or a Military sim?” [/b]
“So, I get to the 32 Megabytes per second mission. [...] One barricaded suspect with a hostage in some apartment rooms. A great early mission simulating a realistic SWAT scenario. Awesome. Just what I'm looking for in a SWAT police simulator.”
“Then you start playing and it feels like you're assaulting an insurgent building in Fallujah.“
“Like...what the hell is happening? Why is half the apartment complex shooting at us? It really feels like there was some major disconnect during development”
“Honestly, it feels like this for most of the game. The VAST majority of people you deal with have no regard for their own lives and just won't surrender."
[b] Commenters Elaborate [/b]
"I don't care that the game explains why there are 15 armed suspects in the building, this was the perfect opportunity to have a small, routine swatting mission."
[b] My thoughts [/b]
There isn't even an official bank robbery mission, instead, all of these missions are tailored around a story basically involving and restricted to the scope of a pedophile ring, in a game that DOESN'T EVEN NEED A STORY TO BEGIN WITH.
Additionally, VOID removed the option to be able to pick different variations of certain maps/areas, such as bomb threats, active shooters, barricaded suspects etc, limiting player choice.

[h1] RON - Realistic or Not? [/h1]
While RON is generally quite realistic in many aspects, there is a lot of completely unrealistic things and weird design choices. 
This would be generally permissible  if realism was sacrificed for better gameplay, but instead, we are at a lack of both. 
There’s a lack of “ideal and logical” realism, like shoulder tapping previously mentioned, and drones instead of an unrealistic "mirror gun". The way long tactical equipment is carried on the back (40+ pound Ballistic shields or battering rams being carried on the back) is not a thing in real life. But I will concede on that specifically because it does have gameplay values. Here's one I haven't mentioned; GORE! The devs have surely blessed their player base of tactical realism based operators now... By making limbs and full heads and necks just come clean off due to a shotgun, regardless of range. Just *pop*. Great. That sure is realistic. Even if I didn't care for realism that much, I still wouldn't want to see it just because it's so over the top and generic. 

[h1] Breaching methods [/h1]
Making entry into locked or even just closed doors and rooms is a fundamental aspect of SWAT and Ready or Not. The thing is that Ready or Not really just neglects it entirely in many ways. Firstly is door kicking. Door kicking is still so quick and generally (VOID) of consequences that everyone simply goes to the method first, generally succeeding in 1-5 kicks. 
(Doors?) I forgot to mention... Doors are literally magic in this game! They open both ways and don't conform to door frames. 
Anyways, yeah, why use battering ram or a halligan tool (IF IT WAS ADDED) when you can just kick doors open so easily and quickly despite all the gear you are carrying.
Not only can you kick them down so easily, you can literally quietly lockpick them in seconds or one second 1 reusable deployable.
[b]HERE COMES MR BREACHING SHOTGUN!!! [/b] Open a locked door from across a hallway or perhaps a whole house, by shooting it in once or twice in the middle of the door. Just shoot it anywhere, why aim for the hinges or knob. Angle, range, placement, who even cares.

[h1] MELEE [/h1] 
SWAT operator melee / self defense is just completely absent. The only thing a SWAT operator can do is use a melee strike with a gun. But what's the point in melee if you can't strike an enemy because they are [b] [i] "too close." [/i] [/b]
Also, the suspects can kill you with melee, but you can't kill them. Hell, you can barely effect them at all. 

[h1] Did I miss some things? [/h1] 
Absolutely. I may have missed some things on accident, or purposefully reserved some things to not be deliberately addressed in this post. Also, edits have been made for clarity. Though, the great thing is that other great people have addressed what I have not.
[b] As such: [/b]
Shout out to Lex_ for his review which notes the AI's millisecond reaction times.
Shout out to Chris the cop for his insights, and other truly brave and honest influencers.
Shout out to Noah, Psycho, benrfn and Yngvi, and MrBread to name a few for sharing their experiences.
And a moment of silence to the new players of RON, many of which have refunded the game.

Rating: ★☆☆☆☆

little to no replay value. set amount of missions. Once you beat them only thing left to do is master them (the only way to master is to get S rank which requires non leathal. There is only 3 non leathal guns). Sometimes the NPC's seems to glitch and they take an unreasonable amount of damage to die and then you get beamed in the head before that damage is dealt.

This game is loads of fun with intense and hard game play. It will reward you for playing smart and punish you for playing carelessly. That being said in its current state it has two HUGE flaws. 

The AI is insane in terms of accuracy. Some enemies it makes sense for (ex special forces and the like). Others will one shot head shot you from across the map even with zero line of sight because reasons. It makes some maps extremely infuriating. Add to that ridiculous numbers of enemies (really? 17 enemies against your 5 man squad?) and there is little more than luck involved in some maps. The other big issue is enemy health. On some maps (specifically the female cult map) the enemies can take HUGE amounts of damage. I have dumped 15 rounds into an enemy and she still killed me and my squad. I have put a flash bang at enemy's feet and they still shot me and killed me in two shots. 

There is a difference between hard and unfair. This game is generally just hard but some maps it gets into the unfair. With the health issues, AI issues, and numbers issues the game is damn near impossible on large maps (enemies can just circle around you so you have to just keep clearing the same rooms constantly and eventually that last enemy will kill you in a room you already cleared twice).

All that being said the devs have said they are working on fixing these issues. Given the level of detail in this game I am positive they will fix everything and make the game perfect. They are already there minus those issues (to be fair it is an issue on like 3 maps. Enemies seem fine on all the rest)

I just finished the game today. Here are my thoughts. Overall, I would say that this game captures the intensity of a shootout very well. The gun mechanic is great! The maps are made very well, with a great design that is befitting of the game's style. The creativity the developers poured into this game is absolutely wonderful. That is why it saddens me to say this, but I must be honest. This game has plenty of issues, and the issues are so awful that it makes me regret buying this game that I was so excited to play. This is directly for VOID; please fix your AI! The AI in this game is incomplete, both swat and enemies. The AI in this game is extremely broken. I've had enemies snipe me with a pistol on Port Hokan while I had high ground on the tower. Enemies have shot and killed me through smoke screens; they can also easily wall-bang you at anytime. They seem to always know where you are, and they are also quite aggressive. Enemies will stupidly enter a room full of swat members and get gunned down—not very realistic, if you ask me. The enemies have all the advantage, even though it doesn't make any sense. For example, how can a street thug have the aim of a special forces operator? Maybe they go to the shooting range a lot. OK, how can literal drugged-up junkies have better aim than my own teammates? I really can just keep going with how terrible this game's AI is. Although there is a story line, the way it is presented is complete garbage. There is barely anything to connect the player and story, which ultimately makes the game feel empty. You feel afraid of the enemies because of how broken they are, even though you should feel confident since you are heavily equipped with gear and armor. Your AI teammates are useless; they are totally brainless without your command. Also, it stinks that there isn't a prone feature; the crouching and movement feel too slow. Which doesn't make sense since, in real-life combat situations, you need to be able to move fast or slowly depending on the situation, but in this incomplete game, the only option is slow. Although there are aspects of the game that are great, the problems outweigh the good. Until VOID manages to fix its AI problem and add actual realistic features, I do not recommend this misleading game. One more thing: I also recommend watching Yuki's video on YouTube, where he shares similar thoughts and opinions.

This review is entirely based on solo game with AI. (when i play with friends ill update).

9/10 gameplay

This game is brutal to the core to say the least, one mistake and it will punish you with instant death and make you start the map from scratch. Love it <3
Enemies shoot through walls! Enemies perfect accuracy! However, both points you gotta love and i think that's what makes this game stand out to me ~ Its a challenge.
I can see myself downloading map mods for this game to carry me until the next update.

6/10 teamwork (This will increase when i play with friends).

Teamwork for me makes a game, i like games with lots of teamwork and communication.
Sometimes the bots are stupid, not doing as they are asked, getting in your way.. running out into the other end of a loaded shotgun pointed at their face - even if its mine :)
Playing the game with AI is a little sad to say the least and i cannot wait for playing the game with friends. I feel with friends this game is going to be epic.
I have seen mods for voice commanding the bots which i think should be a standard feature for the game, this would bring this game to the next level of team based AI game.

7/10 features

I feel the feature of personalising your char and weapons is a little slack, don't get me wrong the customisation that you can do so far is almost perfect but with a little push it would be perfect.
OK i know mods will change that but devs, add more shiZ, your char clothes list should be endless this will let us differ between who is who ingame, even with the bots i like to have different skins for what equipment the bots play, but with friends this is a must IMO.
Gun customisation is something i look for in a game too, i know the guns can have attachments on them but let us really customise or guns, let us position which side a flashlight is on and have a lazer on the other if we wish.. BUT punish us with weapon weight ~ ADS speed will be slower etc. (I want to have both, i get scared in the dark and i want lazer because i cant aim for shiZ.

At its core the game is great. Interesting level design and gameplay that forces you to take a slow, calculated approach to completing the objective. However, as someone who plays only single payer the AI is infuriating. Teammates continually seem to ignore commands, neglect to detain suspects and civilians, and when clearing an area often extend too far in passing open doorways where enemies could be located. This basically forces you to do everything yourself with the teammates used only as decoys and additional firepower (even then they cant be trusted).  Warning enemies prior to engaging risks them spinning 180 degrees and killing you instantly, but engaging without prior warning results in a penalty. Using the AI overhaul mod helps a little towards slowing enemy reaction times.

I'm currently experiencing a bug on the level Elephant where despite disarming the bombs the timer continues to run and detonates only killing me even when well clear of the explosive. Its only when I'm dead does Talk come over the radio confirming all bombs defused. Having bombs on this mission at all seems a really strange choice!

Overall i'd recommend the game if you enjoy tactical shooters, but wouldn't recommend purchasing at full price in its current state.

TL;DR - 4/10, Ready or Not has laid solid groundwork for itself in Early Access, but it was not ready for an official release. It has great potential but until it improves upon some fundamental issues I cannot recommend paying full price for this incomplete game.

Ready or Not is an intense SWAT-simulator where you are given a wide range of tools to take control of high-stakes situations and need to make split-second decisions in order to succeed. At least, that’s what it wants to be.

It upsets me to leave this game a negative review since had I left one about a year ago, when I first played the game in Early Access, it would have been positive. However, in its current state the game feels more flawed and incomplete than it felt prior to its official release and I sincerely hope the devs turn this around so I can enjoy the game RoN should be and recommend it to others in good faith.

The two biggest issues that sour my experience with the game at the moment are the shallow, unfun enemy AI and the shoddy implementation of new features.

When I first played RoN dealing with suspects was stressful but exciting. I had to cautiously choose the tools I used to deal with them, pay attention to their every move to prevent bloodshed and carefully assess when lethal force was necessary. After the 1.0 release however, every suspect, regardless of their background, became a battle hardened death machine that will shred you to bits in a split second if you don’t respond with violence immediately upon entering their line of sight. Many complain about the difficulty, which is fair since you’re playing against actual aimbots, but that’s not what ruins the experience for me. I don’t mind a challenge, but the new overpowered AI is far less fun to deal with even when you manage to beat it. This is because earlier you had to try and defuse the situation, then shoot if left with no other options. Now you shoot first, then try to apprehend the suspects if they’re still breathing. The intensity of confronting unpredictable suspects has been replaced with a repetitive test of reaction speed.

The new features that I have a gripe with are mostly related to the world-building and environmental storytelling of Ready or Not, which I found very intriguing upon my first contact with the game. The maps are extremely detailed, tell very little but show a lot. The official release introduced mission briefings which provide more context for the individual scenarios, but for some reason are highly inconsistent with the gameplay. Some are out of order, some make false claims (There is one example where this is intentional, but in other cases it doesn’t seem to be purposeful), not to mention the typos. It feels like the writers and programmers got the same prompt, made the brief and level separately and didn’t bother to cross-reference the two. Noticing these discrepancies really kills the immersion which is a key selling point of the game. There is also a prevalence of AI generated images littered across the new maps. It’s really disappointing to see the detailed environment downplayed by ugly, uninspired artificial “art” plastered on the walls. I also believe this is against Steam’s ToS, so I’m puzzled as to why the devs would risk getting their game removed instead of getting an artist to make some extra textures, especially since they managed to make the rest of the game look great without AI.

In regards to new gameplay elements there is now a career mode, which was clearly not thought through. It does pretty much nothing to enhance the gameplay, only results in pointless micromanagement and ultimately wastes a lot of your time. It seems that, for some reason, the devs rushed to release the game when they did, and did not take time to quality control the new additions.

When it comes to optimization, overall it’s not bad, I could run the game decently on a not so powerful rig, but there still are issues that need addressing. If I consistently had poor performance I could blame it on my PC, but if I have 60 FPS on one side of a room and 20 FPS on the other there is clearly something wrong here.

In general, Ready or Not has solid foundations, but until these problems are resolved I cannot consider this game “fully released” and recommend someone pays triple A price for this incomplete product.

Update: I tried the 1.0 update when it was released, and I like it so far with the SWAT AI. However, the one issue I have is the suspect AI. It seems like VOID gave them enhanced reflexes and the ability to shoot through walls that's impossible for the average human to react to and shoot.

Why? It doesn't feel any good; in fact, it gets irritating after you go through levels when there's tight space and one of your teammates gets in the way, and then you die because of that. To fix this, I had to download a mod called No Crack for AI from Nexus Mods to make the AI surrender and not be a superhuman, so at very least it's fun to play, but that's a band-aid fix that developers should have already done themselves before the "1.0 update" if it wasn't for their laziness and incompetence.

So, in the end, I like this update so far, except for the suspect AI. It needs to be balanced.

I do think this game is good, but I am only going to list out the bad points of this game here, the review is only "negative" you can read about some cons about the game.

though the bots do work fine for the first half of all of the maps, they do not do their job properly in bigger and more complex layouts. Normally when you want them to flash a room after opening a door, they do it just fine, but when the door is facing a wall on the other side, the bots do not try to throw the flash around, or bounce it deeper into the room, which results in their death when running into a single gunman, this limits your choice to throwing the flash by yourself, or enter the room with a shield, just so you can be consistent in achieving a high score. mean while, there's a nice mechanic where you can queue up commands so you can leave your bots and remotely tell them to do something, which allows you do execute nice entries that are satisfying, but this queuing of commands works in a poor fashion, this is because when you are looking through another doorway, and execute the queued command, the bots for no damned reason do the command on the door you are looking at instead of their door you already told them to post up on, this can be avoided by looking away from doorways when executing the queue, but because of how complex the maps can get, there could be doorways all around you and you just might accidentally execute the bug. lastly, it's the most annoying and infuriating aspect of the bots, which is that sometimes, they just stand around and do absolutely NOTHING when you give them a new command, while you can fix this by telling them to follow you and repeating the desired command again (turning the machine on and off again), EVEN THAT doesn't always work and the bots just stand there, being completely brain dead, which lead to many avoidable deaths that I have came across.

there are more nit picks about the bots, but these are the most egregious ones, and greatly limits player choice when trying to avoid using these mechanics as much as possible. I tried to find people who play the game and tries to get high scores and communicate, but the demographic that I played with in public lobbies generally do not know/understand swat tactics, and or just wants to gun everyone down, mean while I cannot find a clan that is within my timezone and aligns with my playstyle. If you are looking for a tactical experience, this game will do fine even in singleplayer, just be wary of your bot's capabilities and plan accordingly, and I hope these kinks will be ironed out in future patches.

There are many glaring issues and the 1.0 release felt like just an other EA patch. The devs also seem reluctant to acknowledge any fault, which is very bizarre.

Suspect AI is unrealistic and 1 dimensional. Every type of suspect from crackhead, to veteran, to teenagers robbing a store all act the same suicidal way. They will rush you down, they will fake surrender and they will 360 no scope you with the precision of an elite sniper.

Civilian AI is static as fuck. It seems they are supposed to be able to hide, yet they never do. They stand in place until you show up and yell for compliance, thats about it.

Swat AI is extremely robotic with zero decision making of their own. They feel like 4 roombas with guns that you control. They won't move to help you if you get shot, they won't hide if they are taking fire, they won't use the equipement you give them unless you specifically tell them to, its quite sad.

"S" rank, which means a perfect score for a map, is ruined by the fact you need to go non-lethal, in a map not designed for non-lethal. No non-lethal sidearm options and if you remove all sidearm ammo they will still swap to their empty sidearm and get stuck with it, unable to do anything. All non-lethal primary cannot penetrate or break windows, yet swat AI will shoot at windows regardless, while getting destroyed by suspects with guns that do penetrate windows. Some enemies with just suicide across the map, which means a suspect will be dead, which means you cannot get "S" anymore. This is somewhat a problem since cosmetics are locked behind "S" rank.

Still a lot of bugs left and right and optimisation isn't great.

The foundation of the game seems good, the game looks good, playing with friends is fun still and everything could be MUCH better, but apparently their patch release speed is abysmal.

Yet another unfinished game, riding on all the people that would like a SWAT 4 kind of game, but unable to deliver anything but pretty graphics and poor copy of SWAT/R6RS game features

In its current state, Ready or Not is nowhere near worth the full price, which is a shame because it's one of the best shooters available in terms of gunplay. Once you get past that initial layer of polish though, you'll realize just how half-baked and unfinished the core game is. 

Plenty of reviews have brought up how unfairly accurate and suicidally aggressive the enemy AI is - tracking you through walls, seeing you through smoke, refusing to surrender no matter how many guns are pointed at them - but your teammate SWAT AI is just as frustrating. They're hardcoded to a horrible degree, to the extent that they will clear a particular room in the exact same manner, following the exact same paths every time, even if enemies are firing at them or are in the way. If they have decided to restrain an enemy, there is no way for you to cancel that order or force them to fall back. In general, you can't even interrupt their current actions without running the risk of them bugging out and ignoring the next couple of commands you give them afterwards, which makes the entire system ridiculously tedious and inflexible during gameplay. 

The big selling point of the singleplayer "Commander" mode - managing a roster of SWAT officers and making sure their mental health doesn't crack from the missions you send them on - is also buggy and lackluster. Several officer abilities don't work. The mental health system is little more than a number on each officer that ticks up or down after a mission. Even more frustrating is that officer mental health takes the biggest hits from killing enemies on missions; this might fit thematically, but when every enemy always does their best to die by SWAT, it simply ends up punishing you for doing what the game, by default, forces you to do. As a result, playing Commander mode is practically no different than playing standalone missions with friendly bots, and is overall a worse experience because of the conflicting gameplay systems present.

However, I think the biggest problem with Ready or Not is that VOID Interactive comes across as a studio that has simply just checked out of their project. The current state of the game is what they advertised as 1.0, their full release, and yet it came with so many bugs that a basic QA pass would have caught immediately. This is a studio that, for whatever reason, decided to use a laughably poor AI to generate subtitles for voicelines, remove completed maps and gamemodes for "narrative purposes", and has a long list of features and promises that were brought up at one point and then never mentioned again. I have zero confidence that they will continue to support the game past the first half of 2024, especially since it's already spent years in Early Access prior to the 1.0 release. I'd love to be proven wrong, but until then, I'd play something else.

Ready or Not's 1.0 release feels half-baked. The lack of any real progression system, the removal of changing mission types on each level, and the ridiculous AI issues hinder this game from the true potential it had. Realism takes a back seat when it comes to AI interactions. They are dead accurate with a visual response time of milliseconds. Worst, is the inability to actually pierce through some objects when firing. It is unclear specifically what can and cannot be shot through. Some glass can be shot through, some can not. Enemies can shoot you through brick walls, while you cannot shoot them. It's just not well thought out in many ways and the development team's slow and inconsistent history of updates makes me feel like this game isn't going to receive the polish it deserves. Will I still play it? Yeah. Would I recommend it? Probably not.
