The game and concept are great. The Devs respond to the concerns of the community quite fast. But, the game can be very buggy at times. Such as being unable to arrest certain suspects even though the game requires that you do so, Or shooting a suspect and them not taking damage from being shot. As well the aim of the suspects can be pretty annoying, with the suspects aiming primarily for the arms and legs instead of your armor. Or dying from 2 shots even though you haven't taken damage. Other than the negatives the game is a fun fps shooter with a more tactical point of view than the regular fps.

TL;DR: Game is great, But there are a few bugs and design choices that can be annoying.

Edit:The game has become worse. Prior to my review I had naively believed the devs would listen to the community. But, as I have seen with new updates and notes about the game, the devs have clearly not paid much attention to their own community. As of right now the game is hot garbage for fixes and playability. To fix the game from jumping from 60 fps to 2 I had to lower the graphical settings to low, as well I must run vsync to satiate the fps problems. If I were to give advice for fixing your game just mod the game, the ai has become unfightable without flash-bangs or steel plates and a shield. And due to the new 1.0 update removing different modes such as barricaded suspects and raid and so on, if you were to shoot first you gain a penalty against your final score. Modding the game seems to be the only thing to do now.

Heck it even runs worse than EA somehow. I'm no expert in weaponry, but I'm 99% sure a human will not survive point blank shot in the head from a shotgun.

This game is great. I played a lot of Swat 4 back in the day and I was waiting for a worthy replacement/sequel, I have to say that this game is it. Weapon selection, missions that link together within their own story-line, officer morale and mods are just some of the things I love about this game.

Ok, time to update the review for version 1.0...
I have mixed bud more of positive feelings about the game and it's "1.0". Tldr its the spiritual succesor to SWAT games and the game is good but it has few issues and it should be left in the oven for a little more.

 Let's write some points for new and interested people and then get to the changes and opinions:

Positives:
+Great gunplay
+Tactical action and variety of tools
+Capable friendly AI for SP mode
+Immersion
+Atmosphere
+Enviromental story telling
+Soundtrack and sound desing
+Various maps and locations (gas stations, crack houses, hotels, luxurious villas, cult compounds...)
+Balls for the realism and severity of depicted crimes (CP, human trafficing, drugs, domestic terrorism, "active shooters in educational location"...) and managing doing it respectfully without any glorification
+Graphics
+Every gun and tool has it's use

Negatives:
-Enemy suspect AI (it needs a little bit tinkering from devs, suspects are still too like terminators, the devs are working on it but it will take time)
-Basic and barebone weapon customisation, you can only put optic, foregrip and one illuminating attachement on gun (might change in future)
-Optimalisation (It's improving but it's still not there)
-A little bit clunky movement system
-Singleplayer mode is micromanagement heavy (this is personal negative)
-Some guns and tools while useful are very situational
-Rare visual glitches
-Some maps have multiple spawn locations but the selection works only sometimes and only on some of the maps.
-Game is limited for 5 players at the time (can be resolved with mods)
-Poor modding integration

Now changes and personal opinions:

What changed in 1.0 since early access version? A lot. There is new hub police station, new and better shooting range, new maps, few new weapons, new visual customisation system, reworked friendly AI, new sound system, new singleplayer mode, new immersive tablet (with briefings and maps during pregame lobby and with map and objectives during the missions) ability to command civilians and surrendering suspects, the Hotel map was removed, other maps were modified/reworked/improved etc. 

What should changed but wasn't? Enemy suspect AI, it's a little bit better than old john wick terminator from EA versions but its still borderline cheating (flawless accuracy, hyper agressive and almost suicidal, hearing that would beat even bats, no recoil, tracking through walls, resistant to damage, inhuman reflexes, sketchy animations - suspects often snap from stun to shooting in miliseconds...), weapon customisation (same barebone system from EA days, and it's sometimes broken). 

Personally I like the new version of RoN, it is an improvement but it's not perfect and there are some missed opportunities (some might be done later). Look for example at streamer map. It could be "just an accidental swatting" with streamer and like one or two suspects guarding the farm but NO we got like 10 highly agressive teenagers with shotguns and AKs plus the streamer (who is always at the same place btw)

What could be improved/changed? Already mentioned weapon customisation and suspect AI. More and new tactical tools like camera drones (there is already system wich shows headcams in the tablet, just make it use the drones camera too) and I don't mean those silly cameras on wheels from "tactical" game wich I don't dare to name here. There are loadouts for guns and gear but not for visual customisation wich is a miss. There is no idicator what is player's best rank on the mission during the mission select ( if you want to know which missions you already completed on S-rank the best dyi solution for now is checking the tatoo customisation sice tatoos are rewards for S-ranks) wich could be added to the briefing (like a new tab that would show all players ranking on selected map). Make lights on the shield actually work. I know and understand why was taser moved to tactical from secondary slot and I like that decision but what is stupid is that now we cannot equip shield and tazer together.

Good game but still cannot recommend for $50.00. There are far to many issues still remaining for a game at this price point. 

Your AI Swat team often do not follow commands to breach or enter and clear a room, or sometimes one guy will inexplicably  wander off for no reason (forcing you to track them down) and they have a tendency to give away your position by yelling at civilians and AI baddies who are meters away and behind closed doors. 

AI baddies still blindly shoot through walls, in many cases with pin point accuracy, they will, in the blink of an eye, 180 snap shoot directly to your head, Doors can be checked repeatedly for booby traps, using both wand and peaking the door, with none being found but as soon as you open the door, it will unexpectedly explode. 

Any one of these issues occurring periodically could be ignored but these issues occur regularly and as stated at the beginning that should not happen with a game at this price point. Most can be fixed using mods, like the AI overhaul mod (which is terrific), but some issues still remain even with that mod and for the average player, in my opinion, this ruins the game. 

I hope the Devs are working on fixing these and many other issues and I will still most likely continue playing, but primarily because I spent $50.00 on the game. Until these issues are resolved you should not spend the money....unless you are drawn to the grind or intrigued by the challenges described above...then have at it.

Secondly, the Commander mode with the counseling is an annoying feature since your squad could get wiped easily, you cannot get killed twice, or they are in crisis or resigning. Lastly, our team AI is pretty useless. I get that, so the player gets more of the action, but they mostly just watch you die, so you have to watch out for yourself.

After putting in 48 hours, [b]I do NOT recommend Ready or Not[/b]. Situations in RoN range from raiding small-time arms manufacturers to drug busts to active shooters at public locations. Though a fun and intense game, a lot of deaths are more frustrating than fun, and the more I played RoN, the more I realized a lot of gameplay includes game-breaking flaws instead of one-off glitches are incidents.

[b][u]Customization:[/u][/b]
RoN offers a lot of different weapons and loadout choices, including primary weapons and secondary weapons, armor, lethal and less-lethal weapons,  and a variety of tools/deployables. I enjoyed utilizing different loadouts depending on the scenario, but it also wasn't always clear on first playthrough which levels would be better with which loadout types.

The effectiveness of each deployable seemed to be very inconsistent, resulting in many cases where a stinger grenade can go off right on top of an enemy and yet they end up not effected at all by the blast. This often results in needless deaths of you and your team that get frustrating.

In order to receive the maximum score on a map, nobody, including enemy combatants, can die in the mission. Therefore, the only way to receive a perfect score is to utilize less-lethal weapons and deployables. However, there are many levels where utilizing less-lethals doesn't even make sense, most of all terrorist attacks.

Armor selections mean less slots for ammo and deployables, and the type of armor each has their benefits and drawbacks. However, it isn't directly clear from the descriptions of which armor type actually offers the better survivability (and under which scenarios), so that level of customization doesn't necessarily help.

Lastly, the game allows you to change the look of your character and what clothes they wear under all the armor, etc. I [i]was[/i] a little disgusted that you could unlock a wristband to wear that matched the wristbands worn by shot-up patrons of a nightclub during an active shooter/terrorist attack. I know it's "just a game", but that was a tasteless addition.

[b][u]Missions[/u][/b]
The types of missions vary, which also means the size of the maps, the types of enemies and their loadouts, and the overall design. The missions are generally grouped to follow connected storylines. It's fun seeing how the success of one mission can produce evidence that leads to another mission down the road.

Within the missions, you can encounter varying amounts of enemies and civilians. And the locations where enemies and civilians spawn is varied, forcing you to take caution each time and not just "memorize" enemy locations. Certain missions can also include explosive traps on doors or bombs that must be defused within a time limit. These add another element of caution and tactics required to successfully navigate a mission without dying.

Missions with active shooters means that the enemies will try to kill civilians sometimes. Receiving an S on a level requires all civilians to survive. However the AI can sometimes decide to kill a civilian instantly. You can get lucky and the civilian is only incapacitated instead of dead, but that is truly luck of the draw.

[b][u]Enemy AI[/u][/b]
Although there are many different enemy types dependent on the level the behavior and capabilities of the enemy AI is one of the biggest issues with RoN. Even with mods that change those behaviors and capabilities, the Enemy AI is often way too powerful.

Enemies can detect you, turn around, acquire their target, shoot, and accurately hit you (often killing you or putting you in bleed status) before you can even react to their presence. Their accuracy is insane, whether they are shooting a long distance or actively moving fast while firing a machine gun. When first playing, I thought some of my deaths were luck of the draw that I or a teammate got killed so quickly, but after playing almost 50 hours it's clear that the AI is just too good sometimes. Regardless of enemy type faced, they all seem to be professional shooters with godly reaction times, which is very frustrating.

In order to successfully take an enemy out of the fight, you must kill them, incapacitate them, or arrest them. Incapacitated enemies can actually be faking it and end up standing back up. So cuffing an incapacitated enemy is a must. To arrest an enemy, you have to shout them down. Most of the time, enemies will not surrender just to shouting. Hitting them with less lethal munitions or deployables,will usually result in them surrendering. However, enemies can choose to stand back up and continue the fight with a sidearm or knife. So you need to keep your eye on surrendered enemies and arrest them ASAP. My biggest gripe with this behavior, similar to the issue with AI shooting ability, is there isn't variety between enemy combatants. A meth addict is just as likely to un-surrender and attack you again as professional security. The behavior of enemies just doesn't always match the type of combatant, and, currently, the rate of enemies standing back up after surrendering is extremely high.

[b][u]Friendly AI[/u][/b]
If you are playing the single player mode you command a team of 4 SWAT members. Utilizing the Friendly AI can be important as they are just as capable as the enemy AI at shooting. However, the AI design is overall very poor and glitchy, often in ways that gets you or them killed.

AI often enter the room in a stupid manner. The AI will often enter a room and turn their back to the one opening, giving enemies the chance to shoot them repeatedly in the back. Other times, an area is big enough that the AI will spread out and clear different parts of the area alone instead of in tandem, putting each individual member more at risk of dying to enemies they encounter. Lastly, once they have cleared a room of all active combatants, it's important for them to arrest suspects. Unfortunately, many times their pathing or command glitches, and they'll just leave people uncuffed. As I mentioned with the enemy AI, they are able to surrender and then decide to stand back up and fight. Even directly commanding your AI to arrest suspects often glitches out so that your teammates ignore the command.

Lastly, the AI does not know how to properly handle open doors in a room. Once they've cleared the current room, they require another command to move to the next room before continuing and will just stand still. If an enemy in the next room spots them through the doorway, they will kill your teammate while they just stand there and die.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
Overall, I've enjoyed the game a lot as a tactical shooter, including playing the single player mode and playing with friends online. However, the current design of the game includes too many issues to recommend the game to anyone, especially at $50. Enemy AI are too powerful at times, regardless of "who" they are. Friendly AI are poorly programmed and prone to glitches. The core gameplay is pretty good, though, and a lot of thought went into designing most levels. Many improvements are required to put the game at a place where I'd recommend it to others.
Shoot bad guy, pepper spray hostage. Very Good.

Positive:
-Great "realistic" Swat simulator
-Gun play
-Damage simulation for body parts
-Loadout modification from guns to body armor type
-single player with team member management (could be deeper than just managing and putting to therapy)
- a blast to play with friends
-traps and hiding (would like to have more scenarios and AI behaviors like that)

Negative:
- Stutters especially when first time playing new maps.  
- spectating other team members camera while still alive tanks the frame rate.
- Caliber description/effectiveness (like difference between SOME and SERVICEABLE. Could be clearer.)
- Friendly AI breaks down:
->Refusing to move or do orders, cannot go around you if they are ordered to do something and the player is in their path even if there is enough room.
-> sometimes going to ordered place while walking backwards and getting shot at the back of their head.
-> sometimes fails to cover player or each other when hostile run outs through the door even if stacked on the same door and/or getting killed without firing a shot.
-> often doesn't take cover on bigger maps like hospital and gets gunned downed while standing in the middle of the hall way.
-> On hospital map bots don't move on stacks on long corridors and advance to far from the party and gets killed.

-Enemy AI
-> inhuman reflexes, sometimes shoot you before their animations are done. (like turning around and shooting).
-> sometimes feels like the bots hit boxes doesn't register or dosen't have an effect even if 2 to 3 party members dump a hole mag on target with AR. 
-> bots flinch when taking damage irregularly. like when shooting their leg of with shotgun and they still walk on pair of bones (and probably kill you).

Hopeful improvement ideas:
- Performance
-AI (fixes and new tactics behavior)
-More guns and calibers, Longer barrels to improve velocity and stopping power etc.
-More maps
-Revive system (friendlies could go unconscious and be patched up by a friendly. Or hostiles could even take a friendly as hostage if unconscious). -Dragging system to pull them to cover like on squad.
- A backpack to get ammo and utility gear when not playing on full MP squad. You simply run out of stuff when playing less than a full party because of limited inventory slots. Why not have a backpack compensating for the missing team members. Of course you would have to take of the bag off and look into the bag to get more equipment which leaves you vulnerable. 
- More in depth SP story than just debriefs or officer lore texts.

The game is fun and frustrating.

Now that the game is released, they messed up the AI and now they are all John Wick and will kill you through walls with a Makarov. It's crazy to have some Joe Schmoe in street clothes be a tactical genius who can track you through walls. AI has such insane reaction time and accuracy making peeking nigh impossible and sometimes they will shake off stuns (Flashbangs, etc) instantly or not be effected at all. 

The maps are beautiful and polished, but they are so cluttered and often times AI will see and shoot you through obstacles you won't be able to, which exacerbates the AI issues. Furthermore, the piss poor grenade physics makes these obstacles a pain in the ass to make sure your grenade goes where you want it. 

Don't touch the mods if you plan on playing with other people, even touching the screen will prevent you from connecting to other people unless you get the exact same mods. If you do, make sure to delete all the mods/mod folder.

I'm not gonna ramble too much about all the technical nonsense since people already explained more than enough the sad state of the game's AI since the 1.0 release.
So let's talk about the campaign, it sucks. That's about it, the game doesn't have an overarching 'plot', the characters feel stiff as hell because they are, and pretty much everyone in the fucking game has 0 personality, from teammates to suspects.
Speaking of teammates, what VOID doesn't realise is that the reason why we loved them back in SWAT 4 was that we didn't have to switch between a bunch of nobodies every 2 missions because 'oh no I shot someone', and I understand that Ready or Not has a significantly 'darker' tone than SWAT 4 but god damn, the officers have about as much personality as a fucking sandpaper. There is no banter between teammates, only one-liners that... aren't even noticeable, I mean holy shit you have to have certain members JUST to get one extra line of dialogue on some maps. VOID cannot humanize neither civilians, nor your teammates nor anyone else, it just sucks. And it's directly a result of the game taking itself way too seriously.
Games either oughta have Marvel-esque writing or try too hard to be as gritty as possible, gritty as long as it doesn't cut their sales of course.
The mission designs are not faring any better here... they're very forgettable, like super forgettable. The soundtrack is a downgrade compared to the 5 tracks that were available in early access surprisingly, the 'lore' is dogwater, so really this game doesn't have much going on for it... except the gunplay.
So it's just a glorified COD campaign but only the tactical bits and we're not fighting Russians (not exclusively at least) for once.
Just don't waste your money on this, even if they patch out every single problem, the lore, story, characters and the entire setting of the game will never not be uninteresting.

Okay, while I do love this game, it has some HUGE issues that are impossible to ignore while playing. In my opinion, it's a 3 out of 5 stars, UNTIL they can optimize this game. BUT it has POTENTIAL to be a 5 out of 5. Some of the issues include...

SWAT AI
-I don't get where people are saying that the swat AI are "massively" improved. They are still just as dumb. The only things that have changed is their stacking (which is still bad), and will USUALLY gather evidence/ arrest on their own, meaning sometimes they will outright not do this. A lot of times, when gathering/ arresting, they will completely walk into danger just to do this, such as stepping in line of fire, standing in doorways, walking into uncleared areas, etc, which will usually get them killed. Their stacking has improved somewhat. The actual stack looks okay, but they only sometimes provide coverage. There are times where the AI are "covering" a doorway, and an enemy AI outright kills one of the swat members from the inside room, so another swat member fills that position, providing empty "coverage" and does nothing to react to the enemy that is standing in the corner of the swat AI's view. A lot of the time, their "coverage" isn't really coverage. During stacking they will also over-expose themselves into the doorway, allowing enemy AI to just full auto into them. 

- SWAT AI constantly get in your way, and now they will also tell YOU, that you are in their way. You can have them stack, but if you want to be the first man in, you have to work around them, because if you get in their "spot" they will not shut up about how you are in their way. Once you give command to open and clear, they will not do so because one of the swat members are not in their "position". So if you wanna be first man in, you gotta either awkwardly work around them, or have them stack on the opposite side of you, which then exposes your back in a lot of areas. They will also get stuck in random places, trapping you in the process, this happens a lot in doorways.

- SWAT AI will get stuck and not follow commands. You can tell them to stack up, and they will not do so at random times. Then you have to switch between "fall in" and "stack up" a few times until they finally listen to the command. This obviously takes unnecessary time, and is super annoying when you are trying to get into a room quickly.

- SWAT animation is wayyy too slow. It takes them much longer than it should to stack, check if door is unlocked, open door, and then breach. Each specific animation takes too much time, especially when opening the door, they will take too much time opening the door, which allows them to be shot while in the animation to open door. Swat AI also does not follow each other close enough, leaving gaps when breaching. They will trail too far behind you, leaving you exposed constantly. It's more like "follow the leader" rather than them covering different sectors. 

- Swat will constantly shoot in full auto, and completely empty their pistol, only to barely hit the enemy AI, but will somehow accidentally kill any nearby innocent. If enemy AI takes a hostage, swat will not think twice to full auto into innocent, killing them, then full auto into enemy. 

-Swat AI will tend to bug out, and wander off on their own, into random parts of the map for no reason, getting themselves killed, which then leaves you with no clue what happened to them until you stumble upon their body. When clearing, they tend to over-extend into uncleared areas, with too many different angles to cover on their own, overwhelming themselves and getting killed. They sometimes will clear areas in an awkward manner, walking in backwards and unable to react to a threat until they turn around.  

LIGHTING ISSUES
- In almost every map, there is this ridiculous amount of blinding haze created by lights/sunshine. Which blinds you to the point where you can't even see what's in front of you, which gets you killed.

- Red dots are almost useless. The dot is so dim you can't even see it and effectively use it, this is a problem I have brought up to the devs before.

-Flashlights are too dim and narrow, almost as if they want this to be a horror game rather than a realistic-tactical shooter. Modern weapon lights are very bright and have a wide amount of coverage, capable of flooding an entire room with light. 

- Night vision is almost useless, in dark areas there will still be unnecessary dark shadows that should not be there when using nvg's. 

ENEMY AI
- Enemy AI are all cracked out, capable of spinning 360 degrees and shooting you in the head instantly. I've had enemy's do this to me and swat AI with a pistol.

-Half the time, enemy AI will completely ignore a flashbang or c2 charge, even if they were right next to the detonation.

- Enemy AI is incredibly accurate, capable of shooting full auto from across the map, and effectively hitting you with almost every round.

- Enemy AI will react through even the smallest opening, shooting any moment a single pixel of you is exposed.

- Enemy AI will shrug off rifle rounds. I have died while shooting them center mass with a 556 rifle, only for them to not feel a thing and walk straight towards me and kill me. Other times I will shoot them, they kinda "bend over" in pain, then to get up and shoot back, running away as if they are totally uninjured. 

- Enemy AI will constantly know where you are at, capable of hearing you from multiple rooms away, and knowing the exact spot you are standing in.

CONSTANT FRAME DROP AND STUTTERING
-The game is not optimized, no matter what you do to the settings, the game constantly will stutter and have massive frame rate drop, The game needs to be better optimized.

VOID DOES NOT LISTEN TO IT'S CUSTOMERS
- They got rid of great map's that were fun to play, as well as the option to choose different scenarios for that map, which would give you different locations to play on, in specific maps. Original hotel and it's secondary map for barricaded suspect. Original port map with its secondary map for bomb threat and hostage rescue. The original farm map. The fast food map (which was a work in progress). There was no reason to remove these. 

Overall the game is fun to play, however there are a lot of annoying issues with it. I don't believe this game was ready for an official release, and needed a lot more work prior to the official release. As of now I give 3 out of 5 stars.

The multiplayer, which is why I got this game - based on the multiplayer marketing/features - is terrible. You also cannot filter for servers or see servers or anything. some people run mods that you dont want to play, but it is not possible to see what mods or settings are being used in any hosted games that you join. this game also doesn't feel like 1.0 and should still be in early beta - the AI just isn't polished. The game is absolutely not worth $50, probably closer to $15. It is very fun at first, but then becomes extremely underwhelming. The player characters movement is also illogical at times, and again, makes this game feel very much like a beta game. STEAM should have more regulation regarding alpha/beta/1.0 completed games.

i also just need to add that the overall mechanics of the game really need more polishing. It REALLY feels like an alpha or early beta just on those grounds alone - like very basic character movement etc. Very surprising as bad as it is, given how easy it is to implement these days in development. 

Unfortunately, the player base can also be exceedingly toxic; there is proxy chat and sometimes the racism/sexism and overall really ugly vulgarities are just too much. unfortunately, there is no way to report players or anything, so people can say and do whatever they want.

What an absolute stuttery mess. The game is insanely single thread limited. Christ on a stick is it bad. - RTX3070
- 32GB RAM

This system is way above the recommended specs. 

Also the tutorial is hella confusing. The game tells you to use an optiwand on the wrong door. Why?! Most impatient gamers would probably close the game and refund it by now.

Thoughts after playing the full game or 1.0 patch:
I loved this game when it was Early Access, now that it's full (sort of) I love it even more.
I don't care what anybody says, I don't encounter that many bugs and glitches. Now I'm not saying they're not there. You will come across bugs and glitches but what game doesn't have bugs or glitches? In my opinion triple A games are even worse sometimes. 
But we're not here to talk about triple A games. 
I wanna talk about Ready or Not and thank the developers for making me feel that special feeling when I played masterpieces that gaming companies used to make in the 90s or 2000s.
Most games today are so simple that it doesn't matter which one you get, you have three objectives: Grind, Rank up, Be competitive.
Ready or Not is not like most games today and most gamers wouldn't like this game because they're so used to "Run and gun" or "Team-Deathmatch meta". In simple words games today have made people lazy, they just want to compete and prove the weaker person they're better and tell the better player to get a life.
In Ready or Not you don't grind, you learn to survive and keep your teammates alive. 
You don't rank up, you gain knowledge and make better strategies the next mission or the next restart. 
You don't compete, you learn teamwork and how important it is to work together, if you try to go solo you or your team won't make it till the end of the mission.
This game does have problems, yes. But they don't bother me because there's way more pros than cons, at least for me. What I'm trying to say is, if you're like me and you still want to play a game that isn't about who has a higher KD or who has a higher rank, or which strat is better now and where you can relax without anybody fighting in the chat, this game is for you. Because at the end of the day you can play this game every day or once in a while, at the end of it we all have one objective. To cuff 'em up and let them hang.
It's like playing Rainbow Six Siege where every enemy has aimbot :)

Edit: 360, wallbanging, noscope, aimbot Suspect AI is just infuriating - Devs have a way to go to make the AI actually act like human beings with self preservation in mind. I get it if we are up against a coked out druggie that would storm you, but giving the same "class" aimbot and wallhacks doesnt make any sense. Same with your regular hoodlum being the second coming of John Wick and not fearing for their life while staring down the barrel of 5 SWAT officers yelling for compliance. Final map also has too far of a range for compliance to work, they really dont care, but still detect you from across the map, so you end up having to shoot them with lethal.

Overall, I think this game is very fun if you're into tactical FPS games that require some level of critical-thinking to complete missions. For that alone, I recommend it. The new 1.0 version is a giant leap forward for the playability of the game. Despite this, I think there are some QoL improvement to be made. Here are a few:

1. The post-mission status report (i.e. grading screen) should be skippable. Having to sit through the whole grading, particularly for more difficult missions, becomes tiresome.
2. Related to the above, players should be able to "replay" mission without having to jump back to the HQ and then reload the map. I think this whole process should be optional in case players want to make loadout/squad modifications.
3. There is a glitch with the flashlight on the Pepperball gun. I select laser and it still runs the flashlight.
4. The AI are incredibly quick, accurate, and can see/shoot through walls. Their reaction time needs to be lowered, because as it stands they can turn and shoot you in less than a second.
5. The squad AI need a new "back up" or "get the f* out of my way" command (or need to be adjusted). They cluster into doorways and prohibit the player from quickly moving through rooms.
6. The player AI sometimes do not respond to player commands/prompts, particularly when it comes to "Restrain" or "Deploy" commands. The AI sometimes become stuck in idle.
7. The "Execute" command needs to be reviewed. I task both Red and Blue teams with their respective actions, but once I 'execute' them, they fall into only performing the action of one team. E.g., if I task them with breaching and clearing a room through two separate doors, they stack up on one door and perform a single breaching action (this is especially bad for maps like Valley of the Dolls with multiple entries into small rooms).

Ready or Not? Not Ready. This game still needs some work before it can call itself finished. My main grievances essentially boil down to the AI being superhuman and the optimization being poor.

I wouldn't blame you if you mistook the crackheads and cartel members you get into gunfights with for T-800s. The reaction time and accuracy of enemy AI is ridiculous. The nature of this game encourages you to play at a slow and methodical pace, yet you are punished by near-instantaneous deaths from all-seeing, hyper accurate demi-gods before you even have the chance to aim. This is especially frustrating considering the fact that dying at any point during a mission will net you a loss and require you to restart it in its entirety.

I said that the optimization was poor, which was being generous. This game's performance is laughably bad. Impressive even, given the engine it runs on. I run a high-end rig and find my PC regularly dropping to 30 FPS on some maps, even on low settings. This is an issue that is not specific to my PC either, as many, many other players corroborate that the performance is egregious as well.

Compounding the poor performance with overtuned AI and hardcore gameplay elements, you're left with a rather unfulfilling and frustrating experience. The foundations of something great are certainly here, but this game still needs work before it can be considered [strike]complete[/strike] ready.

This game is the tactical shooter I have been waiting for. It's a slow (no sprint), methodical, and tense experience unlike any other game I've played, broken up by intense and unforgiving shootouts. There are 18 maps currently and the random placement of enemies and civilians make each game a different experience. The Police aspect adds gameplay aspects that are new to me: The idea of "Rules of Engagement" and non-lethal takedowns are a great style but totally avoidable if you don't care about score. Which I try not to.

The game is obviously meant to be played with friends but the single player experience is pretty good in it's own way. You only get AI squad mates when playing solo but being able to order them around changes the strategy nicely. It does mean that playing solo with 4 bots can be easier than playing with only 2 players. I haven't tried to play with other public players.

The npc activities are incredibly well done. Enemies will play dead or fake a surrender, and take civilians as human shields. civilians will panic and flee if there's too much going on. An npc you thought was safe could pick up a fallen gun while you look away and turn on you.

I really like the slow progression of difficulty between each levels, almost every level adds in a new mechanic that you have to look out for like trip mines, new enemy behaviour, and threats (although it does mean that early levels could become boring for lacking these mechanics).

There are no equipment unlocks, meaning that you start with all the tools and can try out everything to find a setup that works. Which might change depending on the mission select. Some customisation options are locked behind level score requirements but most are pretty easy to get.

When all the objectives of a mission are completed the game ends and you are given a score depending on how you did. This score is strictly for achievements/bragging rights and don't negatively impact you. It's based mostly heavly on 1: Completing level objectives 2: Rescuing all the civilians and 3: Keeping the players alive. You get bonus points for taking the "Suspects" (the bad guys) alive but it isn't required to complete the level. Some levels have objectives for taking specific Suspects alive but the mission doesn't fail if you kill them. I've "completed" levels with an F rank before and probably will again.

The game is DIFFICULT. The enemies are merciless and great at holding angles, flanking, and taking you by surprise. As of right now, there is a lot of talk about the bots being TOO strong: reacting too fast and being too accurate. My opinion is that they're mostly fine. I've seen very few instances of them being aimbot/wall hacking. The fast reaction can be worked around by moving slowly and avoiding doors that they're actively guarding will allow you to get the jump on them. When the bullets start flying though it's better to get behind cover rather than try and out shoot them.

One downside that all of my friends ran into was the Tutorial being broken in some way or another. It's a bad first introduction to the game.

If you're looking for a slower more tactical shooter then you might love this game, there's already a lot of content to enjoy and I'm looking forward to additional content that is likely to come at some point in the future. Also there's already a large modding community releasing content but I haven't tried any mods yet.

I love this game, even with my bad PC where I have to set the graphics lower than normal, I still liked the game. Even so, I had some issues with the game.

First: The SWAT AI. It's terrible. I command my team to go down a hall, and if there is a room to the left or right and the doors are open or an enemy opens it, they will just keep going while the enemy guns down half my team, and only one of my team actually tries to attack. I think it's because with each command, they take their own roles, so only one or two are actually shooting. But they should at least react; it's supposed to be a realism game. You would think someone would react getting shot in their rib three times. The SWAT just doesn't feel like SWAT; when they attack the enemy, they never do it well, and more times than not, they end up getting killed, and sometimes my whole team. You would probably be better off playing solo.

Second: The enemy AI. The enemy AI, paired with the horrible SWAT AI, is just... I have no word for it. I pulled an all-nighter for one map multiple times, and you would think after all that I would get better? Nope, I tried many different loadouts for me AND my team; I'm still not past that map, and I've given up by now. It's just the bad SWAT AI paired with the crackshot aim, past military training AI, makes the game unnecessarily hard. I don't want it to be too easy where you can just fly through the game, but you really don't understand how long I was trying on a SINGLE map. Even the meth heads seem to have better coordination than my team.

Third: This is kind of a small one, but it's the streamer map. If you look close enough at the art in the streamer map, it's AI. They used AI for the pictures. It wouldn't have costed that much to just hire someone to make art, maybe in early access, but full release? AI art in full release? Seriously? I guarantee you they had enough money to hire an artist to just make art, but no, they had to hop on that weird AI trend for the art. It's so stupid; I don't know why they would make it AI.

That's really all I have to say. I know some idiots are going to give me the Jester award because they can't handle an opinion, but oh well.

Bad AI and awful performance that gets worse with every update. Modders have fixed the most glaring issues with the AI in an hour that the dev team has not been able to fix in 3 years. S Rank requirements are deranged and the game isn't built for it. Suspects can also shoot themselves or each other and you get a docked rank as a result.

Singleplayer seems fun for 2 missions and then the glaring issues pop up. AI teammates are terminators that will insta-dome suspects across the map but then need therapy after 2 missions because apparently shooting at people with beanbag shotguns gives them PTSD.

Multiplayer is OK but things get so laggy that it's barely playable. Riddled with technical issues, you can't turn off the forced film grain for instance.

They lied about a lot of their promises with the 1.0 release, removing things like alternate mission types in the same map.

The concept of the game is great. You can think of it as an updated version of "Swat 4" game from 2005. Some  issues I've ran into while playing is that the non-lethal weapons don't seem to be doing their part, as in the bean bag shotgun nor the pepper ball gun does not stun/stagger the criminals. The grenades also don't seem to be working properly. With this, the game is pretty tough, especially when adding that the criminals don't seem to be missing their shots and can shoot you through walls. However, these are all issues that can be fixed. Hope to be playing this more often.

Update:
This game is released now. The guns have been fixed, but the grenades are unreliable. The gas grenade will, at times, not effect a suspect who is not even wearing a gas mask. In my experience, the most reliable grenade is the stinger, since the flash grenade will not hit a suspect who is not looking at it.

The AI teammates in the game are useless, bug out often, and will body block you in a hallway so the suspects can kill you. They constantly make noise, so good luck trying to sneak around. The suspects will hear the AI teammates and start unloading on you.

The suspect AI is massively overpowered. They will empty a clip into a wall and kill you with a head shot. Shoot through doors while you are opening it. Pre-fire from corners while unloading a full clip into you. Sit in a corner of the room until you get near and then unload a full clip into you. Reload in half a second.

This game is more so a shooter like Rainbow Six, but masquerading as a SWAT game.
The missions go from SWAT like, into full blown shooter status towards the latter missions.

I still play it since there isn't any other game as similar to SWAT.

Update:

I forgot to mention the framedrops. Why? No idea. Both DX 11 and DX12 will result in massive frame drops regardless of what setting you put it at.  Frames will drop whenever you are around AI, which adds to the "fun" of shooting them before they shoot you when they have aim bot and you have 10 frames, if even.

Last Update:
I'm pretty much done with this game. The suspects have instant AIM BOT. As in, they will turn and shoot you square in your face as soon as they see you. You have no chance to respond. If you're playing single player, good luck because your squad AI is literally retarded and will constantly yell which attracts the attention of all suspects on the map. You will consistently see this in Ides of March where the suspects will already know where you are as soon as you start the map. The guns are pretty much all trash and there's no difference between the majority of them. The only gun that actually staggers suspects is the bean bag shotgun. You need to stagger because the suspects are unloading their entire clip into you as soon as they see you. So if you're trying to outgun them, best of luck since their bullets stagger you but you don'[t even tickle them.
Seeing as to how it's been 3 years since this game went into development and this is the AI of suspects on "Release", best of luck. It will likely take 5 years for this to even get fixed in which case the game would have already died.

it finally feels like this can be called a worthy predecessor to swat 4, levels are unforgiving and unpredictable making mastering them a lot of fun, the Single player AI is somewhat capable and the briefings and general atmosphere feel authentic.

simple mod support and multiplayer make this great for replayablility but i find it still stings a little not having any over arching progression or store system to make completing levels with high ranks even more rewarding. and i love that there is now a light story and level by level campaign to play through now instead of being bombarded with a range of maps and modes that barely work. maps are nice and tight now too making it clearer where to look and progress through a level without wandering around too much.

im sure ill keep coming back to this from time to time to complete permadeath mode and get full S rank. i hope they continue to add new maps, features, and hopefully some more unlockable content.

Is this game have flaws? Yes. Is this game still fun? Absolutely! I'm not even a big fan of FPS game but I'm enjoying this game very much.

I must said from the beginning to everyone that interested to buy this game: this game is not for everyone. If you like quick paced action shooting game when you can shoot everybody easily, or an one man army shooting game when killing enemy is the only objective, then this game is not for you. But, if you like tactical shooting game when you need to proceed very carefully and prioritize teamwork, then this game is for you. 

Let's start with the positives in this game. First, this game really makes you feel like a real SWAT personnel (well, for me at least): commanding your squad (or communicating with your friend when you play multiplayer), using a variety of tools for a variety of different situations, the fear of death and failure, is something that I enjoy a lot. You can't go alone recklessly in this game because you are not an one man army.

Second, THERE IS NO MICROTRANSACTIONS in this game! All the weapon are unlocked right from the start, and for customizable gear, you can unlock it after finishing mission with good score. I think this is something that should be highly appreciated, considering the recent gaming market conditions which are full of microtransactions. I hope the developers will maintain this principle.

Now, let's talk about the negative thing. I think the main negative thing in this game is the problem with the suspect AI (the enemy). For most of the time, they can see past wall and shoot you right away! Not to mention that they have a very quick reaction time (lot of video already shown this issue). This problem often make the game unbalanced. But is this problem make the game cannot be beaten? Not really. I already complete lots of map in single player, and even in multiplayer (with just one of my friend) we are able to finish some of the map (after a lotttt of restart). Of course I don't support this situation. Because this problem make feel frustrated for lot of the time. I just want to say that this game can still be enjoyed, and I hope the developer can solve this problem soon.

Second, playing multiplayer DIDN'T COUNT FOR ACHIEVEMENT. It's like, what the hell? I don't know if this was something intentional by the developer, or an unintentional bug. it's really annoying! Why make us can only get the achievement by playing the single player mode? It feels like all the efforts achieved from multiplayer are in vain. Please make the achievement count in multiplayer, dev!

I think that's all I want to say regarding this game. Don't hesitate to buy this game if you have the money. Because I'm sure you won't regret it (but you will very likely be frustrated when playing this game haha)

The game has finally released into it's 1.0 state after 6 years.

I'd say it's worth the wait, I'm very satisfied with this update but the game definitely needs more work.  Though I highly recommend get it now (14th of December 2023) as the price might raise later on due to it being a more finished game.

The company is extremely small and I'm happy they didn't crunch themselves like the last two early access updates.  I'm proud to see this game finally release and I'm excited to see more content in the future.

Though I do believe the 50 dollars price tag is steep for it's current state.

ptsd generator

Hi! Are you here because they announced 1.0? That's unfortunate.

Not a few versions ago this was a great item. I'd have recommended it. Now they're touting it as released? Absolutely not.

In order to play the maps now you have to sequentially unlock them. This means your fun lives or dies on whether you're able to complete - potentially - a single map, or not. The difficulty therefore can vary from extremes. Can't deal with the far extreme? Well it might not be your fault - I'll cover that shortly. But it does mean you'll be locked out of the rest of the content.

Let's cover friendly A.I first; they're dreadful. Considerably worse than they were a few versions ago as mentioned. Pressing Z was NOT an instant win button back then, you still had to take care in positioning and choosing your route and steps taken through a map to attain success. Nowadays you can order your squad up to a door to Open and Clear and they'll move in the requisite 6 metres into the space and clock off for the day. This becomes a major concern on larger maps with larger rooms, where they'll enter potentially very many lines of fire and sit and wait to be deleted without returning fire. Compounding issues, friendlies in FRONT of you will complain about being stuck on you even if they're the ones taking up space! That Void had the nerve to release "Commander mode" in this state (good luck trying to take any of your officers to the finish line, by the way) is "No man's sky" release astounding. It's Cyberpunk 2077 release astounding. It's measurably better than "Gollum" astounding though. Still, when friendly A.I is told to open and clear, I've seen them move in to an area, have two of their own squad die and they've then proceeded to NOT clear the threat, again clocking off for the afternoon. How do I know they didn't? When I went to report the downed officers and bag their weapons, I was shot by the same threat! They don't have the wherewithal needed to be competent officers.

We're not done talking about large maps though - draw distance on enemies seems to be negotiable! Some enemies will outright warp out of space and time on your screen. Don't worry - they're still there. In fact they can shoot you while they're phased out of reality, but do enjoy trying to return fire on the invisible man.

As for the enemy A.I something has gone very, very wrong here. The game doesn't seem to want to be a John Wick simulator. You're a police officer, you should be moving to apprehend first and foremost. But if you do that, enemies will react and open fire far quicker than you can even get line of sight on them sometimes. They'll snap to you no matter if you're in the same room or a half mile across the map. The gameplay is at odds with the hyper-realistic graphics here - you can't discern enemies through the debris, but they can definitely see you. There's no description of scopes available yet either, so you're always at that disadvantage especially considering as mentioned, enemies disappear at range. So you're at a crossroads as to whether this is a police roleplayer or a pure squad based tactical shooter. But there's more! Enter the rules of engagement that state whether or not it's appropriate to use lethal force, which seem very arbitrary at times. Told a suspect to drop the weapon and then shot the weapon out of their hand several seconds later? That's not allowed. They're not dead, just incapacitated but that doesn't matter. Now, what if that same suspect had opened up on you instantly? You'd be dead! So there's no 'right' way to go about it at that point and it becomes unplayable. It will remain in this state until at least, enemy A.I has to acquire you as a target at distance with reasonable delay that equals that of the player. The maps are too dark and cluttered for you to be on even footing with them, presently.

To add to this, the TUTORIAL broke! When learning about how to instruct your red and blue team I was locked out of progressing, unable to issue commands. I had to shoot my own officer to have the others kill me, restart and progress. When that's your introduction to the 1.0 game space, that messes with you. It's a terrible seed of doubt to plant in the player's mind that your inputs are negligible or just outright worthless.

I have no idea what possessed void to take a product that was smooth and well running and turn it into ..this, but this is how it is now and based on how it is now I cannot recommend it. As is you're only getting a minor selection of playable maps before you hit a major stopping block. I was seeing great potential in RoN, now I don't know if I'll be hanging around to see if these get ironed out. Playing commander mode having lost all of my persistent data in the form of the officers I started the campaign with, there's no reason to not offer me an immediate restart button, but there it isn't. This is a huge blow to something I was previously enjoying.

This game has to be the most amazing tactical fps to have existed and with the final release and the improved AI this game couldn't be better. Of course with the amount of videos of this game showing up on social media with its full release, it has a massive influx of inexperienced fps players complaining about the difficulty while blaming their lack of skill in the game on the game itself. The AI behave as though your playing against real people which is what has created the amazing fan base it has. If you've always wanted an actually realistic tactical fps where the AI aren't idiotic and put up no kind of challenge then this game is for you. You are not god or rambo in this game. You have to actually plan how to handle every engagement. The AI move around the map and flank like actual people and do not stay in one place the whole game. You will need to read the stress and the moral of the enemies as that is actually simulated in the game. If you're moving around loudly then they will know you are about to come around the corner and will be aiming and ready. They will sometimes spray through walls or doors if they think you are there even if you aren't. Give your squad mates roles and use them. Give on guy on both blue and red a riot shield and when clearing and breaching they will lead in first. There is a noticeable difference between gang bangers, crackheads, and ex military based on how they respond, shoot, and move. Crackheads will stand in the open and be yelling letting you know where they are. More intelligent enemies like the secret service (yeah them) and ex military will be quiet and will listen to you and wait to ambush you. If you are a casual gamer this is not for you. If you want an honest to god fps challenge that actually feels realistic and puts fear in you then this is it. This is a game where you will most likely have to try levels a few or maybe even several times to complete. This is not for people who like to fly through a level and not put any actual effort into it. The AI in this game is by far the best I have ever seen in a video game and people who say otherwise are probably just frustrated. Sure they could add a difficulty setting but I admire a game without one that you have to get good at to play. In a world where games have become increasingly easier and more handicapped this brings back a time when games had a spine and said "You're going to learn how to play this if you want to beat it." Some missions are hard, some are easy, some are almost impossible at first. Some maps are small, some big, some claustrophobic, and some are wide open. The game hits every kind of mission you could want and every kind of environment as well. An incredible modding community continuously brings in new maps as well. Don't buy this game because you watched some guy on facebook or tiktok fly through a level alone and wipe out all the enemies and think that you can do that as well. This game is incredibly satisfying when you complete a mission unlike any other tactical fps I've ever played.

Lots of undeserving hype about this game. It's just yet another tactical shooter, this one is peppered with bugs.

- AI is awful, both in enemies and allies.
- You can only play with bots in your team in career mode (solo). This means that playing this game with only one friend is just barely possible since there will only be two operatives in your team... to clear houses, caves, mansions, villages, etc. So the only good way to play this game is either solo, or with at least 2 friends (3 players total).
- There is no way to change the loadout of your team between attempts without having to go back to headquarters.
- Even with SSD, the game takes long to load.
- Sometimes, between attempts, someone in your team can randomly lose all their armor, forcing everyone to go back to headquarters and restart the whole mission.
- Weapons dropped on the floor often clip through the geometry of walls and floor. Use the "highlight weapons" in the accessibility options to at least be able to see them.
- There isn't much customisation, even in weapons. It's often a case of "use this good sight, or any of these other crappy ones", or choose between laser, IR laser, or flashlight (you can only have one equipped... for whatever reason).

I purchased this game at full price because of pressure from friends and I deeply regret it. Also, don't buy this game if you only have one person to play with. You'll be limited to playing maybe the first 4 missions, things beyond that takes more people in your team.

If you carefully analyze statements in the latest Vol. 67 Ready or Not Development Briefing, Void isn't admitting any wrongdoing on their end but in fact; you, most of the world, and myself are just bad. 

"Why is the taser in the tactical slot rather than being a secondary?

The taser was moved to the tactical slot to address a growing desire from players to carry a lethal sidearm and a taser at the same time. By making it a tactical slot item, we improved the flexibility of less lethal options."
-How does removing an equipped weapon slot, improve my less lethal flexibility. I used to be able to have Primary, Secondary (Taser), and Pepper Spray. Now, you just remove your sidearm, no alternative option. Unless the intention is 'all non-lethal options shouldn't take a firearm slot', in that case pepper guns and bean bag shotguns should be turned into tactical as that would technically increase my non-lethal options by Void's stance. More eggs in a basket means more options to Void, instead of having more baskets. 

"Is further work being done on Suspect reaction time and game sense? When should Suspect AI be able to detect me?

Yes, we are working to address these systems to make the process fairer and more enjoyable for the player. Suspect AI aim, reaction, and game sense can sometimes be too fast or accurate for what should be expected. Currently, auditory sources are a large factor of whether Suspect AI can determine your location and how they may react to you."
-This can be interpreted as, "Yes, we are changing the A.I. because you're bad and can't/don't hold the SHIFT key while in retention (ready to fire your weapon - as going into low ready means you move faster but make more noise)". By using the phrase "sometimes be " implies that the majority of the time is the contrary, which would be that the A.I. is acting as expected. 

"My SWAT AI switch to lethal force (i.e. pistol) when I am trying to get an S-rank on a less-lethal play-through. Is there anything that can be done about this?

The granular control you have over your officers’ loadouts lets you remove lethal options, including ammunition, which can help circumvent unintended situations where they use lethal force for those of you striving for the coveted S-ranks. Furthermore, features to further facilitate less-lethal playthroughs may be expanded upon, such as potentially making less-lethal options like the TPL also available in the secondary slot in a future hotfix. Programming quirks may need to be sorted out for other less-lethal items such as the taser’s simultaneous compatibility in tactical/secondary slots, however."
-Here, they don't really see the true issue. The SWAT A.I. will swap to their sidearm with no ammo. You can setup their loadout all you want, all barbied out for non-lethal. They will still swap to the pistol with no allocated ammo. 

"Are Suspect AI intended to be able to shoot through walls?

To a degree yes, partly to prevent players from too easily shooting suspects through walls and to give Suspect AI further tactical flexibility, they are indeed intended to be able to fire through walls. However, we are seeing instances where their estimation player tracking appears too precise or their proclivity for engaging through walls is perceived as too much."
-"Instances"? "Perceived"? Watch Operator Drewski on Youtube. The Suspect A.I. have literal seconds of esp. What they're really saying here is the A.I. in the majority of cases, is balanced and functionally normal. Contrary to the belief that all suspect A.I. is comparable to the fictional being that is John Wick.

I want to start by saying I like the game. It feels good to play and the shooting mechanics are mostly responsive. 

That being said

If you are here for a gritty, harsh, swat-sim experience, this isn't it.
This game is an unintentional comedy.
Crackheads tracking you perfectly through walls and debris, soccer fans hitting you three floors away through concealment, commands being on the same key as actions so you scream at a civilian to comply standing 6 inches from them, after they had already complied (points for realism there at least) 

The story doesn't really exist, not that it needs to. Crimes be occurring and you be stopping them. Its when you look into the police department that it gets *really* funny. 
Therapist has to take unpaid overtime while you have full access to an arsenal of weapons including prototypes, foreign designs, and weapons that have never been used by any law enforcement agencies, absolute peak of comedic writing.

The friendly AI is mostly good to really solid. Your teammates will stack up, breach, clear, hold, all competently. And they apparently went to whatever crackhead training camp exists. Or maybe the crackheads are ex-police. Whatever is funnier to you.

A pure peace of copaganda filled with more bugs than a rock in the woods that you and your friends will enjoy every second of. 
Its no SWAT4, but do we really deserve that anyway?

Overall, good try, poor execution.

The game has a good spirit, good idea and a nice successor to SWAT 4 and that game had it's flaws. The worst part of this game is AI and performance. The performance is really inconsistent. I tried both epic and low settings. While I can run epic settings around 144 fps, sometimes I get lag spikes and game turns into PowerPoint presentation and after that I get console experience(around 30 fps). Same thing happens on any graphic settings.

AI in this game is something else. Enemy AI basically has wall hacks and sees you through smoke grenades, blindfolds and other "obstacles", that they are not supposed to see. Even in low lit, smoked corridor enemy will see your small pixel and will be able to run and gun you down as if I am in CoD.

This game should not have been released, it stills should be "early access" with poor performance and broken AI.

Suspects have x ray vision and pinpoint accurracy they often times will be shooting at you before they even round a corner. This game was NOT READY for release. The map Greased Palms is the worst map I have ever played I don't know how anyone thought this map was ok for release there is just too many angles and the AI can just seemingly always see you through everything, as soon as you get into the mail sorting room expect to just be shot at from suspects who you can't see, hopefully if you playing Solo your cheating AI squaddies take out the bad guys before they get you. I don't think the AI in this game has improved since I bought it in early 2022. I don't know why this game is getting as much praise as is when it is so clearly not ready for release. Edit: Now the game crashes every time I try to play the map Rust Belt. Yay!

Ready or not is the single best tactical shooter to ever exist. Campaign is very fun. Its very difficult at times though. Buy it. Void deserves more love.

I wish there was an in between for recommending this game. 

While the whole idea and story intertwined into this game is incredible (and most of the execution is good especially after 1.0), the AI still hasn't been fixed. 

The fact that I can open a door and an AI can headshot me from 100 metres away with a pistol is just so infuriating that many sessions have involved me just closing the game after this has happened. 

Then there's the optimisation. Void claimed they optimised this game a lot from the early access to 1.0 but I have seen almost the complete opposite. I have gone from averaging 100-120 fps on the early access to now where I am lucky if i even get 60 fps in every mission (I'm running a 4070 ti and 13700k). I don't know what has happened but I just wish the game worked well.

Would I recommend this game as it stands? That depends. 

If you have incredible hardware that can cope with this game and are looking for an updated SWAT 4. Yes

But in my opinion I would stay away until there is a few more major updates that hopefully finally fix the AI and actually optimise the game.

Edit: enemy AI are beyond broken, not fun

For a price tag of around 45 CAD I'd have to recommend it.

RoN is a great first person realistic S.W.A.T. game I have ever played. However, there are some minor bugs and certain things that I think the developers need to fix, especially with multi-player and singleplayer. The minor bug fixes would be when players have on their gear like plate carriers especially when you go to arrest someone on the other person's POV you see your character arrest but then you see a floating plate carrier where you character is supposedly standing as you are arresting a civilian or suspect. Another bug is when in singleplayer and you have your AI team with you, and you're either clearing a room or arresting a suspect or civilian they like to always get in front of you or get in your way. Also, with the AI team, they are automatically shooting through the walls at suspects that you don't even see yet before you clear the room. Another bug is also when you have the AI team running less lethal to get S ranks they always switch out to their pistols even when you set them to have no ammo in them yes realistically it would be bad in a situation when your running pepperball guns only but it just makes it hard to get those S ranks if the AI will waste their ammo in their primary gun and switch to a pistol that is empty and die to these suspects. One more bug that I think needs to be fixed is also the game crashes when waiting for friends to load into lobby or after you get done with missions and you hit return to headquarters.In my opinion, I hope the developers bring out some good updates with this game or more missions as it's a really fun game to play with friends or run solo.

I originally put the game away pre-1.0 because every enemy was John Wick and sometimes it was just impossible to get through a match. This seems to of been toned down quite a bit, but there are still some missions that feel nearly impossible to complete with the AI being crack shots shooting you through 2-3 layers of wall. Sometime's I'll see them running away from me and still shooting at me with their back to me. The game is currently in Full Release and it still has a lot of issues that were present in Early Access. Frame rate can drop from 140~ to 15 from just entering a new room, with AI as cracked as it is, its literally game over if it happens. One of my favorite things added was customization, unfortunately it is also bugged. Right now in order to unlock more options you need to get a certain score in certain maps. However if you receive an S rank it doesn't actually unlock some options. After completing an S Rank map, it should have awarded our squad with a watch, tattoo, and several clothing options however only about half the clothing options were unlocked. 

As of Right now I do not think the game is actually in a 1.0 State, I would not recommend anyone pick it up today unless you have 3 friends whom can laugh off all the bugs with you. If they fix the game into a better state, I'll come back and update accordingly.

Ready or Not is an ultra tactical shooter that really makes you feel like you are breaking the rules of engagement. The game takes place in the fictional location of Los Suenos which is pretty much just a scaled up downtown Detroit. The game includes many tactical gear options like armour, weapons and tacticals but if you wear anything other than NVGs you are not winning drip or drown and that's truly the most important thing in the game. The game has many unique maps that each feel like their own experience, these maps include: 
Twisted Nerve- The OG experience where you can mag dump into one single crackhead only for them to whip around and one tap you with the smallest possible calibre.
Ides of March- The most realistic experience of what its like to live in the middle east where any and every door is set with an IED.
Neon Tomb- A map that almost emulates the amount of stress I am under in any given real social interaction.

Overall the game is really fun and a great time but the AI is such bullshit sometimes that I truly feel like becoming the bad guy and doming every civvy in a 10 mile radius. It also seems that with each "hot fix" since 1.0 the game becomes more laggy and more buggy than an average Bethesda game. all things considered 7/10.

This game has its ups and downs. However with the 1.0 update, everything is so much better. New maps, customization's, and revamped maps. With the 1.0 update it now gives you a full ranged controllable AI assistance on missions. I really enjoyed this, and I hope you all will too!

It's a good game, good gun play and pretty good graphics. a few character models could use some touch-ups, some clothing clipping and things like bomb vests don't stay with models very well, overall not a big issue. Though 2 things at the moment that do cause frustration while playing are AI (both Suspect and team AI) and doors, both need a rework. 

Suspect AI) They seem overly aggressive, often coming out of the building or travel through multiple rooms to attack you. Now maybe some types should do that like veterans (with previous tactical knowledge) or drugged up suspects (with aggressive behavior and a dulled sense of self preservation) but I'd imagine basic suspects would rather remain rather sedimentary. When trying to apprehend criminals, they are very stubborn to surrender, even when its 5 SWAT Vs 1 with SWAT already aiming at them. Even when they do surrender they almost always seem to pull out a second weapon when you close in to cuff, this feels like it should be a rare event but it's not, it's nearly every suspect.

Beyond the issues of trying to arrest them they are also extremely observant, are exceptionally good at wall banging, able to turn and shoot accurately extremely fast, and can seemingly see straight through tear gas. For their observance ability, I was probably 100 feet away looking through 2 sets of doors and a hallway, a suspect came into view in the middle of the hallway looking away from me, but then instantly turns to engage us. They are able to track you for a moment after seeing and engage you through a wall, you can see this especially on a map with a staircase right next to a door, the bullet holes with be following you as you climb the stairs until they most likely get a head shot. With CS gas you can not see very far through it, but the AI seem to be able to see and engage you with no issue as you travel through the cloud.

Teammate AI) When order to clear a room are actually fairly competent, If one has a shield they will take point, AI will check under beds if that's something on the map. Now and then they pick a wrong direction to focus or go in a less important  section of a room, but people do that too so don't really fault them much there. The issue with teammate AI is when following you or stationary after an order. When following or moving to start an order they really don't help much (probably because they travel single file and block each other's  LOS). When stationary they aren't very reactive at all, they might shoot back a bit, but they should seek cover when under fire and should move to help if one of them is under fire.

Doors) Every door in the game can be opened in both directions, that's not how most doors work. Some doors should also be spring loaded and shut themselves after being opened, like doors you would find in businesses and schools 
(but not residential doors and such), this would help a lot on certain maps where the suspects seem to have opened every door in the building (again I would say moving around too much for people that I would imagine would probably prefer barricading themselves instead).

Overall it's a good game that I enjoy, just with some frustrating elements currently.

While I really WANT to recommend this game. I can't in good faith do so at the current state it's in. While people will say "oh just play tactical" or "get good" to my reasoning. No. That's not the issue here and this game is not immune from flaws and critique. I have played every way these people suggest and it's still an issue. 

The AI is way to over tuned, I even tested in replay mode and tried researching how other people also felt. And I'm not the only person being killed before average human reaction time can kick in, or getting wall banged instantly by a suspect who saw me through a crack in the door and 100% accurately tracked my location through a wall for 3 whole seconds. This doesn't seem normal and feels like a bug. I want the game to be lethal, but what I don't want is to be up against AI I can't even react to because they don't even have frames between being idle and then firing at me.

This game is really cool and I love what it's trying to do but I can't recommend it at this stage. Not until the AI has been reworked, save your money and wait until the AI at least gets some reaction time or tracking tweaks.

Edit: The No Crack AI mod actually does solve this issue, but it shouldn't be on modders to fix a game.

AI's reaction times are insane. I thought it wasn't bad at first and then I got insta-killed the literal moment I leaned through a doorway.

They did not change how the AI acts - nobody surrenders and civilians are still uncooperative. I think they made it worse, actually.
All of the "stop the killing" and "your job is to bring order to chaos" propaganda plastered around the station is almost funny - it doesn't matter what mission you're doing, how big or small time the perps are, they want you and your entire squad dead and will stop at nothing to do so. My advice? Forget going non-lethal, just put them down. You can maybe arrest a couple if you incapacitate them with a flashbang but don't count on it.

Considering every mission in the game has you against multiple (at least fifteen) fanatical, bloodthirsty suspects with automatic weapons and level XIVV-whatever body armor, the LSPD should be sending in thirty-man government death squads in Call of Duty juggernaut suits with LMGs and air support, not four underpaid SWAT officers in cheap body armor and helmets that couldn't protect them from a BB gun, let alone an actual bullet.

I mean, this is insane, how are two jerk-offs running a bitcoin farm able to bribe what feels like a small army of gang members (who SOMEHOW have automatic rifles, despite Los Suenos being an obvious stand-in for Los Angeles) to put their lives on the line for them during a SWAT raid??? I mean, terrorists, cultists and drugged-up meth addicts acting erratic I can understand, but why are small-time thugs with makarovs so willing to throw their lives away against a four-stack of armed and "armored" SWAT personnel? It's insane.

On top of that, Void has been using AI art for pretty much everything they can - posters, photos, even UNLOCKABLE COSMETICS, and it's damn ugly. This is worse than Early Access.

Great job, Void. I want to like this game. I would love to kick doors in with my buddies, but considering the game's current state, just... no.
